DOC.TEXT: Non-Arabic studies introduced from Greece, India, etc for unique study. Philosophy · Logic · Geography · Medicine · Mathematics · Astronomical Calendar · Optics · Alchemy and the like.

DOC.Title: Ibn = Hasm
DOC.TEXT: In the later Umayya period, a theologian and poet who was active in Córdoba.

DOC.Title: Ibn-Rushed, Avroes
DOC.TEXT: Born in Cordoba, a philosopher who served Muwahid morning. It also leads to law, medicine and astronomy. The commentary of Aristotle's work was regarded as the main source of Aristotle's study of the medieval Western Europe and had a great influence on the formation of Scholastic philosophy.

DOC.Title: Ibn = Batuta
DOC.TEXT: A traveler in Morocco. Traveled in Egypt, West Asia, India, Sumatra, China, Central Asia, Eastern Europe, North and Inland Africa, and dictated "The Three Continents Tour".

DOC.Title: "Three Continents Travel", "Travelogue"
DOC.TEXT: Travel memorized by Ibn = Batuta. It was completed in 1356 and is regarded as an important historical material concerning the Islamic world in the first half of the 14th century.

DOC.Title: Islamic natural science
DOC.TEXT: In the Islamic world, Indian and old Hellenistic culture was ingested, medicine, mathematics, astronomical calendar, optics, alchemy, etc. developed. It showed the world's highest level at the time, such as the development of the idea of ​​transfer to India and the idea of ​​zero, influenced the science of Western Europe after the Renaissance period. For that reason many scientific terms are derived from Arabic.

DOC.Title: concept of zero
DOC.TEXT: Established in India. Combined with the Arabic numerals and decades in the Islamic world, it contributed greatly to calculations and mathematics.

DOC.Title: Arabic numerals
DOC.TEXT: Current Arabic figures. It was completed in the Islamic world with Indian figures as the prototype. After the 12th-16th century, it also spread to Europe.

DOC.Title: Hall of Wisdom
DOC.TEXT: An academic research institute built in Baghdad in the 9th century. Translation and research of Plato and Aristotle's Greek literature into Arabic language was done.

DOC.Title: Astrology
DOC.TEXT: A way to predict the future from the operation of celestial bodies. It developed greatly in the Islamic world, and advanced the observation art and astronomical calendar.

DOC.Title: Alchemy
DOC.TEXT: Technique to change base metal to precious metal. Originated in ancient Egypt, the ancient magical nature in the Islamic world declined and became the starting point for modern chemistry.

DOC.Title: Furrysmie
DOC.TEXT: Mathematics / astronomer of the Abbasian era called Iranian system. In addition to modifying the astronomical measurements in India and Greece, established Arabic mathematics and developed algebra (algebra).

DOC.Title: Ibn Sinaer, Avuquenna
DOC.TEXT: Iranian medical scientist / philosopher. He is a perfectionist of Islamic philosophy, leaving many writings of philosophy-related work and compiling Greek · Arabian medicine in "medical law".

DOC.Title: "Medical Law"
DOC.TEXT: Ibn-Sinaer 's work. It is a culmination of Greek · Arabian medicine, it was translated into Latin, and was also heavily used in Western European medicine in the 12th-16th century.

DOC.Title: "Wisdom for happiness"
DOC.TEXT: A literary work by the oldest Turkish written in Kashgar under Kara = Han morning rule.

DOC.Title: Fileduci
DOC.TEXT: Iranian great ethnic poet in the Gazna era era.

DOC.Title: "Shah-name", "King's book"
DOC.TEXT: Phil de Sea is a large-length epic about 60 thousand phrases completed after spending about thirty years, using myths, legends, and history from Iranian founding country to the end of the Sasan dynasty as a material. It is regarded as one of the best masterpieces of Persian literature.

DOC.Title: Nizamiya Academy
DOC.TEXT: Educational institution (Madrasa), established since the mid-11th century by Prime Minister of the Serbujuk Dynasty, by Nizzam-Almurk for bureaucracy training and encouragement of Sunnah scholarship. It is also known that Gathers served as a professor.

DOC.Title: Umar-Hayyam, Omar Khayam
DOC.TEXT: Iranian poets and scientists from the Serg Juk era. In addition to participating in the enactment of the Jalary calendar, he wrote representative poetry "Rubaiyato".

DOC.Title: "Rubaiyato"
DOC.TEXT: The four-line poetry which Umar-Hayyame wrote. Expressed rationalistic pessimism and momentumism.

DOC.Title: "A Thousand and One Night Story", "Arabian = Night"
DOC.TEXT: Arabic great tale collection. After the medieval Persian literary collections were translated into Arabic in the 8th century, the narrative of various places such as India, Iran, Arabia, Greece was merged and it was formed. It was almost the present form in Cairo of the 16th century.

DOC.Title: Rashid = Aedin, Rashidudiden
DOC.TEXT: Iranian politician and historian of Il Han country. He wrote the history book "Collection" with Gazan Han's life.

DOC.Title: "History"
DOC.TEXT: Early in the 14th century, Rasheed = Audine's history book written in Persian. Important historical materials centered on the history of Mongolia, as well as histories and local magazines of various places.

DOC.Title: Alhambra Palace
DOC.TEXT: The Nasrus palace of the 13th-15th century remaining in Granada. It is decorated with brilliant arabesques and it is regarded as the representative architecture of the western Islamic world.

DOC.Title: Arabesque
DOC.TEXT: A decorative pattern that geometrically arranges the stems and leaves of plants in a pattern. Arabic characters were also designed. It developed in the Islamic area which avoided the portrait that leads to idolatry.

DOC.Title: Miniature, fine detail
DOC.TEXT: Precise paintings drawn on the decoration and illustration of books. In Islam it is the etymology that made Latin minium (red lead) the main pigment. Beginning as an illustration of books around the 12th century, after the mid-13th century, it was further developed under the influence of Chinese paintings.

DOC.Title: Germanic person
DOC.TEXT: One of Indian-European ethnic groups. About 1000 years ago I lived in the southern part of the Scandinavian Peninsula, the Jutland peninsula and North Germany, but spread almost all over the Rhine-Danube, while compressing the Celts. Since the first century BC, deepening contact with Rome, promoting political integration, threatening the northern side of Rome. Initially as a fellow, from the middle of the imperial period as a mercenary and Colonus, flowed into the Roman territory. Caesar in the first century and Takitus in the first century after the record.

DOC.Title: Celtic person
DOC.TEXT: Indian-European-based indigenous people living in central and Western Europe. Later most of them were conquered by the Romans and Germans and assimilated, but even today some people inheriting this culture live in parts of the UK, France and Spain.

DOC.Title: "Gallic War II"
DOC.TEXT: Caesar's book. A record of Gaulia (nearly the present French) expedition from 58 to 51 years ago. It is an important historical material of the Old Celtic-Germanic Studies, also known as the Latin name.

DOC.Title: "Germania"
DOC.TEXT: A book by Takitus. Important historical documents about the Germanic people around the century.

DOC.Title: Civics
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Council of Kivitouss (german tribal state) before the big move. It was presided over by the king or the chief, composed of all the adult men of the free people.

DOC.Title: Hun people
DOC.TEXT: An Asian-based cavalry nomads who invaded Europe in the fourth to fifth centuries. The theory that it was composed of various ethnic groups such as fangs is powerful. Conquering the East Goths person of the Germanic faction, it became a direct cause of German migration. In the 5th century I caught Western Europe and built a great empire in Pannonia in the middle of the Danube river, but collapsed by internal conflict and epidemic disease at the end of the 5th century.

DOC.Title: Germann's great move
DOC.TEXT: Beginning in 375, it is about a gigantic migration to the southwestern part of Europe of the Germanic people who lasted for about two centuries. The direct cause was pressure by Hung people, but the shortage of arable land due to the increase in population is considered to be the root cause.

DOC.Title: East Goth People
DOC.TEXT: A part of East Gelman. Although he lived in the northern coast of Black Sea, he was conquered by Hun in 375 and moved to Pannonia under the surveillance. With the collapse of Hun at the end of the 5th century, she moved to the Italian peninsula led by Theodoric and founded it.

DOC.Title: West Goat People
DOC.TEXT: A part of East Gelman. Fearing the westward movement of Hun, starting in the south of 375, crossing the Danube River the next year and moving to Rome territory became the beginning of the Germanic migration. Destroying the Roman army in 378, westward, early fifth century in the south of France. Then moved the center of gravity to the Iberian Peninsula early in the sixth century.

DOC.Title: Vandal Man
DOC.TEXT: A part of Germerman. From Pannonia through northern Italy and Spain, he founded in the northern part of Africa early in the 5th century.

DOC.Title: Franker
DOC.TEXT: A part of West German. Expanded and expanded to the northern part of Gallia while maintaining the original residence on the eastern bank of the Rhine, Clovis founding in the late 5th century.

DOC.Title: Burgund
DOC.TEXT: A part of Germerman. In the beginning of the 5th century, I moved to the eastern part of Gallia as a Roman alliance and founded it. Today, I left the place name of Burgundy in the Eastern region of France.

DOC.Title: Lombardo, Lombardo
DOC.TEXT: A part of Germerman. In the mid-sixth century, I entered Northern Italy from Pannonia and founded it. Leave the place name of Lombardia in northern Italy.

DOC.Title: Anglo-Saxon people
DOC.TEXT: From the Jutland peninsula the german small tribe name that was in the present coastal part of northwest Germany. In the first half of the fifth century, across the ocean, invaded the Great Britain Island, conquered indigenous Celts and built small kingdoms for each tribe.

DOC.Title: Great Britain Island
DOC.TEXT: From the Roman era to the seven kingdom era, it was called Britannia Britannia.

DOC.Title: Attila
DOC.TEXT: The Great King of the Hung people (ranging from around 433 to 453). It entered Pannonia (later Hungary region) and formed a great empire, built the peak period of Hun, but invaded West Rome and lost in Katarawanum. The next year, I invaded Northern Italy, but suddenly died on the way home after Pope Leo I persuaded, and the power of Hun collapsed soon.

DOC.Title: Battle of Katarawanum
DOC.TEXT: The eastern land of Paris. A battle where West Rome, West Goat, Frank Allied troops victory against Attila's Hun army.

DOC.Title: Germanic nationals
DOC.TEXT: Countries who german tribes settled in settlements. At the same time as the founding king concurrently served as Governor of the West Roman Empire (after its destruction, the Eastern Roman Empire), he applied the Roman law to the Roman population and the Germanic method to the Germanic people. Most religiously believed in the Arian factions, they declined contrary to Catholic indigenous peoples, and many cases were destroyed by attacks by foreign enemies.

DOC.Title: Odoquel
DOC.TEXT: German captain of Western Rome from Germanic. In 476 he destroyed the Western Roman Empire and built the kingdom (the kingdom of Odakel), but later lost to East Goth.

DOC.Title: Ruin of the West Roman Empire
Augustus
DOC.TEXT: The last emperor of the Western Roman Empire (ranking 475-476). It was abolished by Odokel.

DOC.Title: Theodoric, Theodoric the Great
DOC.TEXT: The king of the eastern goat (around 473 to 526). He escaped with all the tribes from under Hun 's control, entered Italy, beating the kingdom of Odoakel and establishing the country. In respect of Roman culture, religiously forced the Arians to Romans and rebounded.

DOC.Title: East Gothic Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: It was founded in Italy on behalf of Odakel's kingdom. Ravenna is the capital. It was destroyed by Justinian of East Rome.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Vandals
DOC.TEXT: Foundation on the north coast of Africa. Temporary Mediterranean was suppressed, but because of suppression of indigenous people, it rebelled and destroyed by Eastern Rome even internal conflict.

DOC.Title: Araric
DOC.TEXT: King West Goth (rank 395-410). Ruined the Balkans, plundering Rome temporarily occupied in 410, but died on the way to Africa.

DOC.Title: West Goat Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: In the beginning of the 5th century, the founding country in South France, then the center of gravity in the Iberian Peninsula moved to the beginning of the 6th century, Toledo was the capital. Originally believed in the Arians, but converted to Athanasius at the end of the sixth century. It was destroyed by the Islamic forces (Umayya Morning).

DOC.Title: Burgundo Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Founding country from Switzerland to southeastern France. It was destroyed by the Kingdom of Frank.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Lombardo
DOC.TEXT: Foundation in Northern Italy. It was destroyed by Karl the Great King of Kingdom of Frank.

DOC.Title: Seven kingdom, heptkey
DOC.TEXT: A small kingdom group built by Anglo-Saxon in southern Britannia.

DOC.Title: Egbert, Egberto
DOC.TEXT: King of Wessex in the seven kingdom. Unification of the Seven Kingdom in 829, the first British kingdom built.

DOC.Title: England
DOC.TEXT: It means the southern half of the Great Britain Island. Etymology is the land of Angles.

DOC.Title: Frank Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: In the latter half of the 5th century the clowvis of the Meroving family unified the Frank people and founded them. It survived long together with the Kingdom of England among the Germanic states, dominated the area including the majority of Western Europe. In the mid-eighteenth century the royal dynasty moved to the Carolingi family and became the heyday in the era of Karl Empire, but in the mid-nineteenth century it divided into three regions of France, Germany and Italy.

DOC.Title: Meroving Morning
DOC.TEXT: The crown built the whole Frank unified, the first Kingdom of the Kingdom of Frank. Internal conflicts continued since the second half of the 6th century, replaced by the Caroling Morning in the mid-eighth century.

DOC.Title: Clovis
DOC.TEXT: King of the Kingdom of Frank (ranking 481-511). Unified the Frank people, convert to Catholicism, deepen their alliance with the Roman Church, strengthen the foundation for Frank's development.

DOC.Title: Conversion of Clovis
DOC.TEXT: In the influence of the wife of a Catholic follower, he converted to Athanasius in Rans church with his vassals. After that, the relationship with the Roman population became smooth, the foundation of the development of the Kingdom of Frank has settled.

DOC.Title: Miyazashi, Mayor-Domus
DOC.TEXT: In the sense of secretary of family affairs, head of administrative and financial aspects of Frank Kingdom. In the morning the morning declined in Frank 's inherited division inheritance and so on, the real rights moved to the Carolingian who is laying the palace.

DOC.Title: Battle between Tours and Poitiers
DOC.TEXT: The battle that Miyazashi Karl-Martel repelled the Islam army which invaded the Frank territory beyond the Pyrenees mountains. The Western European Christian world has gone out of danger.

DOC.Title: Carl-Martell
DOC.TEXT: Palace of Frank Kingdom (Meroving). In the battle between Tours and Poitiers, they repel Islamic forces, after which the real power transferred to the Caroling family.

DOC.Title: Pippin, Pippin III
DOC.TEXT: A child of Martel. Small pippin. With the support of the Pope, we abandoned the Meroving morning and opened the Caroling Morning. Donated land to the Pope, deepened cooperative relations with the Pope.

DOC.Title: Caroling morning
DOC.TEXT: Pippin began the dynasty of the Kingdom of Frank. It eventually divides, eventually disappearing after the West Frank Kingdom (later France) was severed.

DOC.Title: Dive in Pippin
DOC.TEXT: At the request of the Pope Pippin attacked Langobald in 754-755 and offered Ravenna etc, which he won, to the Pope in 756. This was the beginning of the Papacy.

DOC.Title: Ravenna region
DOC.TEXT: The land in northeastern Italy. It became the first papal territory.

DOC.Title: Holy Spirit
DOC.TEXT: Prosecution with sovereignty of the papacy. It became the economic foundation of the Pope.

DOC.Title: Carl the Great, Charlemagne
DOC.TEXT: A child of Pippin. King Frank (ranking 768-814). It destroyed the kingdom of Langobald, and fought with the Spanish Islamic army and fighting the Germans such as the Saxon people, fighting back the invasion of the Avar people, succeeded in unifying the confused Western Europe. In 800 years, crowned from the papacy, became the emperor, and fulfilled the "Resurrection of the West Roman Empire". This strengthened the connection between Germanic, Roman and Christian cultures, and the foundation for the development of Western European culture was established.

DOC.Title: Saxon people
DOC.TEXT: A german faction. I live in the Elbe · Wesel region of North Germany. Some emigrated to Britannia in the latter half of the fifth century, the rest subordinated to the eighth century Karl Empire, converted to Catholicism.

DOC.Title: Avar person
DOC.TEXT: Since the 6 th century, the Mongolian nomads who have invaded Central Europe. Lost in the 7th century Eastern Rome, declined after the 8th century uncarl taunt, assimilated to Slavs and Magyres.

DOC.Title: Nori
DOC.TEXT: Frank's local administrator. Karl Emperor took over centralization, appointed influential people in the province as crows and made them direct bureaucrats, but on the other hand, dispatched a policeman to supervise.

DOC.Title: Inbound use
DOC.TEXT: Karl Emperor took over centralization, appointed influential people in the province as crows and made them direct bureaucrats, but on the other hand, dispatched a policeman to supervise.

DOC.Title: Leo III of the world
DOC.TEXT: Pope the Rome (ranking 795-816). He declared the resurrection of the West Roman Empire by giving the emperor Carl the capital.

DOC.Title: Crown of curl
DOC.TEXT: Pope Leo III gave the emperor of Western Roman Emperor to Carl in St. Peter's Basilica. It was a reward for helping the Pope, confirmed the superiority of the Papal Rights, and was also a countermeasure to the East Roman Empire.

DOC.Title: Restoration of Western Roman Empire
DOC.TEXT: At the same time as the coronation of 800 years the Pope declared. It is different from the ancient West Roman Empire both regionally and contentally, but this resulted in a major force opposing the East Roman Empire.

DOC.Title: Verdan Convention
DOC.TEXT: Treaty after the death of Ludwig I, the son of Carl King, the three children fought and divided the kingdom into three.

DOC.Title: Mersen Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Treaty which decided to split and consolidate Chubu Frank after the death of Ludwig King II of the Eastern Frank and King Charles W. Frank, after the death of King Lothard II of the Chubu Frank (the son of Rogart Rodrig I of Ludwig I).

DOC.Title: Eastern Frank Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The Kingdom which was established in the German region of eastern Frank, after the Verdan Convention. From the beginning aristocratic power (the princes) strongly subsequently dispersed power further, the Caroling family discontinued in 911.

DOC.Title: Saxony family
DOC.TEXT: One of the east of Frank. The royal family of the German Saxony morning (919-1024).

DOC.Title: Heinrich I
DOC.TEXT: German King of the Saxony Era first (ranking 919 to 936). It repels the invasion of Norman Majar Slav and on the other strengthens the relationship with West Frank and Burgund.

DOC.Title: Otto I
DOC.TEXT: King of the second generation of the Saxony morning (ranking 936-973). Magyar Slave, we suppressed Bamen · Italy. Following the crown from Pope Johnes XII, it became the first Holy Roman Emperor (ranked 962 to 973). Protected and nurtured the church forces in order to suppress the large houses.

DOC.Title: Holy Roman Empire
DOC.TEXT: A nickname of a medieval German state, established in the coronation of Otto I in 962. It departed as the greatest strongest feudal state in Western Europe, and the emperor had a big feature in that it was elected by the election. The eleventh century was at its peak, declining since then, virtually dismantled in the mid-17th century Westphalia Convention, but only the name of the empire continued until 1806.

DOC.Title: Imperial Church Policy
DOC.TEXT: It is mainly that the emperor has the right to appoint and release clergy. I tried to use the church (monastery) organization for governance under the imperial authority.

DOC.Title: Italian policy
DOC.TEXT: Interference policy to Italy which the Holy Roman Emperor did in the 10th-13th century. I went for the reasons of protection of the Pope and the Papacy, but the aim was to maintain the Imperial Church policy. However, it promoted independence of the domestic people, leading to the division and decline of the empire.

DOC.Title: Magyar person
DOC.TEXT: Non-Indian = ethnic ethnic group. The father of the later Hungarian. It went eastward from the 5th century, entered Central Europe, settled and built around the present Hungary mainly at the end of the 9th century.

DOC.Title: Battle of Lechfeld
DOC.TEXT: Battle that Otto I decisively defeated the Majar. The Majar people were prevented from entering the western province, after that they settled in Pannonia.

DOC.Title: West Frank Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: It was established in the West half of Frank in the Treaty of Verdun Merssen, then became France. The royalty was weak, a large feudal feudal state self-sustaining large and small feudal elephants. The Carolingian disappeared in 987 and it was destroyed.

DOC.Title: Paris Knit
DOC.TEXT: It refers to the House of the Majesty or the House of the Lords who have decorated near Paris.

DOC.Title: Hug = Capet
DOC.TEXT: Eriks of Paris. With the achievement of repelling the invasion of the Normans, the Carolingian morning was discontinued and was elected the king, became King of the first generation capoe (987 to 996).

DOC.Title: Capoe morning
DOC.TEXT: In the early days feudalism houses were self-sustaining, with only about 50 major rivalries comparable to the capuish family, the royalty was weak, but since then it has worked to centralize the central government and has developed rapidly since the 12th century.

DOC.Title: Italy
DOC.TEXT: The Carolingians discontinued in 875, after that, confusion continued with the interference of the Holy Roman Empire and the advance of Islamic forces. In Central Italy there was a papal territory, but in Northern Italy cities such as Genoa and Venice became independent, competing against the intervention of the Holy Roman Empire with a city alliance.

DOC.Title: Norman people
DOC.TEXT: A Germanic man of the northern system which used the Scandinavian peninsula and the Baltic coast as the original residence. Activities began in the latter half of the eighth century and plundered near the coast but began to settle and establish from the ninth century. The cause of the activity seems to be population increase, lack of arable land and conflict between tribes.

DOC.Title: Northern Germanic person
DOC.TEXT: Another name for Norman people.

DOC.Title: Scandinavian Peninsula
DOC.TEXT: The original residential area of ​​Norman people. Face the North Sea, the Baltic Sea.

DOC.Title: Jutland Peninsula
DOC.TEXT: Like the above are Norman's original residence.

DOC.Title: Viking
DOC.TEXT: Another name for Norman people. It can be thought of as the meaning of "people of vik (river)".

DOC.Title: Dane People
DOC.TEXT: The name that called the Normans who came to Britain from the Denmark region in the UK.

DOC.Title: RUSSI, RUSS
DOC.TEXT: Nominal name from the Slavic side for the Normans who entered the Slavic region. There is also a theory of "the ship's rower" and the meaning.

DOC.Title: Lullyik, Ruler
DOC.TEXT: According to tradition, the chief of Rushes built the Novgorod country.

DOC.Title: Novgorod country
DOC.TEXT: In 862, Viking 's chief lueriku was a commercial city state built mainly under the Ruso and Novgorod, which is the beginning of Russian founding.

DOC.Title: Russian origin
DOC.TEXT: It is the establishment of Novgorod country by Rusi.

DOC.Title: Democratic Republic of Kiev
DOC.TEXT: The ninth-thirteenth century Novgorod died southward to Kiev and founded it. As Rusi was a small number, it gradually became slab and became an early feudal state of East Slav. From the Byzantine Empire (the Eastern Roman Empire), we accepted cultures such as Greek Orthodox Christianity, but since the latter half of the 11th century it declined with internal conflict, and it was lost to Mongolian Batu and disappeared.

DOC.Title: Slavic person
DOC.TEXT: Indian = European ethnic group. Although the foot of Carpathias is considered to be the original residential area, it spread to Eastern Europe after moving to Germanic. After that, it was divided into East Slavs, South Slavs, and West Slavs.

DOC.Title: Roro
DOC.TEXT: The chief of Norman. It was destroyed all over northern France since the latter half of the 9th century, and it was sealed in the Public Normandy in 911 by the French king who fainted by it.

DOC.Title: Principality of Normandy
DOC.TEXT: In 911 Roro founded in the Seine River Basin. Then in 1066, William Normandy conquered Britain.

DOC.Title: Anglo-Saxon Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: One German Angle and saxon who immigrated to the Great Britain Island in the 5th century and built a conquered indigenous Celts.

DOC.Title: Alfred Great King
DOC.TEXT: British King of Anglo-Saxons (ranking 871-899). Defeated the invasion of the Dane people, improved the law and political system, made the unification of England progress.

DOC.Title: Knut, Kanut
DOC.TEXT: The King of 5 Danes (ranking 1016-35). In 1016 he conquered England, opened the Dane morning (1016-42), and dominated Denmark and Norway. After that death, the Anglo-Saxon family temporarily restored.

DOC.Title: William Normandy
DOC.TEXT: Founder of the Norman dynasty. After summarizing the Principality of Normandy, he conquered England in 1066, established the Norman morning, took William I (rank 1066 to 87).

DOC.Title: Battle of Hastings
DOC.TEXT: The battle where the army of William of Normandy landed in southern England and destroyed the British army. It became one turning point of British history.

DOC.Title: Norman conquest, Norman = Conquest
DOC.TEXT: William refers to conquering England. After that, a British feudal system with relatively strong kingdom was established.

DOC.Title: Norman morning
DOC.TEXT: Dynasty begins with Norman conquest. Although the successive kings were the king for England, as Normandy was the keeper of the King of France, it caused the British-France relationship to be confused. In this era again, the elements of French culture strengthened in England.

DOC.Title: Ruggero II II
DOC.TEXT: King of the Kingdom of Sicily (King ranked 1130 to 54). Dominated Naples (Southern Italy) and Sicily, deepening interaction with Muslims.

DOC.Title: Both Sicilian kingdoms
DOC.TEXT: In the 12th century, Norman Ruggero II established the country. The unique culture coexisting with Norman, Islam, Byzantine culture flourished.

DOC.Title: Denmark Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Around the 8th century the Dane people formed around the Jutland peninsula. In the first half of the 11th century, it was united by King Knut.

DOC.Title: Norway kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Normans of the late nineteenth century formed a state in the western Scandinavian Peninsula. It was unified with Knut in the first half of the 11th century.

DOC.Title: Sweden Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Around the 10th century Normans founded the eastern part of the Scandinavian Peninsula.

DOC.Title: Iceland
DOC.TEXT: Normans discovered and emigrated in the 9th century. It was annexed to Norway in the latter half of the 13th century. Norman culture was kept long, including "Edda" of Nordic mythology.

DOC.Title: Greenland
DOC.TEXT: Normans reached the end of the 10th century and colonized the southern end.

DOC.Title: Finland
DOC.TEXT: The majority of inhabitants are Finn who speak Ural-Altai language. It was under Sweden 's rule for a long time and moved under Russian rule in the early 19th century.

DOC.Title: Catholic
DOC.TEXT: The Greek word "universal" is the etymology. The Athanasius school which was made legitimate at the Council of Nicene (325) leads to Roman Catholicism of today.

DOC.Title: Goto mountain
DOC.TEXT: It refers to Rome, Constantinoble, Antioch, Jerusalem, Alexandria's Total Archbishop Church. Among them, Antioch, Jerusalem, and Alexandria went down in the Islamic area since the 7th century. In addition, the church of Constantinople became the main mountain of Greek Orthodox with direct control of Byzanz emperor, and Rome became the mainland of Catholic, so the two conflicted.

DOC.Title: Leadership
DOC.TEXT: In the five mountains, the right as the leader church, the Roman church insisted early on. 3 When the church entered under Islamic control, it was disputed between Constantinople and Rome.

DOC.Title: Rome = Catholic church
DOC.TEXT: At the Council of Nicene in 325, Athanasius' trinity theory was certified as Catholic (universal), establishing doctrinal legitimacy. As the status of the Roman Church improved, the conflict began with the Constantinople Church (Greek Orthodox Church) and the conflict became decisive in the controversial worship of the statue from around the 8th century, which was officially separated in 1054. After that occupied the head of the Western Christ church, the bishop became a pope, continued to reign.

DOC.Title: Pope, Pope
DOC.TEXT: Roman = highest chief of the Catholic church. In common name is the pope. Since the 5th century, the bishop of Rome (the total archbishop) placed himself as a successor to Peter, claiming the leadership.

DOC.Title: Peter
DOC.TEXT: In the beginning of the twelve apostles, it was later regarded as the first pope.

DOC.Title: Leo I
DOC.TEXT: Pope (ranking 440-461). Succeeded persuading Attila of Hun who entered Rome and saved Rome from destruction. He also asserted the Roman church's leadership against the Constantinople Church.

DOC.Title: Abbey
DOC.TEXT: A monk training institution for monks and nuns. The monastery in the east is a life of "seclusion, abstinence, penance, meditation", the monastery in the west features living "poverty, purity, obedience".

DOC.Title: Monk
DOC.TEXT: The monastery's practitioner.

DOC.Title: Benedictus
DOC.TEXT: A monk born in Italy. Improved the monastery originated in the east and introduced it to the west, promoted the monastery movement.

DOC.Title: Benedictine Abbey
DOC.TEXT: In the 6th century Benedictus opened a monastery in Monte-Casino, Italy. He gave a supportive command from the Pope and the King Frank, and in the 9th century, he took charge of all the Western monasteries.

DOC.Title: Monte-Casino
DOC.TEXT: Mountains of Central Italy. In 529 Benedictus founded a monastery here and became the center of the Catholic evangelism movement.

DOC.Title: St. Benedictus' precept
DOC.TEXT: Benedictus imposed on monks "Severe pure, purity, submission" severe precepts. In that motto, "pray and work" is raised, emphasizing labor as well as faith, escaping economic dependence on secular forces.

DOC.Title: Gregorian I
DOC.TEXT: Pope the Pope (ranking 590-604). He played an active part in propagating to Germanic people, especially Anglo-Saxon.

DOC.Title: Mission to german people
DOC.TEXT: After the conversion of King Frank at the end of the fifth century, the Roman church actively tried to propagate against the Oriental church. At the end of the sixth century I succeeded in converting Anglo-Saxon, and by the 8th century I also proceeded to the West Goat, Langobald etc.

DOC.Title: hierarchical system
DOC.TEXT: Personnel / administrative organization that declares hierarchy ranging from Pope to clergy of the lowest church in Greek word meaning management of sacred things. It was maintained and immobilized as the Catholic development.

DOC.Title: Parishes church
DOC.TEXT: A church that divides believers into certain jurisdictions (parishes) in villages and cities, and mainly conducts missionary work for those people. Residents of the parish have strengthened ties as a member of the community by participating in ceremonies such as Sunday Mass and ceremonial funeral held by the church to which they belong.

DOC.Title: Archbishop
DOC.TEXT: Senior bishop who will oversee other bishops while overseeing their own diocesan. That power rivaled the secular large houses.

DOC.Title: Bishop
DOC.TEXT: clergyman. We supervise the bishop district, which is the administrative division of the church. It was also a lord with provision, and it was regarded as a secular owner.

DOC.Title: priest
DOC.TEXT: Go over one church and do Misa holy festival and Sacramento (sacrament = seven important ceremonies).

DOC.Title: Abbot abhorian
DOC.TEXT: Chief responsible officer under the jurisdiction of the monastery. It was also a lord with provision, and it was regarded as a secular owner.

DOC.Title: Holy Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop and abbot, who had a wide place like the secular houses and recognized the same status from the emperor and the king.

DOC.Title: Priesthood trading
DOC.TEXT: To sell priesthood and accompanying secular property. It took place in the 9th-10th centuries when the church was corrupt. In 1075, Pope Gregory VII banned it, but it continued thereafter.

DOC.Title: clergy's marriage
DOC.TEXT: It is forbidden in Catholics for clergy to have a wife, it was a symbol of church corruption / popularization along with priesthood trading.

DOC.Title: Abbey movement
DOC.TEXT: The internal exercise campaign, which attempted to revive the early monastery spirit with faith and labor as precepts to corruption and popularization of the church.

DOC.Title: Cluny Abbey
DOC.TEXT: The Benedictine monastery founded in the Middle East of France in 910. Since the eleventh century, it became the center of the reform movement of the Church and had a great influence on the reform of Gregory VII.

DOC.Title: Cistercian Order
DOC.TEXT: In 1098, founded in Ciceo Chubu, France. It also played a big success in the cultivation movement and developed most in the 12th-13th centuries.

DOC.Title: Mendix Priest
DOC.TEXT: In the 13th century, a new type of monastic bishou was born criticizing the feudalization and enrichment of monasteries. He did not have personal property to live in poverty and faith, and preached less than a devotee from a believer. New features are also seen in terms of activities mainly in cities.

DOC.Title: Franciscan Order
DOC.TEXT: Founded in 1209, Francesco. A typical mendicant priest who strongly denied ownership of property and respected preaching activities in cities.

DOC.Title: Francesco
DOC.TEXT: Around 1181-1226 The saint of Assisi in Italy. I woke up to faith and abandoned property, developed preaching activities while doing poverty and wanderers life, and founded the Franciscan Order.

DOC.Title: Dominican religion
DOC.TEXT: Mendicant monastery founded by Dominix in 1215. Like the Francesco Order, a typical mendicant society denying property ownership and respecting preaching activities in cities. In particular, he gave great results to the heresy and theology thesis.

DOC.Title: Dominico, Dominicus
DOC.TEXT: I am from Spain. Sermoning against the Catharism in Southern France, followed by a Dominican religious group.

DOC.Title: "Peace of God"
DOC.TEXT: A peace pledge that the nobility and noncombatants are not infringed on their lives and property. Since the end of the 10th century, the church organized church conferences and arranged. Apart from this, it is called "armistice of God", and the church sometimes decided to prohibit battle for a certain period centered.

DOC.Title: Priesthood Introduction Right
DOC.TEXT: The authority to appoint high priests such as archbishop (bishop) and monastery director.

DOC.Title: Intellectual Rights Struggle
DOC.TEXT: A conflict between the Pope and the German Emperor (Holy Roman Emperor) over the possession of priesthood intellectual rights. It reached a climax in the 11th-12th centuries.

DOC.Title: excommunication
DOC.TEXT: It is a religious punishment performed by the Pope and the Church, which declares exclusion from the Church community. Excommunication means social elimination, it was the last means by the Pope.

DOC.Title: Gregory VII
DOC.TEXT: Pope (ranking from 1073 to 85). We struggled to pursue the church and establish the papal rights, and succumbed to German emperor Heinrich IV. After that, he was counterattacked and died at the place to escape.

DOC.Title: Gregorian Reform
DOC.TEXT: Church reform advanced by Pope Gregory VII. In the spirit of the Cluny Abbey, we prohibited priesthood trading and clergy's marriage, and centered on the Holy Father holding about religious authority.

DOC.Title: Heinrich IV IV
DOC.TEXT: Emperor of Holy Roman Emperor (rank 1056-1106). The priesthood royal right was excommunicated in contending with Pope Gregory VII, and he succumbed (humiliation of Canosa). After that he succeeded in counterattacking against Gregory VII, but he died in disappointment after receiving rebellion from his son Heinrich (next Emperor Heinrich V).

DOC.Title: Humiliation of Canosa
DOC.TEXT: The emperor Heinrich IV who was excommunicated to Pope Gregory VIII was finally forgiven for allowing for forgiveness in the snow in Canota Castle of Northern Italy.

DOC.Title: Worms Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Concerning priesthood pledge rights, an agreement between Pope Calixustus II and Emperor Heinrich V. The intellectual right itself is a compromise that the pope has, but in the German territory the emperor has the right to approve the territory of the church / monastery, the religious rights struggle has ended for a while.

DOC.Title: Innocentius III
DOC.TEXT: Pope (ranking 1198-1216). The German emperor Otto IV, British king John French king Philippe II and others were excommunicationly experts. He also advocated the 4th Crusade and celebrated the height of papal rights. The word "the papal right is the sun and the emperor's right is the moon" is taken from Innocentius III who showed off the superiority over the emperor's rights of the papal rights.

DOC.Title: feudal society
DOC.TEXT: A society in which agriculture-based natural economy was carried out and serfs were in charge of production work. In addition, clergy and aristocracy became dominant, and was also a social-oriented society that owned and dominated production means (land) and labor force (farmers). A hierarchical Kimishi (master-slave) relationship was established between the lords and the vassals.

DOC.Title: feudal system, feudal master-slave relationship
DOC.TEXT: In the feudal society, it refers to the relationship between the priests (master-slave) formed mainly by giving and receiving the enclosure. It was established in connection with the Roman benefit plan system and German seniority system. The feudalism guard insisted autonomous control, and the centripetal force of the state tended to be lost.

DOC.Title: Ministerial thank you
DOC.TEXT: A ceremony held by the vassal when the enclave is given to the vassal by the monarch, the vassal owes allegiance to the monarch

DOC.Title: Equity Rental System
DOC.TEXT: In the end of the Roman Empire, a system that began as society became confused and unstable. The land owner handed over the land to an influential person in the area to protect his own land and borrowed it again.

DOC.Title: PhD system
DOC.TEXT: Custom of old Germanic. Instead of receiving free clothing, weapons, etc. from the influential people, free people got loyalty as a minor instead of being protected. Especially developed in Frank Kingdom.

DOC.Title: enclosure, knowledge
DOC.TEXT: Land lent to the vassal from the lord. The vassal who received the enclosure will have a loyalty relationship between military service and service to the lord, but this was a contractual relationship, not a unilateral subordination.

DOC.Title: Non-import not permitted
DOC.TEXT: The right to be exempted from the entrance of the manor and the official of the king and its officials and their duties (trial, taxation, etc). When this right was accepted, the lord became a complete ruler of the manor, and the feudal society was decentralized.

DOC.Title: Princess
DOC.TEXT: A lordship with own control and vassals. The upper is from the Great Hou, following the King, and the lower includes the castle, the name of the hall, or even one small lord.

DOC.Title: Knight
DOC.TEXT: It refers to the warrior class that military service is done by connecting the master-slave relationship with the lord. In general, there are many small lords, active in the battle of the Middle Ages, became a flower form of feudal society.

DOC.Title: Chivalry Spirit
DOC.TEXT: The morality expected to be possessed by the cavalry soil. In addition to respect for Yuutake and Nobuyoshi, there were also influences of Christianity, and it was thought that touches to women and the weak are important.

DOC.Title: Lord
DOC.TEXT: Generic name of the owner of the manor. Including kings and churches and aristocrats and knights. I dominated farmers within the manor.

DOC.Title: Shop
DOC.TEXT: Land ownership. It consisted of cultivated land consisting mainly of villages and directly owned by the lords and farmers' holdings, and land (common ground) including pastures and forests jointly used by farmers.

DOC.Title: Directly-owned place, lord's directly operated place
DOC.TEXT: Out of the manor, land directly owned by the lords. It was cultivated by the imprisonment of domestic fellows and serfs, and the whole crop was made by the lords. Farmers' motivation to work here was low, and productivity was low.

DOC.Title: Holdings, farmers' holdings
DOC.TEXT: Land which farmers held in manor. Farmers were able to deliver rents (in kind, currency) to their owner and the rest to their own, so labor motivation and productivity were relatively high.

DOC.Title: Classic Manor
DOC.TEXT: It is a manor consisting of directly managed place management and owned land management, and the revenue of the lords was largely due to the service of serfs. By the 10th century, it spread almost throughout Western Europe.

DOC.Title: Ryo manor, pure manor
DOC.TEXT: A manor that the lords divided the directly operated land and lent it to farmers, making it a farmer's possession. The income of the lord became a product rent instead of a concession. In France in the 11th-13th century, in the UK in the 14th century was formed, leading to the improvement of the status of farmers (serfs).

DOC.Title: two-field system
DOC.TEXT: Half of the cultivated land is set as a relaxation area, cattle and sheep are kept to restore the ground power, and the following year, the farming method to be cultivated land.

DOC.Title: Three fields
DOC.TEXT: Agricultural law that will divide cultivated land in three, set it as a spring arable land, autumn arable land, and fallow land, and it will go around in 3 years. From the 10th to the 11th century, it spreads on behalf of the traditional two-field system and continued until the early 19th century.

DOC.Title: Entry place
DOC.TEXT: It is a common use site of farmers, also called a common place. Many are mountain forests, wilderness, lakes and so on.

DOC.Title: Serfs
DOC.TEXT: Farmers who occupied the vast majority of the manor. Ownership of families, residences, cultivators etc was accepted, but semi-free citizens without relocation and free choice of occupation. He was given charge, donation and other duties to the lord, and took charge of a considerable part of the production labor of feudal society.

DOC.Title: Immigration
DOC.TEXT: Labor age for serfs lords. The main cultivation of the directly managed land (2 ~ 3 days a week). Especially in the classic manor, the serious burden was borne by the serfs.

DOC.Title: Contributing
DOC.TEXT: Production rent that serfs pay to the lord. Liberalization from the possession is the main. Later it moved to coinage rent.

DOC.Title: sufficient tax
DOC.TEXT: The seriousness that the serfs paid to the church. I paid a tenth of the harvest.

DOC.Title: Marriage tax
DOC.TEXT: The tax that the farmer paid for the lords when married. There was meaning of compensation for the shift of labor force.

DOC.Title: Death Tax
DOC.TEXT: After the death of the serfs, the tax the heirs to the lords. This guaranteed the hereditary assets of the possession, and then moved to inheritance tax.

DOC.Title: Territorial Jurisdiction
DOC.TEXT: Jurisdiction exercised by farmers against farmers. By having this by the owner, it became possible to dominate serfs by force.

DOC.Title: Byzantine Empire
DOC.TEXT: Another name for the East Roman Empire. Origin of the capital city Byisantum etymology. After the division, the Roman rule dominated the eastern half. After the Roman Empire died at the end of the 5th century, it was almost successful in restoring the dominance of the entire Mediterranean area in the middle of the sixth century, but the area shrank in response to Islamic attacks since the second half of the 7th century. In the 7th century the Empire made Greekization, the emperor doubled as a religious leader (Emperor papalty), and formed a unique Eastern European culture against Western Europe in terms of politics, religion and culture. After the crusade movement further declined, it was destroyed by the Ottoman Empire.

DOC.Title: Constantinople
DOC.TEXT: The capital of the Byzantine Empire. In the first half of the 4th century, emperor Constantine emperor Roman capital took over, became the capital of the Byzantine Empire after the eastern and western division of the empire. It is located at the key position of the Black Sea and the Mediterranean Sea and became the center of politics, economics and culture of the eastern Mediterranean. Current Istanbul.

DOC.Title: Justinian, Justinian the Great
DOC.TEXT: Byzantine emperor (ranking from 527 to 565). In an effort to restore the old Roman territory, in 534 he conquered Vandal Kingdom, 555 East Gothic Kingdom, and robbed part of the Iberian Peninsula from the West Goat Kingdom. He gained silkworm eggs from China, made a silk fabric business, culmination of the Roman law, the construction of the Hagia-Sophia cathedral, and the heyday of the empire celebrated. On the other hand, however, because of long-term warfare the national strength was exhausted, and after the death the empire was confused.

DOC.Title: "Roman law enforcement"
DOC.TEXT: The compilation of ancient Roman laws that Justinian ordered Tribonian to edit. It consists of three parts: the Imperial Script, the Legal Theory and the Legal Introductory. It was completed in 534.

DOC.Title: Triponian
DOC.TEXT: Legist of Byzantine Empire. In accordance with the life of Justinian it became the center of compilation of "Roman law comprehensive".

DOC.Title: Heracryios I
DOC.TEXT: Byzantine emperor (ranking 610 to 641). Susan Morning · Islamic and fighting, the military district system was enforced (There is also the theory that the military district system was started a little later).

DOC.Title: Military district system, Tema system
DOC.TEXT: A regional governance system that divides the territory of the empire into several military provinces and gives the commander the authority of the administration as well as the military aspect and to supervise it. Although it was effective for defense from foreign enemies such as Islamic powers, later the commander became self-sustaining, leading to weakening of the emperor's power.

DOC.Title: Tunta military force
DOC.TEXT: A military agreement system that gave land to soldiers and small peasant groups, but instead imposed military service obligations. Under the military district system, it was implemented in a wide area excluding the capital.

DOC.Title: Leon III, Leo III
DOC.TEXT: Byzantine emperor (ruling 717-741). I issued a ban on statue of the statue and also won the fight against Islamic forces.

DOC.Title: Holy statue ban
DOC.TEXT: Byzantine emperor Legislation prohibited the creation and worship of all the holy images such as Jesus and Virgin Mary launched by Leon III. It was issued against Islamic forces which severely deny idolatry. However, since the Roman Church continued to conduct missionary work for the germans by opposition to the ban, he became a major dispute between the East and West Churches, which later became an opportunity for the Church to split in the east and west. In addition, the ban was lifted in 843.

DOC.Title: controversy on worship of statues
DOC.TEXT: Controversy over the Byzantine Emperor and the Roman Pontiff over the statue of the statue ban.

DOC.Title: Icon
DOC.TEXT: Statue of the Oriental church depicting Christ, saint and religious scene.

DOC.Title: Greek Orthodox Church
DOC.TEXT: About the eastern church against the Roman Catholic church in the west. At the boundary of the statue of the statue of the statue, it fought against the Roman church and the orthodox Christianity, which was established in 1054 completely.

DOC.Title: Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the Greek Orthodox Church, opposed to the Pope. In fact the Byzantine emperor had the appointment and dismissal power, and he dominated.

DOC.Title: Emperor's Papalism
DOC.TEXT: In the Byzantine Empire, the system that the emperor grasped the right of politics by having the right to appoint and release the chief of Greek Orthodox Church (Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople). There is a big difference between Western empire system where emperor rights (kingship) and papal rights were separated.

DOC.Title: Macedonian Morning
DOC.TEXT: Dynasty of the Byzantine Empire. In the latter half of the 10th century, Islam and Bulgaria etc. expanded their power.

DOC.Title: East and West division of church
DOC.TEXT: Since 726, conflicts with the subject matter of the worship of the statue of the statue, excommunicated in 1054 and completely divided.

DOC.Title: Pronoia system
DOC.TEXT: Land system implemented in the Byzantine Empire since the 11th century. The emperor lets powerful generals and aristocrats manage the state-owned land and residents for the first generation and imposes duty on military service in compensation. It is similar to feudalism system of Western Europe, but land re-enforcement was not done, and a position class system was not established. In the 13th century, the emperor's rights were further weakened, the hereditary assets of the state-owned land were officially recognized, so the division and decline of the empire was accelerated.

DOC.Title: The 4th Crusade
DOC.TEXT: Crusaders made in the advocacy of Pope Innocentius III. Venice took the initiative, took the sea for the first time, occupied Constantinople, aborted the Byzantine Empire, built the Latin Empire.

DOC.Title: Latin Empire
DOC.TEXT: Empire the 4th Crusade built around Constantinople. It was destroyed by the Nicene empire (a Byzantine state built after the end of the Byzantine Empire).

DOC.Title: Ottoman Empire
DOC.TEXT: A country built by Turkish tribes who controlled Balkans from Asia Minor. In 1453 the Byzantine empire was destroyed.

DOC.Title: Byzantine culture
DOC.TEXT: Culture of the Byzantine Empire. Because the Greek Orthodox regulation was strong, there was a lack of originality of academics and thought. Inherited and preserved the classical Greek culture, influenced neighboring ethnic groups, it also had a big influence on the formation of Italy = Renaissance. On the architectural aspect it gave birth to the Byzantine style of its own.

DOC.Title: Byzantine style
DOC.TEXT: Features appeared in church architecture decorated with dome (circular roof) and mosaic wall painting.

DOC.Title: Greek word
DOC.TEXT: In the Byzantine Empire, the Greek region became more important as the territory shrinks, and after the 7th century Greek became an official language.

DOC.Title: Nomisma
DOC.TEXT: Gold coins issued in late Roman Empire and Byzantine Empire. Especially it was used as a base currency in medieval Mediterranean trade. In Latin it is also called Solidus gold coin and became under the sign $ of today's American currency (dollar).

DOC.Title: Hagia-Sophia Basilica, St. Sophia Basilica
DOC.TEXT: A representative Byzantine cathedral built by Justinian emperor in Constantinople. The original roof of bronze circle became popular as a symbol of Greek Orthodox Church. After the occupation of the Ottoman Empire, it was renovated to an Islamic mosque.

DOC.Title: Mosaic mural painting
DOC.TEXT: Stones, shellfish, glass and other small pieces fitted in the walls of plaster, making up patterns and paintings. It was greatly developed by the Byzantine Empire 's church architecture.

DOC.Title: St. Vitale Basilica
DOC.TEXT: The church cathedral in Ravenna. In the mid-sixth century architecture, representative of Byzantine art rich period. Famous for the mosaic mural of Justinian and later Theodora.

DOC.Title: St. Mark's Basilica
DOC.TEXT: It is located in various places, but the one of Venice is the most famous. It was renovated in the 9th century, Byzantine style in the 11th century.

DOC.Title: Pannonia
DOC.TEXT: In the middle of the Danube river, it means the current Hungarian basin. Hun occupied in the 5th century and the Magyres settled at the end of the 9th century.

DOC.Title: Magyar person
DOC.TEXT: Asian ethnic groups. Ural language. It settled in Pannonia at the end of the 9th century, westward from the foot of the southwest southwestern Ural Mountains around the 5th century. The current Hungarian father.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Hungary
DOC.TEXT: After the late 10th century the Kingdom built in Pannonia after the Majals were defeated by Otto I at the battle of Lechfeld. Then accepted Catholicism in the 11th century. It was devastated by the invasion of Mongolia in the 13th century, but regained its prosperity in the 14th century. In the 16th century most of the territory was occupied by the Ottoman Empire and was incorporated under the rule of Austria (Habsburgs) at the end of the 17th century.

DOC.Title: Matthias I
DOC.TEXT: King Hungary (ranking from 1458 to 90). Invade the Austrian doubling as King of Bamen. He also emphasized the introduction of the Renaissance culture and revealed the heyday of medieval Hungary.

DOC.Title: Dakia
DOC.TEXT: Northern coastal area downstream of the Danube. It almost overlaps with today's Romania. In the beginning of the 2nd century it was regarded as a province of Rome, people settled from various parts of the empire, and development advanced.

DOC.Title: Romanian
DOC.TEXT: Latino. As for its origin, there is the theory that it is due to the mixture of old Dhakians and Romans, and the theory that they have migrated from the Balkan Peninsula. In the 13th and 14th centuries the Kingdom of Walachia and Moldavia were established.

DOC.Title: Principality of Wallachia
DOC.TEXT: A principal native of Latin language. In the 14th century he was independent from Hungary, but in the 15th century it was under the control of the Ottoman Empire.

DOC.Title: Democratic Republic of Moldavia
DOC.TEXT: Although it was founded in the 14th century, it entered under the rule of the Ottoman Empire in the 15th century. When this and the Transylvania region join Wallachia, it almost overlaps with the current Romanian territory.

DOC.Title: Slavic person
DOC.TEXT: Ethnicity belonging to the Indian-European system and living mainly in Eastern Europe. It can be divided into three big East Slavs, West Slavs, and South Slavs, but most of them except the West Slavs were influenced by Byzantine Culture (Greek Orthodox).

DOC.Title: West Slavs
DOC.TEXT: Polish, checkers and others mainly, received Catholic.

DOC.Title: Polish
DOC.TEXT: West Slavic system. Built the kingdom in the 10th century and soon accepted Catholicism. Although it was hit by the invasion of Mongolia in the 13th century, it reached its peak in the era of the Yagaiwo dynasty that was established in the 14th century.

DOC.Title: Kazimierz III, Kazimierz the Great
DOC.TEXT: Only one big king (ranking 1333-70) in Polish history. Backed by economic development, Poland established the first legal code and established the country's oldest Krakow (Yaegao) university.

DOC.Title: Lithuanian
DOC.TEXT: Indo-European Baltic school. Unified the nation against the invasion of the 13th century German Order. In the 14th century called the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, it covered the eastern bank of the Baltic Sea.

DOC.Title: Lithuania = Poland Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian Grand Duke Yogaewo (1351-1434) was founded by marrying the Queen Poland in order to counter the advance of the German Order Group.

DOC.Title: Yagaiwo Morning, Yagello Morning
DOC.TEXT: The dynasty dynasty of Poland. In the battle of Tannenberg in 1410, he defeated the Knights of Germany. The capital city is Krakow.

DOC.Title: Checker
DOC.TEXT: West Slavic system. It accepted Catholic at the end of the nineteenth century, strengthened the cohesion as an ethnic group between the 10th and the 11th century, and formed the Kingdom of Vamen.

DOC.Title: Boamen, Bohemia
DOC.TEXT: It is an area in the center of the present Czech Republic, the city center is Prague. In the 10th century a checker built the Kingdom of Beimen, but since the 11th century it was incorporated under the rule of the Holy Roman Empire.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Moravia
DOC.TEXT: A slavic kingdom, built by checkers in the 9th century. In the 10th century, it declined with the advance of the Magyres.

DOC.Title: Slovak people
DOC.TEXT: West Slavic system. It is thought that it has the same origin as the checker, but received control of the Majar since the 10th century.

DOC.Title: South Slavs people
DOC.TEXT: From the 6 th century onwards, Slavs who fell south to the Balkans. Serbian / Croatian people are representative.

DOC.Title: Serbian
DOC.TEXT: South Slavic system. In the sixth century I entered southwest of the Balkans, accepted Christianity by the 9th century, belonged to the Oriental Church. In the middle of the 11th century we built the Kingdom of Serbia and integrated the northern part of the Balkans in the first half of the 14th century. It was defeated by the battle of Kosovo at the end of the 14th century, and was placed under the control of the Ottoman Empire for about 500 years thereafter.

DOC.Title: Croatian
DOC.TEXT: South Slavic system. In the 7th century south of the Carpathian region. From the end of the eighth century to the beginning of the ninth century, it came to Frank (King Carl) and converted to Catholic. After independence was achieved, it reached its peak in the 10th-11th century, but at the end of the 11th century it became effectively a Hungarian nation.

DOC.Title: Slovenian
DOC.TEXT: South Slavic system. I live in the northwest part of former Yugoslavia. At the same time as the Croatian, he came to Frank Kingdom and converted to Catholic. I was strongly influenced by Italy (Venice) and Austria.

DOC.Title: Bulgarian
DOC.TEXT: Asian nomads. I entered the southeastern part of Vulcan, we signed an agreement with the Byzantine emperor at the end of the 7th century, and was granted the foundation. Afterwards assimilated into indigenous Slavo, converted to the 9th century Greek Orthodox. Early in the 10th century is at its peak.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: In 681, the kingdom Bulgar conquered the Slavic people and built it. After that, Slavicization progressed, accepted Greek Orthodox in the 9th century, Simeon I got the title of Tourism and called the 1st Bulgarian Empire (893-1018), but was soon dominated by the Byzantine Empire. At the end of the 12th century, Asen I reconciled with the Byzantine Empire to establish the Second Bulgarian Empire (1187-1393). However, by the end of the 14th century, it lost to the Ottoman Empire and placed under control. There is also a theory that the beginning of the first Bulgarian empire will be 681 years. ]

DOC.Title: CUREROS
DOC.TEXT: Missionary of Greek Orthodox. In order to propagate to Slavus, we made Gragorite letters based on Greek letters.

DOC.Title: Cyrillic character
DOC.TEXT: It is a prototype of letters used in today's Russia and others, developed from Gragor.

DOC.Title: East Slavs people
DOC.TEXT: Russians, Ukrainians, Belarusians, etc., belonging to them, developed mainly under the influence of Byzantine culture (Greek Orthodox).

DOC.Title: Russian
DOC.TEXT: It is the central ethnic group of East Slavic people, accepting the Greek Orthodox in the era of the Kiev Duchy, and laying the foundation for the development.

DOC.Title: Novgorod country
DOC.TEXT: Lewick, the head of the Swedish Viking, founded the late ninth century (862).

DOC.Title: Democratic Republic of Kiev
DOC.TEXT: The family of the 9th-13th century Lyurik moved from the Novgorod and was founded, eventually becoming mixed with the indigenous Slavs and becoming slave. Dominated the trade route connecting the Black Sea and the Baltic Sea, and accepted Byzantine culture, it prospered, but it was destroyed by invasion of Batu of Mongolia in the 13th century.

DOC.Title: Vladimir I __
DOC.TEXT: Grand Duke of Kiev (around 980 to 1015). On the occasion of marrying with Byzant emperor 's sister, I converted to Greek Orthodox. Advancement of Byzantine and serfdom system in Russia.

DOC.Title: Kipchak = Han country
DOC.TEXT: Mongolian Batu founded South Russia around the country. Sarai is the capital. Russia received this severe ruling, and its development was greatly delayed in the western world. On the contrary, it is true that the Mongolian rulers indirectly controlled by using the Slavic persons, and there was also a hypothesis that they did not do so severe control.

DOC.Title: "Tatar's Yoke"
DOC.TEXT: Representation that means that Russia (Kiev) was placed under severe control of Mongolia. It was regarded as the cause of the development of Russia being delayed.

DOC.Title: Grand Duchy of Moscow
DOC.TEXT: It was promoted to Mongolia in 1328 with recognition of success.

DOC.Title: Ivan III
DOC.TEXT: Grand Duke of Moscow (rank 1462 to 1505). It consolidated the other countries, unified the national land almost, and in 1480 it was totally independent from Mongolian rule. Married to the niece of the last Emperor of Byzantine Empire, he inherited the name of Tsari and the emblem emblem (two head eagle).

DOC.Title: "Third Rome"
DOC.TEXT: I thought that Moscow would be the third holy city, following Rome and Constantinople. It is said that Ivan III boasted of prosperity and named it.

DOC.Title: Ivan IV
DOC.TEXT: Prince of Moscow and Czech Republic of all Russia (ranking 1533-84). From 1547 I had my parents. It suppressed and consolidated the opposing people in terror politics using a powerful guard, and was called "the thunderhead" (Grozny). Pushing for external war, started Siberian management, reinforced the serfdom system.

DOC.Title: Russian Orthodox Church
DOC.TEXT: A faction of the Eastern Orthodox Church. The Eastern Orthodox Church has been the center of the Greek Orthodox Church, which is the leader of Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople. However, as the Byzantine Empire was destroyed, the Patriarch was also presided over in Moscow, and the Orthodox church was named as the center of the Oriental church.

DOC.Title: Tsar
DOC.TEXT: Emperor of Russia. Russian form of Caesar which was one of the titles of Roman Emperor. It was used by Ivan III, and was officially used by Ivan IV in 1547. It became the origin of tyranism of despotism.

DOC.Title: Ukrainian
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Slavic system. Residents in southwestern part of Russia. It was divided into Poland and Lithuania in the 14th century by the invasion of the Mongolian of the 13th century, and it was annexed to Russia at the end of the 18th century.

DOC.Title: Three fields
DOC.TEXT: Agricultural law that will divide cultivated land in three, set it as a spring arable land, autumn arable land, and fallow land, and it will go around in 3 years. From around the 10th to the 11th century, it became popular on behalf of the traditional two-field system, raising agricultural productivity.

DOC.Title: Iron-made farm tools
DOC.TEXT: It became popular from the 12th century, it was used for such as Arima and made it possible to use cattle horses and raised agricultural productivity.

DOC.Title: Weighted wheeling
DOC.TEXT: Especially it was possible to cultivate deeply by using the iron with a heavy and durable wheel, which caused the improvement of agricultural productivity.

DOC.Title: Waterwheel
DOC.TEXT: It began to popularize around the 12th century and enhanced agricultural productivity.

DOC.Title: Open cultivated land system
DOC.TEXT: Agricultural law which cultivates cultivated land for each owner without partitioning it with fences or moats. It became popularized in connection with three fields. In some cases it is convenient for cattle and horses to haunt meals, and the arable land was often used as a ground fence (arable land segmented into elongated bandwags).

DOC.Title: Large cultivation movement
DOC.TEXT: A large-scale cultivation cultivation campaign that was advanced around the 12 th-13 th century, due to population increase in Western Europe. Dutch reclamation, cultivation of the Alpine highlands, and eastern colonies by German princes and others are representative.

DOC.Title: Oriental colony
DOC.TEXT: The colonists to the Slavic settlement in the eastern part of the Elbe River, which the German princes, knights, monasteries, etc. went from the 12th to the 14th century. In particular, the Order of the Germans promoted a colonist with a strong military character in the southeastern part of the Baltic Sea due to indigenous Christianization, and acquired a large territory to become the basis of later Prussia.

DOC.Title: Pilgrimage fashion
DOC.TEXT: During the 11th and 12th centuries the pilgrimage of sacred places in Europe grew, and Rome, Jerusalem, Santiago de Córdostella gathered many people as the three major pilgrimage sites.

DOC.Title: Santiago de Chomostella
DOC.TEXT: A city in the northwestern part of Spain. One of the twelve apostles, believed to have the tomb of St James, gathered many pilgrims.

DOC.Title: Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Holy land of Judaism, Christianity and Islamism. Although the heat of pilgrimage of the 10th century Christians suddenly increased, in the 11th century it was occupied by the Islamic Serjuke morning and was regarded as the reason for the Crusades expedition.

DOC.Title: Seljuk morning
DOC.TEXT: The Turkish dynasty which occurred from Central Asia and became Islamic. It restrained the whole of West Asia and fought with Byzantine Empire and West Liao in Fatimid Morning. The deprivation of Asia from the Byzantine Empire caused the crusade expedition from Europe.

DOC.Title: Urbanus II
DOC.TEXT: Pope the Rome (rank 1088-99). I was from Cluny Abbey and promoted church reform. He was asked for relief from the Byzantine Empire, called Clermont religious council and advocated Crusaders.

DOC.Title: Clermont Religious Conference, Clermont Council
DOC.TEXT: A meeting held in Clermont in central France in 1095. At the meeting, the pope emphasized the abundance of the East, and preached Islamic expedition against Israel. In addition to religious belief, the establishment of superiority to the Oriental church, the expectation of acquisition of land and goods, etc. overlapped, and a great expedition to recapture the sacred place was decided.

DOC.Title: Crusader
DOC.TEXT: Christian troops formed to recapture the sacred place Jerusalem from the rule of Islam. It was named after the soldiers marked the cross. Formally, 7 crusaders were made but failed except for the 1st and 5th, eventually failing to recover the sacred land (In addition to this, the theory that counts the number of crusades as 8 times There is also the theory that it is 1291 that the last year of the Crusades fell down to the end year). As a result, the authority of the Pope was greatly fluctuated, the feudal lords fell, and the authority of the king increased. In addition, the development of the Northern Italian cities, which profitable in the Mediterranean trade, the interaction of people and things in the Mediterranean became complicated, the spread of the monetary economy remarkable, leading to the collapse of the medieval feudal society.

DOC.Title: First Crusade
DOC.TEXT: French princes are central. I went eastward through the road. In the conflict between the participating principals (in particular France and Germany), in the mutual distrust of the Crusades and the Byzantine Empire succeeded in recapturing the sacred land and built the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: A feudal state built after the first Crusade restored the sacred ground, giving a sealant to the remaining battle ground. In the first half of the 12th century I dominated the majority of Syria, but in 1187 I lost the city of Jerusalem by counterfeiting Ayube morning Saladin, and in the 1291 Mamluk morning attack, the last base Acron was fallen and it died.

DOC.Title: The 2nd Crusade
DOC.TEXT: German emperor French king leads eastward through land route. Because of the opposition of the two sides, due to the distrust of the Byzantine empire and the non-cooperation, I reached Ackon, but I returned home to be chased.

DOC.Title: Saladin, Salahu-Affine
DOC.TEXT: Kurdish people. In 1169, I built the Ayyub Morning and in 1971 I ruled Egypt by destroying the Fatimid Morning. In 1187 I recovered the city of Jerusalem and I became the third crusade. It was also known from the West by Yuutake and generosity.

DOC.Title: Aiyuba Morning
DOC.TEXT: Sunni school Islamic dynasty where Saladin founded. In the center of Egypt, I was played as the 3rd, 5th and 6th Crusade. The vast territory was divided into the children, the Egyptian region was destroyed by the Mamluk morning, the West Asian region was destroyed by the Mongolian army.

DOC.Title: The Third Crusade
DOC.TEXT: In opposition to the advance of Saladin, the German emperor, the King of France, King of England and others raised Western Europe and went eastward through the road. Crusade 's high tide period. The French army went back to the unexpected death of the German emperor of mediation as a counterattack of King French King British. The King of England was self-taught to Saladin, but eventually it ended in failure.

DOC.Title: Richard I, lion heart king
DOC.TEXT: British king (ranking 1189 to 99). In the Third Crusade, I struggled for soldiers against Saladin, but after all I went home and returned to the country. Later he died in battle against France.

DOC.Title: Friedrich I, Redbeard King
DOC.TEXT: Holy Roman emperor (ranking from 1152 to 90). He was known for his efforts to strengthen the empress, even among the emperors of the past, participated in the Third Crusade, but drowned on his way.

DOC.Title: Innocentius III
DOC.TEXT: Pope the Rome (ranking 1198-1216). The German emperor · King of England · King of France followed excommunication · clothes and clothing, revealed the height of papal rights, proposes the 4th Crusade.

DOC.Title: The 4th Crusade
DOC.TEXT: Venice, who was in charge of maritime transport, took the initiative and occupied and plunder Constantinoble for its commercial expansion, established the Latin Empire. After that the crusade's religious character weakened.

DOC.Title: Latin Empire
DOC.TEXT: The 4th Crusade was established in Venice's colonial state. It was annihilated by the Byzantine Empire (officially the Nikaia Empire) attack.

DOC.Title: Boys crusade
DOC.TEXT: Crusaders led by boys who said they heard God's message in Germany, France and others. Young people and poor people headed to the sanctuary, but some of them returned home on the way or the group departing from southern France was unsuccessfully sold as a ship wreck or a soldier.

DOC.Title: The 5th Crusade
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Friedrich II of Germany temporarily recovered the sacred place by talks with the Islam side, but it did not last forever.

DOC.Title: Friedrich II
DOC.TEXT: Holy Roman emperor (ranking 1215-50). I restored Jerusalem by negotiating with the Ayube morning. He grew up in Sicily (Palermo) which thrived in the Mediterranean trade and was understood to be an educator with an understanding of Islamic civilization such as understanding several languages ​​including Arabic.

DOC.Title: Louis XV
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranking from 1226 to 70). We have centralized domestic centralization and led the 6th and 7th Crusade.

DOC.Title: The 6th Crusade
DOC.TEXT: At the initiative of Louis IX attacked Egypt on the sea route, it was lost.

DOC.Title: The 7th Crusade
DOC.TEXT: Louis IX attacked Tunis along the strait. In the epidemic of the epidemic, the king also died and it was destroyed, which became the last Crusader movement.

DOC.Title: Ackon
DOC.TEXT: Port city on the coast of Syria. After the fall of Jerusalem in 1187, it became the last base of Jerusalem soil country, but it fell in 1291.

DOC.Title: Religious Order
DOC.TEXT: Organized by the monastic knight who combined the role of the knight and monk for the crusader to protect the sacred place.

DOC.Title: John Knights
DOC.TEXT: It was established in the 1st Crusade, and until 1187 he was active in Jerusalem for rescuing victims. After that, moved to Cyprus, Rhodes and the main base, it was also called Maltese Order because it was transferred from Malta Island from Carl V in 1530 and moved. He played an active part in the Lepanto war.

DOC.Title: Knights Templar
DOC.TEXT: It was founded in 1119 with the aim of protecting pilgrims and defending the tomb. It got enriched by many donations and expanded branches to the whole of Europe, but it was repressed by Philip IV of France who aimed at the wealth, then it was broken up in 1312.

DOC.Title: German Knights
DOC.TEXT: Established in Acu, 11th at the Third Crusade, moved to the southeast side of the Baltic Sea due to the Crusaders' warfare in the 13th century, and established a vast German Knights Association.

DOC.Title: Medieval city
DOC.TEXT: A city developed from the 10th to the 12th century. With the commercial activity becoming active, the money economy developed and a city was born. These cities gained the autonomy right from the feudal rulers with the strength, autonomous city was born.

DOC.Title: Diffusion of money economy
DOC.TEXT: An increase in agricultural production brought surplus goods to various places, and when that exchange developed in order of irregular city → regular city → fixed store, the physical economy gradually shifted to the monetary economy. This trend was further promoted mainly by the city of Southern Europe due to the crusade movement where a lot of people and things moved. The development of trade and commerce, centered on money, led the collapse of self-sufficient natural economy.

DOC.Title: remote commercial commerce
DOC.TEXT: Trade made between long distances such as trade between the northern Italian cities and the Islamic commercial area on the east coast of the Mediterranean and the North Sea and the Baltic Sea trade which became irreplaceable since the end of the Middle Ages. It has been one of the reasons to encourage the development of commercial and urban and monetary economies and to collapse the self-sufficiency agriculture-centric feudal feudal society.

DOC.Title: Toho Trade, Levant Trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade between northern Italian cities and the Levant (Eastern Mediterranean) region. Particularly imported since the Crusades, imports of spices (pepper etc.) from South Asia by northern Italian cities were mainly.

DOC.Title: North Sea · Baltic Sea Trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade between northern European countries and cities using the North Sea and the Baltic Sea. Hamburg · Lübeck · Bremen in North Germany, Gun · Brugge in Flanders and London in England formed the Northern European Commercial Area and trade mainly the necessities of daily necessities such as marine products, cereals, wood and woolen fabrics and prosperous .

DOC.Title: Resurrection of Commerce, Commercial Renaissance
DOC.TEXT: The eastward trade and the North Sea-Baltic trade became comprehensive during the 11th to the 12th century, and commercial activity was revitalized.

DOC.Title: Bishopric city
DOC.TEXT: A city in which a church under jurisdiction of the bishop, a Catholic high priest, was placed. It began to be built from the end of the Roman Empire.

DOC.Title: Regular Market
DOC.TEXT: A city that came to be regularly opened in various places for surplus production, brought about by the increase in agricultural productivity from the 11th to the 12th century, to exchange it. It was developed further in connection with remote commercialization, leading to the formation of a medieval city.

DOC.Title: Patent state
DOC.TEXT: Document that the feudal ruler of the king and lords allowed delegation / abandonment of its own power to the city. The city acquired this by acquisition / struggle. The main contents are market rights, money casting right, residence rights, trade rights, autonomy right etc.

DOC.Title: Autonomy right
DOC.TEXT: The privilege that the city acquired from the feudal ruler, centered around the 11th to 12th centuries. Acquiring this, the city completed the legal independence from the lord.

DOC.Title: Commune movement
DOC.TEXT: Movement aiming at the formation of a city (autonomous city) that was dominant by powerful people in the city and was independent from the rule of the lord.

DOC.Title: Autonomous City
DOC.TEXT: A city where the city was issued a patent from the king and lords, centered around the 11th-12th century, the autonomy was acquired by acquiring various autonomy rights and the city succeeded. Thereafter, many castle walls were built around to avoid intervention from lords etc.

DOC.Title: Comune, Autonomous City, Urban Republic
DOC.TEXT: Mainly autonomous city established in northern and central Italy since the 12th century. Aristocrats and large merchants led and gained autonomy right from the lord, and it was established. Municipal administration was administered by the citizen himself, and surrounding rural areas also formed the urban republic in addition to the area.

DOC.Title: Imperial City, Free City
DOC.TEXT: It is an autonomous city established in Germany mainly since the 14th century. It was established after a powerful city was granted autonomy right from the emperor. It was reported to the emperor, recognized as the same position as the princes (regional lord), originally called the imperial city, but as civil autonomy strengthened it came to be called a free city.

DOC.Title: "Air in the city is made free"
DOC.TEXT: German proverbs born in the middle of the middle of the middle of the city's development. If serfs fled to the city for a certain period of time (usually one year and one day) and continue to live, they were supposed to be free from the status of serfs.

DOC.Title: Venice
DOC.TEXT: Harbor City facing the Adriatic Sea in Northern Italy. Early in the 13th century, after led the fourth Crusade, the East Asian trade grew and reached its peak.

DOC.Title: Genoa
DOC.TEXT: Northern Italy Harbor City on the Mediterranean coast. It emerged in eastern trade and developed as a rival in Venice.

DOC.Title: Pisa
DOC.TEXT: Harbor City of the Central Italian West Coast. Since the 10th century saw prosperity in eastern trade.
