DOC.Title: Milan
DOC.TEXT: Northern Italy, the center of the Lombardy region, prosperous in relay trade with the north of the Alps.

DOC.Title: Florence
DOC.TEXT: Central Italy, the central city of the Tuscan plain. Prospered in woolen textile production and trade and finance industry. In the thirteenth century, the emerging civic forces emerged as republics, but in the 15th century it became the center of the Renaissance under the Medici dictatorship.

DOC.Title: Marseille
DOC.TEXT: Port city in southern France. Origin of Greek colonial city Massillia. Since the Crusades, it thrived in eastern trade.

DOC.Title: Lübeck
DOC.TEXT: Port city on the Baltic coast of Germany. Since the 12th century Duchy of Saxony was established, it will be the center of the Baltic Sea and North Sea trade. After that it became the ally of the Hanseatic League.

DOC.Title: Hamburg
DOC.TEXT: In the harbor city of the Elbe estuary, the center of Hokkai trade and Hanseatic alliance.

DOC.Title: Bremen
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city downstream of the Wesel. The center of the Hanseatic League.

DOC.Title: Novogorod
DOC.TEXT: Located on a trade route connecting the Black Sea and the Baltic Sea, it is a city of Russia. City of Novgorod country.

DOC.Title: Kiev
DOC.TEXT: Located in the middle of the Dnieper River, it is a Russian city on the trade route connecting the Black Sea and the Baltic Sea. City of Kiev's principality.

DOC.Title: London
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city downstream of the Thames. From the Roman era, prosperous in Beihai trade as the political and economic center of Britain Island, won autonomy from the king at the end of the 12th century.

DOC.Title: Flanders
DOC.TEXT: Today 's Belgian region in southeastern part of Netherlands. From the 10th century the production of woolen fabrics has prosperous and prosperous.

DOC.Title: Brugge
DOC.TEXT: Cities in the North Sea coast of Flanders. Prospered in the woolen textile industry. It became a member of the Hanseatic League. Since the 15th century the centers of prosperity moved to Antwerpen (Antwerp).

DOC.Title: cancer
DOC.TEXT: A city that flourished in Flanders' woolen textile industry.

DOC.Title: Champagne region
DOC.TEXT: State in southeast of Paris. Located in the middle of the Mediterranean and North Sea commercial areas, the regular city has been opened in turn in the 12th-13th century, 4 cities a year (6) times, known as the regular city of Champagne. It declined since the 14th century.

DOC.Title: Lyon
DOC.TEXT: Center of the Rhone valley. Prosperous in the inter-Korean relay trade and silk fabric production.

DOC.Title: Nuremberg
DOC.TEXT: It was a city in southern Germany, prospered as the center of commerce and craftsmanship.

DOC.Title: Augsburg
DOC.TEXT: It is a city in southern Germany, the center of trade and mining industry in this region. It is known for the rise of Fuggers in the late 15th century.

DOC.Title: City Alliance
DOC.TEXT: A medieval city with a small population and a small scale, even though it is independent, was an alliance formed to combat the oppression of emperors, kings, and princes. The nature of the military alliance was strong.

DOC.Title: Lombardia Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Cities such as Northern Italy and Milan of the Lombardy Plain were formed in opposition to the south of Holy Roman Emperor (Friedrich I). It broke the emperor army in 1176 and confirmed the autonomy right. Even after opposing Friedrich II then he was formed.

DOC.Title: Hansa Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Hansa means "merchant's companion". Developed from the latter half of the 13th century with Lübeck as the leader, took the form of city alliance clearly in 1358. Member cities over 100, decided a common currency, metrology and trading law, maintained the navy and army, and oppressed the North Sea and the Baltic Sea against the king and the princes. However, since the sovereign state system began to be established, it declined gradually from the 16th century, and in the beginning of the 17th century, it lost almost its substance.

DOC.Title: Guild
DOC.TEXT: The same association of merchants and craftsmen in medieval cities. An exclusive organization that negotiates entry into the same business other than the signatory by negotiating the manufacturing method, quality, price etc.

DOC.Title: Merchant Guild
DOC.TEXT: It was established in each city from around the 11th century and monopolized the market between mutual aid and members. In the self-governing autonomous city, the subject of municipal administration after the 13th century was primarily the owner of the merchant guild.

DOC.Title: same guild guild, tsuntoft
DOC.TEXT: Association of craftsmen in the same industry. It fought against the merchant guild. Have strict rules such as apprenticeship system.

DOC.Title: Master
DOC.TEXT: He was an independent handicraft worker and was a regular member of the same guild, joined municipal administration. We kept absolute authority on tech and personality as well as guidance and management for umbrella craftsmen and apprentices. The tendency to hire the adoption of new technology strongly, the guild became to hinder the advancement of technology, and the development of the new technology later became the basis of rural areas where weak guild regulation is the foundation.

DOC.Title: craftsman
DOC.TEXT: A paid technician working in the master workplace. As the accreditation became more difficult as a parent, in the 14th-15th century, the confrontation with the birthplace was deepened and occasionally a revolt occurred.

DOC.Title: Apprentice
DOC.TEXT: Apprentice 's unpaid apprenticeship. It is normal for 2 to 7 years in the age. After that, it became a craftsman.

DOC.Title: Tussle struggle
DOC.TEXT: Since the middle of the 13th century, the fight that Zunghut (same guild) occurred ahead (the first half of the 12th century) against the merchant guild who had monopolized municipal administration. Succeeding in this fight, Tsuntto also decided to participate in municipal administration.

DOC.Title: Jewish persecution
DOC.TEXT: The Jews who gave Judaism were discriminated from persecution by Christians through the Middle Ages. In Europe, because land ownership was often not accepted, it was often subjected to hatred for commercial and moneylending business. Persecution varied in timing and extent depending on the region, but generally increased after the crusade movement.

DOC.Title: Ghetto
DOC.TEXT: Jewish quarantine settlements in cities of medieval Germany and Eastern Europe. Resident conditions were poor, typical of discrimination and persecution for Jews.

DOC.Title: Delivery of Lateran Council, 4th Laterano Council Death
DOC.TEXT: At the largest religious council held in the Middle Ages, discriminatory treatment against Jews (fellows) was decided, along with reforms of the Church. As the marriage and manor management with Christians was banned, the Jews headed to the financial industry and became subjects of increasingly hated Christians.

DOC.Title: Marano
DOC.TEXT: A derogatory name for converts from Jews in Spain or from Judaism to Catholic, meaning "pig". Along with the land recovery movement, persecution against Jewish as well as Muslims became intense in Spain.

DOC.Title: Medici family
DOC.TEXT: Florence's big financial and large merchants. Taking charge of municipal administration in the first half of the 15th century We strove to acquire wealth and protect literature, became the center of the Renaissance. Later ones from the family appeared became pope and queen.

DOC.Title: Hugger family
DOC.TEXT: Europe's largest financial company based in Augsburg. In the fifteenth century Italy we made goods with fragrance and wool trading, and at the end of the 15th century we monopolized the silver mine in southern Germany. Early in the 16th century, with its wealth, it had a strong influence on the emperor and the pope, but it went down in the second half of the 16th century.

DOC.Title: Catharism
DOC.TEXT: Christian heresy that was influenced by Maniacism and spread to Western Europe from the 11th-13th century.

DOC.Title: Albicillian school
DOC.TEXT: In the 12th-13th century, a Catharic heresy spread in the Albi region of southern France. Although it was supported by rural nobility, it was attacked by the Albidgeva Crusader of the king side in 1209-29 and it was eradicated.

DOC.Title: Boniface VIII
DOC.TEXT: Pope the Pope (ranking from 1294 to 1303). Fighting with the French king Philippe IV on the taxation problem of clergy, he was captured temporarily by Annani in 1303 and was indignantly killed.

DOC.Title: Philippe IV
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranked from 1285 to 1314). He tried to consolidate, confronted the Pope with the intention of taxing clergy. In 1302, the three parties were convened for the first time, 1303 broke the pope in the case of Anani, 1309, punished the pope 's relocation of Avignon.

DOC.Title: Anarchy case
DOC.TEXT: Case that Pope Bonifatius VII was murdered and indignated due to humiliation that it was captured by Philippe IV of France to Anni in the vicinity of Rome. It was the beginning of the fall of papal authority.

DOC.Title: Avignon
DOC.TEXT: Cities in southeastern France. In 1309, Philip IV forced Pope Clements V to relocate here. After that the Pope was placed under the supervision of King French.

DOC.Title: Clemens V
DOC.TEXT: Pope the Pope (rank 1305-14). In 1309, I was relocated to Avignon.

DOC.Title: "Papal Babylon Captivity"
DOC.TEXT: That the Pope was relocated to Avignon under pressure of French royalty for seventh 69 years. A way of calling to the story of ancient Jewish Babylonian captors.

DOC.Title: Church division, large cisma
DOC.TEXT: To the pope of Avignon under French rule, the emperor of Germany and the King of England asserted legitimacy when he embarked upon the Pope in Rome, the division of the center of the church. This lost the authority of the Pope, but then reunified at the Council of Constance.

DOC.Title: Wickliffe
DOC.TEXT: A pioneer of the British religious reform. Oxford University Theological Professor. In honor of the respect of the Bible, we have translated the Bible into English and criticized the Pope and the Church system.

DOC.Title: Council of Constance, Konstantz public religious conference
DOC.TEXT: Council opened for dissolution of church division. It was held with German emperor Sigismund, advocated Husu as a heresy, banished the three papers, elected a new pope, and finished the great division of the church.

DOC.Title: Fus
DOC.TEXT: A pioneer of the Czech religious reform. University of Prague Professor of Theology. Resonant to Wycliffe to fulfill the reform of the Catholic Church, and to guide the checkers' ethnic movements. It was summoned by the Council of Constance and its theory was regarded as heresy and was burned down.

DOC.Title: Huss War
DOC.TEXT: After the execution of Bush, the war that Hussi Bommen resident (Huchetin) protested against the pressure of the Pope, Emperor. Although the Pope and the Emperor organized the Husband Crusaders, they failed, defeated the extremists (Tabor school) in partnership with the moderate Hussean, and the sum was approved.

DOC.Title: "Crisis of feudalism system"
DOC.TEXT: In the 14th-15th century, the feudal system has gone. The development of the monetary economy, warfare and black-and-death epidemic, frequent occurrence of illegal farmers, progress of agricultural liberation, etc., overlapped, the manor system was transformed and collapsed, and the lord who supported the feudal system, mainly, became poor It almost finished its role. After that, it will shift to a new social system centered on the king.

DOC.Title: Serf liberation
DOC.TEXT: In the trend that the rent is shifting from the labor to the product rent / money rent, the serfs are released from their status. Specifically, in Western Europe, it was released from feudal bondage such as lord jurisdiction, death tax, marriage tax, in the 13th-16th centuries.

DOC.Title: Product Rent
DOC.TEXT: The rent to be delivered as a harvest from the possession. In many cases, it was coexistent with the labor age, but in this case there was a serious agency because it was a fixed rate rent, work motivation and productivity were high. It became almost popular in France in the 13th century, in the UK in the first half of the 14th century.

DOC.Title: Diffusion of money economy
DOC.TEXT: Money economy gradually spread through the occurrence of surplus goods due to the increase in agricultural production, the development of commercial and urban areas, and the development of remote area by crusade movement.

DOC.Title: Money rent
DOC.TEXT: The rent that spread in the latter half of the Middle Ages by money. In the background, there was development of commercial and monetary economy. As a result of the dissemination of this monetary rent, the rent (manor) manor without a charge also spread in the manor system, the dominant power to the sericulture of the lord class weakened, leading to the liberation of agriculture and the collapse of the manor system.

DOC.Title: Black death disease, best
DOC.TEXT: Especially 1346-50 years, epidemic in Western Europe, plague that many died (there is also the theory that it is about one-third of Western European population). Italian merchants arrived from the port of Italy and France, in the eastern region, 48 years was at the height of the year. As a result, the agricultural population drastically decreased, making it difficult for the lords to be operated in a directly-managed place, which triggered dismantlement of feudal society.

DOC.Title: Independent self-employed farmer, Yeoman
DOC.TEXT: From the mid-14th century, farmers who are out of agriculture. It is an independent small producer who plows its holdings mainly by family labor and pays a small rent, but it was almost free of status.

DOC.Title: Gentry
DOC.TEXT: A commoner but abundant landowner, with the aristocrat forming the British ruling class. In the rural capacity group, the ranking owner confronted the royal powers by securing and expanding its own territory, whereas he served unpaid by the municipal officials and other local administrative officials and supported the extension of the kingship.

DOC.Title: Constellation Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The lordship that is going to be poverty due to the progress of the monetary economy is to reinforce the control and exploitation of autonomous farmers and to try to go against the old days of feudal rule. It became a cause of peasant rebellion frequent occurrence.

DOC.Title: Farmer's riot
DOC.TEXT: It is also called farmers 'rebellion or farmers' war. A large rebellion of the farmers' layer over the feudal reaction of the lord. In the 14th and 15th centuries in England and France, in the 15th and 16th centuries in Germany it departs. In Britain and France, the King and Lord Army was crushed and the mastermind was executed, but the lord side also conceded, preventing the recurrence, the farmers' demands were also frequented, and its liberalization advanced.

DOC.Title: Jackley's Random
DOC.TEXT: Northern French peasants rebellion. The defeat of the early 100-year war and the imposition of a heavy tax are the direct cause. Leader Guillaume = curl. It was thoroughly suppressed by the king and the army army. Jack is a derogatory name for farmers.

DOC.Title: Watt = Tyler's Random
DOC.TEXT: British peasant revolt guided by Tyler and others. Citizens of London also joined, promised the King to abolish the serfdom, but fooled, Tyler was killed and crushed. Following this rebellion, the liberation of farmers (farmers) has advanced and yeoman has increased sharply.

DOC.Title: John = Ball
DOC.TEXT: Wat Tyler's ideological leader of turbulence. A lower clergy from a farmer who consecrated the Wickliff theory.

DOC.Title: "Who was a nobleman when Adam plowed Eve spun?"
DOC.TEXT: When Watts = Tyler's turbulence, the words John = Ball met. He severely criticized the status system of feudal society.

DOC.Title: Changing tactics
DOC.TEXT: Changes in the fighting ways caused by spread of active infantry and the use of firearms in the late Middle Ages. As a result, the battlefield advanced the fall of the knight class, which was primarily a horsemen.

DOC.Title: Courtier
DOC.TEXT: Bureaucrats working at the court of the king. In the latter half of the Middle Ages, small and medium-sized lords and knights lost autonomy economically and militarily by changes in manor management and tactics, became a local landlord (gentry) that would only be a courtier or settled the rent from farmers.

DOC.Title: Firearms, Firearms
DOC.TEXT: A cannon in the 14th century, a rifle in the late 15th century emerged, became the main weapon beyond the bow and arrow spears, collective fighting of agricultural soldiers became generalized.

DOC.Title: Mercenary
DOC.TEXT: A soldier hired by money. The role of the infantry who used the firearm on behalf of the knight became bigger and its use widespread due to the tactical change in the late Middle Ages.

DOC.Title: Norman morning
DOC.TEXT: Conquest dynasty established by Norman conquest. The feudal system was established in this era, but the royalty is powerful when compared with the continental countries, few large lords compete with the royalty. King was King of England, but in the territory of France he was a vassal of King French.

DOC.Title: William I
DOC.TEXT: Public Normandy, Norman King's First King of Kingdom (ranking 1066-87). I made the first notch in the UK (Doom's Day = Book).

DOC.Title: Arm of Anjou
DOC.TEXT: A large aristocrat defining the Anjou region in the southwestern part of France. Although he was a vassal of King French, he later entered the UK and began the Planet Ginnet morning.

DOC.Title: Plantaginet Morning
DOC.TEXT: With the break of the Norman morning, Henry of Anjou began as King Henry II of England. For the British territory was the king equal to the King of France, and Anjou was the keeper of the King of France, which caused complications and conflicts of British-French relations.

DOC.Title: Henry II
DOC.TEXT: Count of Egypt and Planet Ginetto King of the Early King (ranking from 1154 to 89). British feudal monarchy reached its peak. It is also known to assassinate Archbishop Canterbury.

DOC.Title: King John
DOC.TEXT: British King (ranking from 1199 to 1216). Missed king. A child of Henry II. He lost consecutive defeats against France and lost the continental territory. In the issue of appointing and canceling Archbishop Canterbury there was excommunication from Pope Innocentius III and he surrendered. The aristocrat was attacked by tyrann and was signed by the Great Charter.

DOC.Title: Archbishop of Canterbury
DOC.TEXT: Priesthood was the highest ranking of British Catholic church until religious reform in the 16th century. In 1209, King British King John was excommunicated in opposition to Pope Innocentius III over this appointment and dismissal, and finally excommunication was made by making the whole of Britain 1213 as the papal territory.

DOC.Title: Large Charter, Magna = Carta
DOC.TEXT: The nobility united and let the king acknowledge against John 's misunderstanding. Article 63. In addition to requiring aristocratic consent to taxation, it clearly stipulated control over the law, became the beginning of the British Constitution.

DOC.Title: Henri III
DOC.TEXT: The firstborn of John King of England (ranking from 1216 to 72). Ignoring heavy taxes and ignoring the large charter, they arrested the nobility and subdued.

DOC.Title: Simon-de-Montfort
DOC.TEXT: French-style nobility. The rebellion in 1258 against the tyranny of Henri III was made, and in 1265 the state knight and the citizen delegation joined the advisory council to let the king acknowledge.

DOC.Title: Origin of British Parliament
DOC.TEXT: In 1265, the Congress was composed of clergy and aristocrats and state and city representatives. In the mid-14th century a bicameral system was established.

DOC.Title: Edward I
DOC.TEXT: British King (ranking from 1272 to 1307). A model parliament was held in 1295.

DOC.Title: Example parliament
DOC.TEXT: In addition to priests and aristocrats, a status system consisting of two knights in each state and two citizens in each city.

DOC.Title: Bicameral System Council
DOC.TEXT: The parliament consisting of the House of Lords (Senate) and the House of Commons (House of Representatives). It was founded in the middle of the 14th century.

DOC.Title: Senate, aristocrat
DOC.TEXT: It consisted of high priests and large aristocrats.

DOC.Title: House, House of Commons
DOC.TEXT: It consisted of state knights and representatives of privileged cities.

DOC.Title: Identity Council
DOC.TEXT: Since the end of the Middle Ages, an advisory body of the king composed of clergy and aristocrat representatives plus new citizen representatives. Having the right to examine the taxation, he restrained the royalty from the financial aspect. In the early days the king and the citizens cooperated in many cases, but later became a place of confrontation. Starting with the British model parliament, it was established in various countries including the 14th century French trio, the German imperial parliament, the German parliament, the 16th century Spanish Cortez.

DOC.Title: Capoe morning
DOC.TEXT: Elegy of Paris Hugue-Capete began by the French dynasty. In the early days the power of the princes was strong, but the successive kings joined the Catholic, steadily expanded the kingship, became a powerful country to the Holy Roman Empire at the end of the 12th century. The capital is Paris.

DOC.Title: Philippe II
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranking 1180-1223). He tried to consolidate, and struggled with the feudal master and extended the kingship. Participated in the Third Crusade. The British king robbed the British territory within the continent.

DOC.Title: Louis XV
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranking from 1226 to 70). Holy king. Succeeded in the Albjorge Crusade and expanded the kingship to South France as well. We dispatch Rubruk to Mongolia. The sixth and the seventh crusade happened, but it was sick in Tunis of North Africa.

DOC.Title: Philippe IV
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranked from 1285 to 1314). We tried to centralize centralization. We convened the three parties for the first time, defeated Pope Bonifatius VIII and transferred the Papacy to Avignon, France. In addition, it disseminated the Knights Templar, took away huge wealth and helped strengthen the royal power.

DOC.Title: "King's miracle"
DOC.TEXT: Ability to do miracles believed to be in the king. In the late medieval period, in France and the UK, the King admired the "divinity of the king" and used it to strengthen the kingship, when there is the ability to do miracles such as the healing power of the sweet (swelling).

DOC.Title: Three Parties
DOC.TEXT: A French status society established by Philip IV. We convened clerics, nobles and citizen representatives and gained cooperation in preparation for a dispute with Pope Boniface IX. It was dissolved in 1615, but it was resumed in 1789, and it became the beginning of the French Revolution.

DOC.Title: Valowa Morning
DOC.TEXT: The French dynasty established in the morning of the cape morning.

DOC.Title: Philip VI
DOC.TEXT: King of the Valois first generation (ranking 1328-50).

DOC.Title: Edward III
DOC.TEXT: British king (ranked 1327-77). My mother is the daughter of Philip IV of France. He insisted on the throne succession right in the morning of the cape morning and caused a centennial war.

DOC.Title: Flanders region
DOC.TEXT: Present Belgian province. The production of woolen fabrics has become an object of competition between Britain and France, and it was the main factor in the economic aspect of the centennial war.

DOC.Title: Guyenne, Gienne
DOC.TEXT: It is the French principality between the Pyrenees and the Loire, the central city is Bordeaux. Kingdom of the United Kingdom from the 12th century. It became a place of conflict between the two countries, and it contributed to the war of the centennial.

DOC.Title: Duke Burgundy, Duke Burgundy
DOC.TEXT: The great princes of France. During the centennial war, I joined the UK and forced France to be inferior temporarily.

DOC.Title: 100 Year War
DOC.TEXT: King Edward III of the Kingdom of England was born from his mother, claimed the right to succeed to the throne during the cape disconnection, fought against France and waged the game. Although the British army continued the dominance, the French army won the end at the end of the epidemic of black death disease, peasant rebellion and the like. In both England and France, the decline of the lord and knight class, farmers' liberation, development of civic classes was seen, and the centralization by the king was encouraged.

DOC.Title: Battle of Cresi
DOC.TEXT: Battle where British army led by Edward III won the French army. The activity of the long arm of the British side was remarkable.

DOC.Title: Battle of Poitiers
DOC.TEXT: Battle where the British army led by Edward Kuroto won the French army. King French King Jean II was caught.

DOC.Title: Edward Black Prince
DOC.TEXT: Firstborn of Edward III. It was considered brave as a chivalrous man, but it was harsh for the people.

DOC.Title: Orléans
DOC.TEXT: A small city in central France. It is famous for being released from the siege of England by the French army led by Jeanne-d'Arc during the centennial war.

DOC.Title: Charles VII
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranking 1422-61). On the verge of losing and defeating Orleans, Jeanne d'Arc has rebounded its defeat in 1429. After World War II promoted reconstruction and centralization.

DOC.Title: Jeanne-d'Arc
DOC.TEXT: Daughter of peasants of East France, Don Rumi. In 1928 he entered Orleans as receiving a remark of God, inspired Charles (later Charles VII of the King), repelling the British army which surrounded Orleans by himself. After that the French side recovered its dominance and eventually won the hundred year war, but Jeanne d'Alc himself was caught by the Burgundy school (at the time, conflicted with the king), then handed over to the British army, He was burned in Rouen as a person.

DOC.Title: Curry
DOC.TEXT: Port city on the north coast of France. Britain surrounded and occupied in the battle of Cresy, became the only land possessed by the continent even after the end of the war. An anecdote that was escaped from destruction by the heroic act of the citizen when the town was surrounded is famous.

DOC.Title: Jack = cool
DOC.TEXT: A large merchant, Treasurer of Charles VII. I tried to rectify the fiscal situation.

DOC.Title: Charles VIII
DOC.TEXT: French King (ranking 1483-98). It crushed the rebellion of aristocrats connecting with the UK and achieved centralization. From 1494 to 1995, I made an expedition to Italy.

DOC.Title: rose war
DOC.TEXT: The civil war over the succession of the throne in England. Many aristocrats were divided into both Lancaster and York, and fought fiercely, exhausted, self-destruction. The result was that the Tudor family who was a neighbor of the Lancaster family won, opened the Tudor morning, and promoted centralization.

DOC.Title: Lancaster Family
DOC.TEXT: The royal family of England (1399-1461). Planta Ginet inherits the strain of the morning.

DOC.Title: York House
DOC.TEXT: The royal family of England (1461-85). Edward IV is the first throne during the rose war. The next Edward V was abolished by my uncle Richard III, and Richard was overthrown by Henri VII and it ended.

DOC.Title: Henry VII
DOC.TEXT: British King (ranking 1485-1509). In the Lancaster family, married to the daughter of Edward IV, opened the Tudor morning. After that, it succeeded in centralization.

DOC.Title: Morning Tudor
DOC.TEXT: Five generations from Henry VII to Elizabeth I. Britain 's absolute monarchy was established.

DOC.Title: Stars Office Court
DOC.TEXT: Founded in the era of 1487 Henry VII, the Special Court directly under the King. It was installed between the stars of Westminster Palace. Punished aristocrats against the kingship, helped to establish absolute kingship.

DOC.Title: Italian policy
DOC.TEXT: Intervention policy to Italy that the emperor of the Holy Roman Empire of successive times. On the other hand it caused the emergence of the large houses because it neglected German rule and hindered the centralization (German unification).

DOC.Title: Land
DOC.TEXT: It is a feudal small country that was in Germany from the late Middle Ages to the modern era. In the 13th-14th centuries, each of the 300 national territories continued to have diplomatic rights and money casting rights, while Germany was called the Holy Roman Empire, it was in a completely split state.

DOC.Title: Oriental colony
DOC.TEXT: A colony to the Slavic settlement in the east of the Elbe River carried out by German princes from the 12th to the 14th century. Pushed forward a colonist with a strong military character.

DOC.Title: Cistercian Order
DOC.TEXT: He worked with Oriental colony with the Knights of Germany etc.

DOC.Title: Brandenburg Frontier Era
DOC.TEXT: In the 12th century, the emperor of Holy Roman Empire formed the tomb of the Oriental colony. In the 15th century Hohenzollern became a family.

DOC.Title: German Knights
DOC.TEXT: During the crusade movement in 1190, the Order for the sacred place guardian founded in Ackon on the east coast of the Mediterranean. After the end of the crusade, I participated in the Oriental colony, pioneered the Baltic coast, formed the German Knights Organization, and built the foundation of the Prussian Duchy after.

DOC.Title: Staufen morning
DOC.TEXT: The era of Friedrich I (ranking 1152 to 90) was at its peak, but domestic was confused and the empire was declining because it was biased towards Italian policy.

DOC.Title: Friedrich I
DOC.TEXT: Holy Roman emperor (ranking from 1152 to 90). We tried to strengthen the rule of the empire, succeeded in the integration of Italy temporarily. In 1176, it was defeated by being defeated by the Lombardier alliance army. On the way to participation in the Third Crusade, I drowned in Asia Minor.

DOC.Title: Friedrich II
DOC.TEXT: Holy Roman emperor (ranking 1215-50), but rather stayed in Italy (Sicily) for a long time. It widely granted privileges to the German cities and cities, and as a result promoted the formation of the national state. He led the fifth Crusade and succeeded temporarily.

DOC.Title: Age of Great Dimensions
DOC.TEXT: After the break in the morning of Staufen, "Emperor" was made easy for the Count of the Netherlands and Britain · France, but in fact it was a no emperor era. Until the emergence of the Habsburg morning, the weakening of the Holy Roman Emperor (German King) right continued.

DOC.Title: Carl IV
DOC.TEXT: Emperor of Holy Roman Emperor of the Luxembourg morning (rulers 1347-78). He issued the Kim's Imperial Book and realized the return of the Pope during the captivity of Avignon (1377). In addition, he also contributed to the development of the Czech culture, such as building the oldest Prague university in Eastern Europe, also serving as King Baren Carel (dwelling 1346-78).

DOC.Title: Kim's Imperial Statement, Golden Document
DOC.TEXT: An edict that approved that the electorate of seven elected to elect the emperor. It legally confirmed the dominance of the ruler and the church for the emperor and the pope, which caused the German division.

DOC.Title: elected chief
DOC.TEXT: Seven saints and princes who got the right to elect emperor. Four Archbishop of Mainz, Trail, Cologne, King Bamen, Earl of Brandenburg, Prince Sachsen, Earl of Faltz. Since 17th century the number and members changed.

DOC.Title: Habsburg House
DOC.TEXT: The Austrian royal family. Between 1273 and 1308, between 1438 and 1806, the prestigious Europe of the Holy Roman Emperor. In the 15th century Hapsburg morning I took self-dominant management first principle, so I could not prevent division of the German region and autonomy of the princes.

DOC.Title: Swiss independence
DOC.TEXT: For the rule of the Habsburg family since the 13th century, three states initially started independent conflicts, mainly in farmers and citizens in 1291, and the autonomy was recognized in 1316. Earned independence of 13 states at the Basel conference in late 15th century. In 1648 the Westphalia Treaty was approved internationally internationally.

DOC.Title: Both Sicilian kingdoms
DOC.TEXT: Formally, the name of the kingdom combined the kingdom of Sicily with the kingdom of Naples in the southern part of the Italian peninsula. Conventionally, the Sicilian kingdom built by Norman Ruggero II in 1130 is called the first Sicilian kingdom. In the heyday of the 12th century, it also owned the southern half of the peninsula, and in the capital city Palermo deepened the exchange of Norman culture, Islam culture, Byzantine culture, high cultures were created among them. Separated into the Kingdom of Sicily and the Kingdom of Naples at the end of the 13th century, the Kingdom of Sicily (Aragonese royal family) annexed the Kingdom of Naples in the mid-15th century, the names of the two Sicilian kingdoms revived. Although it will also divide afterwards, it was officially unified at the beginning of the 19th century, called the two Sicilian kingdoms, and was merged into Sardinia in 1860.

DOC.Title: "Sicilian night bell"
DOC.TEXT: In 1282, anti-French (Anjou family) great revolt that the nobility of Sicily made mainly of Palermo. Thousands of French people were killed and the two Sicilian kingdoms were separated into the Kingdom of Sicily and the Kingdom of Naples.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Sicily
DOC.TEXT: As a result of the revolt in 1282, Sicily became the army of King Aragon. It merged with the Kingdom of Naples in the 15th century and became both Kingdom of Sicily, but it was annexed to Spain early in the 16th century. After that, the territorial dispute between Spain and France continued (temporarily became Austrian territory in the 18th century), and reunified with the Kingdom of Naples under the Bourbon family in 1816, forming the Kingdom of both Sicily.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Naples
DOC.TEXT: As the result of the revolt in 1282, the French line (Anjou family) built the kingdom. Although there was a time when it was integrated with the Kingdom of Sicily (Aragon royal family), the territorial dispute between Spain and France continued (temporarily became Austrian territory in the 18th century), it was reunified with the Kingdom of Sicily in 1816 , Formed both Kingdom of Sicily.

DOC.Title: Holy Spirit
DOC.TEXT: The territory dominated by the papacy. Beginning with the dragon of Pippin in 756, in the era of Gregorus VII and Innocentius III, he dominated the broad territory, mainly in Central Italy. After that, the territory was shrunk in the era of the French Revolution and Napoleonic, followed by Italian unification, and today it is limited to the Vatican City in Rome.

DOC.Title: Urban Republic
DOC.TEXT: The autonomous city formed a wide area of ​​surroundings together. It was established in the weak Italian lord of Italy since the 12th century. Venice, Florence, Genoa, Milan etc. are representative.

DOC.Title: Venezia Republic
DOC.TEXT: The port city that prospered by the eastern trade. After the 4th Crusade, it prospered until the early 16th century as an urban territory with colonies in various parts of the eastern Mediterranean.

DOC.Title: "Queen of the Adriatic Sea"
DOC.TEXT: Around the 13 th to 15 th century, it is a designation that fights prosperity of Venice.

DOC.Title: Republic of Genoa
DOC.TEXT: One of the city republics. The 12 th-13 th century prosperity. In the 13th-14th century vengeance and maritime rights fought and defeated, declined.

DOC.Title: Florence Republic
DOC.TEXT: A metropolitan state of the Tuscan plain. It was the most prosperous in the 14th-15th century in the woolen production, trade and finance industry, became the center of the Italian-Renaissance.

DOC.Title: Principality of Milan
DOC.TEXT: From the beginning of the 14th century until the middle of the 15th century Visconti family exclusively ruled.

DOC.Title: Papal Party, Gelf
DOC.TEXT: Papal supporters in Italy in German emperor and papal conflict after the 12th century. There were many large merchants in the city.

DOC.Title: Emperor's party, Gibberin
DOC.TEXT: Emperor 's supporters in Italy in the German emperor and papal conflict after the 12th century. There were many aristocrats and lords.

DOC.Title: National Recovery Campaign, Reconquista
DOC.TEXT: An exercise that Christians tried to regain this land by driving Muslims on the Iberian Peninsula. From the eleventh century it was done from north to south by Christian nations such as Leon, Castilla, Aragon, and in 1492, it was completed by depriving Granada the last ground for Islamic side.

DOC.Title: Aragon
DOC.TEXT: The Kingdom of Christianity, founded in the 11th century. One of the center of the national land recovery movement.

DOC.Title: Castilla
DOC.TEXT: Kingdom founded in the 11th century. In the course of promoting the national land recovery movement, we occupied Cordoba in 1236. It merged with Aragon in 1479 to form the Kingdom of Spain.

DOC.Title: Fernando V
DOC.TEXT: King Aragon Fernando II. Married Isabel in 1469. Merger with Castilla in 1979, became King of Spain (rank 1479-1516).

DOC.Title: Isabel, Isabella
DOC.TEXT: In marriage with Fernando in 1469, became Queen Castilla in 1974, and co-governed the Kingdom of Spain after the Federation in 1979. Completed the restoration movement (Reconquista), displaced the Islamic forces, and assisted Columbus.

DOC.Title: Spain Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: In 1479 when the national land revival movement advanced, Aragon, a kingdom established by integrating Castilla. It was the most prosperous in the 16th century through the control of the American continent, but it began to decline from the end of the same century, expelling Islamic forces from the Iberian Peninsula.

DOC.Title: Granada
DOC.TEXT: It is the last city of the Nasr dynasty of Islam in the southern peninsula. It fell here in 1492 and the national land recovery movement was completed.

DOC.Title: Portuguese Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: It separated and independent from Castilla. As an extension of the national land revival movement, we devoted our national strength to cultivate the West Coast route of Africa.

DOC.Title: João II
DOC.TEXT: King Portugal (ranking 1481-95). It suppressed aristocratic rebellion and strengthened the kingship. Assisting the discovery of Daisu 's celebrated peak, developing the Oriental Passage, and in 1494 signed the Treaty of Tordesillas with Spain.

DOC.Title: Fin people
DOC.TEXT: Ural-Altai language system. Founder of the current Finnish people. It went northwest from the Volga watershed, and established around 700 in the present location. It was integrated into Sweden at the end of the 13th century.

DOC.Title: Margrette
DOC.TEXT: Princess Denmark, after 1387 the de facto Queen of Denmark. In 1397 he formed the Kalmar alliance and became the ruler of the three Northern European countries.

DOC.Title: Kalmar alliance
DOC.TEXT: The alliance of the three Northern Europeans formed the same alliance under the rule of the Danish royal family. Denmark "Queen" Margrette took control. Then in 1523 Sweden was solved independently. Kalmar is the town of Sweden.

DOC.Title: Denmark Union Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The allied nations of three Northern Europe that was established around Denmark by the Kalmar alliance. Sweden independence and withdrew in 1523, Norway stayed in the Union until 1814.

DOC.Title: Latin
DOC.TEXT: Daily languages ​​of the Romans. In the Middle Ages, it was used as a common academic term mainly in the Catholic Church, but its slang word was French, Spanish, Italian, etc.

DOC.Title: Hieronymus
DOC.TEXT: Priest of Antioch. Father. He wrote the Latin translation of the Bible and the Biblical commentary.

DOC.Title: Latin translation Bible
DOC.TEXT: By Hieronymus, it was translated from Greek and Hebrew originals into Latin. Known as the name of Vurgata, later became a Catholic standard Bible.

DOC.Title: University
DOC.TEXT: As a research institution attached to the church / monastery, he studied the church law and Roman law, and since the 12th-13th century it was organized and operated as guild form as a self-governing body of professors and students. Staff and students leave control of the lords, there was autonomy of the school, but there was hardly any freedom of learning or thought.

DOC.Title: Salerno University
DOC.TEXT: One of the medieval oldest universities in southern Italy. The contact with Islam is strong, renowned for medicine affected by Arabian medicine. The 12 th-13 th century is at its peak.

DOC.Title: University of Bologna
DOC.TEXT: The oldest university established in northern Italy around the end of the 11th century. Famous for law.

DOC.Title: University of Paris
DOC.TEXT: Early in the 12th century, it was promoted from the Theological Seminary attached to Notre Dame Cathedral. The king 's protection became a professor student union. In the Sorbonne in 1259 the faculty of divinity was established, until the church division period was the highest authority of theology.

DOC.Title: Oxford University
DOC.TEXT: In the latter half of the 12th century, Paris University was established as a model. In the 13th century I took a unique dormitory system. Center of British theology.

DOC.Title: University of Cambridge
DOC.TEXT: In 1209, teachers and students of Oxford University were transferred and established.

DOC.Title: Freedom 7 Department
DOC.TEXT: From the end of Rome, the general liberal arts required for free people, the lower three courses are grammar, rhetoric and dialectic law, the four upper courses are arithmetic, geometric, astronomy and music. In medieval universities, the main contents of humanities were composed and learned as basic subjects (general liberal arts subject).

DOC.Title: 3 departments
DOC.TEXT: It refers to the theology department, law school, medicine department placed in major medieval colleges. In addition, as a foundation of these, the Humanities Department (General Education Department) to learn general education was established. There is also the theory that it adds this and makes it four faculties.

DOC.Title: Theology
DOC.TEXT: In the study of Christian doctrine, faith, ethics, the center of medieval science.

DOC.Title: "Philosophy is Theology of theology"
DOC.TEXT: A proverb that shows that theology was the best learning.

DOC.Title: Scholastic philosophy, Scholasticology
DOC.TEXT: Schola means the school attached to the church. Medieval European theology and philosophy, organized by the association of Christian church doctrine with Greek philosophy (in particular Aristotle philosophy). It was particularly tasty around the 12th-15th century.

DOC.Title: Caroling = Renaissance
DOC.TEXT: Ancient cultural restoration campaign through protection and encouragement of the Carl King. From the UK Alkyne was imitated and tried to disseminate the Latin, and Roman style church building also came.

DOC.Title: Alquink
DOC.TEXT: British theologian. She was instructed by the Carl King and instructed the cultural movement of the Kingdom of Frank, including opening a school with Aachen etc.

DOC.Title: Einhart
DOC.TEXT: A scholar / historian who was active as the center of Caroling = Renaissance after Al Quin. Author of "Carl Daiei".

DOC.Title: Caroling small form
DOC.TEXT: A typeface used when creating a manuscript at a monastery. It became the source of typographic characters for today's printing.

DOC.Title: Aachen
DOC.TEXT: Cities in Western Germany. Al Qin was imitated and became the center of Caroling-Renaissance. At the end of the eighth century, a large court of Karl Empire was built.

DOC.Title: Realityism
DOC.TEXT: One theory of Scholastic philosophy. God and the idea of ​​universality are assumed to precede things. Anselm is the representative.

DOC.Title: Anselmus
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop of Canterbury, "Father of Scholasticism" is said to be. I gained realism.

DOC.Title: Nominal theory, nominal theory
DOC.TEXT: It was conflicting with realism as real things were only individual things, God or universality was only abstraction (name only). Represented by Abelal or Ockham.

DOC.Title: universal controversy
DOC.TEXT: The conflict between realism and nominism in Scholasticism. The metaphysical argument expanded to the issue of faith and reason, but Aquinas was solved once, with the introduction of Aristotelianism.

DOC.Title: Abelal
DOC.TEXT: French scholastic scholar. I insisted on a nomination theory.

DOC.Title: Thomas = Aquinas
DOC.TEXT: Scholastic scholar in Italy. We harmonized Aristotle's philosophy with Christian thought, tried to combine theology and philosophy, and formed the Scholastic philosophy.

DOC.Title: "Theological Theology"
DOC.TEXT: The main work of Thomas Aquinas. Completion of Sukura philosophy in total.

DOC.Title: Duns = Scotus
DOC.TEXT: Scholastic scholar in the UK. Separating philosophy and theology, claimed a dominance of will.

DOC.Title: William = of = Ockham
DOC.TEXT: Scholastic scholar in the UK. Taking a nominal theory, distinguishing between faith and reason, theology and philosophy. Occam is the name of the fabric.

DOC.Title: Roger-bacon
DOC.TEXT: Scholastic scholar in the UK. Attempting to systematize theology by theology, but also due to the influence of Islamic scholars, emphasizing experience, opened the way to the methodology of modern natural science.

DOC.Title: 12th century Renaissance
DOC.TEXT: It means that the medieval culture has greatly developed in the 12th century. Specifically, Scholastic philosophy became a big boat, a university was born, a heroic epic was created, a Romanesque architectural style was completed, and a Gothic architectural style was started. The background is the influx and development of the ancient Greek / Roman culture and Arabic culture through exchanges with agricultural productive capabilities, commercial development, Islamic area, which became irreplaceable from around the 12th century, and so on.

DOC.Title: Sicily Island
DOC.TEXT: The Mediterranean's largest island. Especially in the 9th and 12th centuries, Christian culture, Islamic culture, Byzantine culture, etc. were integrated mainly in Palermo, creating a high-level culture.

DOC.Title: Toledo
DOC.TEXT: Ancient capital of Spain. Many Arabic academic papers (Islamic scholarly books and Greek classics) were translated into Latin in the 12 th-13 th century, and had a major impact on the 12 th century Renaissance and the Italian Renaissance after the 14 th century.

DOC.Title: "Song of Nibelungen"
DOC.TEXT: German big hero epic completed in the 13th century. Sexuality of hero Siegfried and love and death, singing revenge of his wife Cream Hilt. The historical facts and legends of the ethnic migration period were used as materials.

DOC.Title: Chivalry Story
DOC.TEXT: A song-narrative with the theme of a knight. A flower form of medieval literature. Many singing love with the knight's martial arts.

DOC.Title: "Laurent's Song"
DOC.TEXT: A heroic epic established in northern France at the end of the 11th century. Set in the Karl Empire's vs Islam warfare, he sang a love of Knight Laurent's martial arts and friendship.

DOC.Title: "Story of King Arthur"
DOC.TEXT: A series of chivalrous story centered around the legendary hero Arthur of the Celts. Caucasian literature occurred in the Wales · Cornwall region, established around the 12th century.

DOC.Title: Bard specialist
DOC.TEXT: A common translation of France 's Tribadour and German Minninger. I mainly examined the poetry about the court and the theme of knight love affair. The twelfth century was at its height.

DOC.Title: Byzantine style
DOC.TEXT: The architectural style of the church of Byzantine empire. Consolidate the central circular to the east in the basilica. Circle roof. The walls were decorated with many mosaics.

DOC.Title: Romanesque style
DOC.TEXT: Art style developed in Western Europe from the 11th to the 12th century. In the architecture, the chapel has a stone ceiling and a semi-circular arch. There is a feeling of heaviness and magnificence. The wide wall was decorated with frescoes.

DOC.Title: Pisa Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Representative Romanesque architecture in Italy. It was erected in the 11th and 12th centuries.

DOC.Title: Worms Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Representative Romanesque architecture in Germany. It was erected in the early 12th-13th century.

DOC.Title: Cluny Abbey
DOC.TEXT: Representative Romanesque architecture remaining in France.

DOC.Title: Mainz Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Romanesque architecture in the western part of Germany.

DOC.Title: Gothic style
DOC.TEXT: The style that happened from north France in the 12th century. Because of the use of a cusp arch and a ceiling, the window got wider. It became the mainstream of church construction, which was able to be large scale, spread to all the Europe until the Renaissance period.

DOC.Title: Stained glass
DOC.TEXT: Colored glass used for Gothic window.

DOC.Title: Notre Dame Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Representative Gothic architecture in Paris. It was constructed in the 12th century and almost completed in the 13th century.

DOC.Title: Amiens Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Representative Gothic architecture in north France. It was erected in the 13th century.

DOC.Title: Cologne Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Germany's largest Gothic architecture. Construction began in the 13th-14th century and it was completed in the 19th century.

DOC.Title: Chartres Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: French representative Gothic architecture. It was erected at the end of the 12th century to the beginning of the 13th century.

DOC.Title: Canterbury Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Representative building of tonic Gothic in Southern Canterbury, London. It was erected from the end of the 12th century to the 15th century.

DOC.Title: Path of steppe
DOC.TEXT: The oldest east-west transportation street penetrating the large stepping area connecting the grassland zone of southern Russia-Kazakh meadow zone-foot of Altay mountain-Mongolian plateau. Also called step = load. It became a route in the case of Hidete, Scythian culture, his success, and invasion of Asian ethnic groups into Europe.

DOC.Title: Major horse nomads
DOC.TEXT: Nomads who seem to be Turkish · Mongolian, etc, who took on horse riding strategy and acquired combat skills. From its mobility it expanded the range of activity along the way of the grassland plays and played a major role in the exchange of East-West culture.

DOC.Title: Scythai
DOC.TEXT: Around 6 to 4 th centuries ago, a cavalry nomads presumed to be of Iranian type who dominated South Russian meadow zone. It produced a unique equestrian culture called Skito-Siberian culture and had a great influence on nomads in Central Asia.

DOC.Title: Skito = Siberian culture
DOC.TEXT: Scythian culture characterized by animal patterns and rich golden use on weapons · horses etc, was formed in South Russia · Mongolia · Siberia, and formed culture.

DOC.Title: 匈 奴
DOC.TEXT: A cavalry herd who was active in the Mongolian plateau from the end of the 4th century to the 1st century. Incorporating the Scythian cavalry culture, breaking the neighboring tribes, built the nomad nation. It split and declined since the first century.

DOC.Title: Hun people
DOC.TEXT: A cavalry nomad in the Kazakh meadow zone. It was established in the Volga river zone around the 2nd century, moved westward around the 4th century and brought about a massive movement of the Germanic people. There is a family theory with a fool.

DOC.Title: Avar person
DOC.TEXT: Mongolian nomads in Central Asia. Although it invaded Central Europe since the 6th century, it declined after the end of the 8th century Karl the Great, assimilated with Slavic and Majar.

DOC.Title: Oasis' way
DOC.TEXT: The main route of East-West traffic connecting Luoyang · Chang'an of China to northwest China · east-west Turkistan · Iran plateau north · mesopotamia · east coast of the Mediterranean. It was developed by Akemenesen Ekiden system, Alexander the Great Eastern expedition, Wuhan Wing Emperor's Western Region management, etc. Scattered oasis city flourished as a relay city. Since the 8th century, maritime trading by Muslim merchants declined due to active activation.

DOC.Title: Silk Road, Silk Road
DOC.TEXT: Another name for Oasis' way. German geographer Richthofen named the Chinese specialty silk which was transported to the west by this road.

DOC.Title: Oasis City
DOC.TEXT: A city that is made up of agriculture using Oasis in the arid area and trade. It has long been established in the periphery of the Tarim Basin and around the Am River and the Sir River, playing a major role in the exchange of East-West culture.

DOC.Title: caravan trading
DOC.TEXT: Major trade form on the road of the oasis. Merchants set up a caravan and make use of livestock such as camels. It was operated mainly by sogged merchants and Muslim merchants.

DOC.Title: Sogiana
DOC.TEXT: An area blessed with numerous oasis cities such as Samarkand and Bukhara, sandwiched between Am Sill River. The name from the fact that the Iranian Sogudo was active in this place. Since Arabic Islamic forces have entered the market, it is also called Murwarra Annalf (Arabic) and Turkish Uyghur afterwards (West) Turkestan.

DOC.Title: Sogged merchant
DOC.TEXT: Merchants of Iranian Soguto who played an active part in the way of Oasis. He was mainly engaged in caravan trading, under the rule of a nomadic state such as 匈 奴 · あ っ そ う · Uyghur, told Maniacism and Sogd letters · Sogdo to Central Asia · East Asia.

DOC.Title: Sogd word
DOC.TEXT: Persian language of India = European language. Since the 7th century, it was used as a common language in Central Asia.

DOC.Title: sogged character
DOC.TEXT: Characters used by Soguto people. Characters derived from Aramaic characters, popular in Central Asia, became prototypes of Uighur, Mongolian and Manchurian characters.

DOC.Title: Akemeneshi
DOC.TEXT: The largest Iranian empire in the history of Orient. In order to connect the vast area, we improved the Ekiden system, activated trade activity and became the foundation of east-west exchanges through the oasis way later.

DOC.Title: Alexander's eastern expedition
DOC.TEXT: In the latter part of the 4th century BC, the eastern expedition made by Alexander. As a result, the great empire of Alexandros from the northern coast of the Aegean Sea to the Indus River basin was constructed, and the integration of east and western culture advanced and Hellenistic culture was created.

DOC.Title: Watanabe's Western Management
DOC.TEXT: In the latter half of the 2 nd century BC, the warrior started dispatching Zhang Zi to the west area. Under the control of the Oasis city around the Tarim Basin, we established 4 Kasai districts such as Dunhuang, and after that the East-West traffic passage will be opened.

DOC.Title: West Bank management of Later Han
DOC.TEXT: It was done by establishing the west area 福 福. In the 1st century, the superior activity of the group settled the control of the latter Han, the way of the oasis (Silk Road) was connected. Since then, Buddhism (era of latter Han), Zoroastrianism (era of Northern Wei) etc, etc. were transmitted to the East Asian world along with the novel western goods.

DOC.Title: Western regional management of Tang
DOC.TEXT: Miyako (in the Western Region, Anzai · North Garden City Guard Office) was established. As a result, silk horse trade through Sogdo merchants took place regularly, and the Nestorian Christianity, Mannishi and Islam was transmitted through the western region of this era, Genkyo and Yoshihiro were in India and brought back the Buddhist scriptures. However, since the middle of the 8th century, the western regional policy of Tang became passive due to the defeat at the battle of the Thalas river and the turbulence of Anshin.

DOC.Title: Sea Road
DOC.TEXT: From the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea, the Indian Ocean coast to the southern part of China via the Malay · Sumatra · Indochinese Peninsula. Although it is said that the danger is high and the utilization is lower than that of the inland route, after the Tang Dynasty, the Muslim merchant became the main route of East-West traffic due to its activity.

DOC.Title: Seasonal trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade using seasonal wind blowing towards the north east in summer and southwest in winter, which became irregular in the Indian Ocean from the first century.

DOC.Title: "Eurutura Hai Guide Information"
DOC.TEXT: A navigational guide in the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea and the Indian Ocean, written by Greeks living in Egypt around the middle of the century. Important historical documents of Nankai trade where trade circumstances were also mentioned.

DOC.Title: Greek merchant
DOC.TEXT: From the first century when the development of Rome became full-scale, trade between Rome and the direction of the Indian Ocean became a trade and it worked.

DOC.Title: Harbor City State
DOC.TEXT: Based on the port city (port town), the country flourished by managing and dominating marine trade and supplies from the inland river basin. Many were established in the coastal area of ​​Southeast Asia in the previous modern era. Fenan · Champa · Sri Vuay Jaya · Malacca Kingdom · Ayutaya Morning · Aceh Kingdom · Banten Kingdom etc. are representative. Besides, there are cases where Sydon Tirus that India's Sataverhanian morning, Sri Lanka (Ceylon Island), and Phoenicians built, is also an example of a port city state.

DOC.Title: Fenan
DOC.TEXT: China name in the country built in the Mekong River basin in the 1st and 2nd century. Through maritime trade, I exchanged with India and China.

DOC.Title: Champagne
DOC.TEXT: A country of Cham people in the southeastern part of the Indochinese Peninsula. Independent from the latter Han, flourished by maritime trading.

DOC.Title: Shreevyjaya
DOC.TEXT: A kingdom centered on the eastern part of Sumatra. Prosperity as a key point of maritime trade, Tang Dynasty stayed on the way back from India.

DOC.Title: Saturday morning, Andendra
DOC.TEXT: The dynasty of India who dominated the South West coast from Deccan Plateau. The maritime trade with the Roman world came and the Buddhist culture also flourished.

DOC.Title: Chinese Merchant
DOC.TEXT: In the East Asian ocean trade, Chinese merchants manipulated the junk ship to replace Indian merchants and Muslim merchants from the 10th century and became the leading role.

DOC.Title: Ceramic Road
DOC.TEXT: Another name for the sea road. Since around the 9th century, China's ceramics were brought to the west in large quantities through the sea route, and this name was to be used.

DOC.Title: Junk ship
DOC.TEXT: A ship developed in China, mainly used by Chinese merchants for ocean trading. It was made of a strong structure and was suitable for carrying a lot of baggage to a distance.

DOC.Title: East China Sea Trade Area
DOC.TEXT: Trade zone centered on Japan, China and Korea, conducted through the East China Sea. Since the latter half of the 14th century, the Kingdom of the Ryukyus prospered as the center of trade in this area in the days when Akira continued the policy of prohibiting the ocean.

DOC.Title: South China Sea Trade Area
DOC.TEXT: Trade zone connecting China, Southeast Asia, and even the Indian Ocean region, which took place via the South China Sea. Particularly from the Song Dynasty, ceramics were traded as major products and became the center route of the Ceramic Road. Since the 16th century, Portugal, Spain and the Netherlands also established bases in this area and entered trade.

DOC.Title: Manila
DOC.TEXT: In 1571, Spain established a trade base on Luzon Island.

DOC.Title: Macao
DOC.TEXT: In 1557, Portugal was allowed to live in China and established a trade base.

DOC.Title: Batavia
DOC.TEXT: In 1619, the Netherlands built a trade base in Java.

DOC.Title: Guangzhou
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city of the Pearl River estuary. It developed to Tang · Song · Yuan period. Marco = Polo called Kung Fu.

DOC.Title: Quanzhou
DOC.TEXT: Fujian is the port city of province. It developed to Tang · Song · Motoyo, and Marco-Bolo called Zeiton, introduced it as the world's first trade port.

DOC.Title: Yangzhou
DOC.TEXT: Cities in the northern coast of Jiangsu Province.

DOC.Title: Hangzhou
DOC.TEXT: Harbor City developed to South Song · Yuan period. Marco Polo introduced to Europe in the name of the quince.

DOC.Title: Mingzhou, Keito
DOC.TEXT: Current Ningbo. Developed to Tang · Yuan period, a Japanese trade boat arrived.

DOC.Title: Xiamen
DOC.TEXT: Harbor City developed to South Song · Yuan period. After that, it became the base of Okinawan resistance and overseas Chinese due to Zheng success.

DOC.Title: Shi Shi, Feng Shi Shi
DOC.TEXT: A government office placed for management of maritime trade from Tang Dynasty to Ming Dynasty. Since the Song Dynasty, maritime trade has become active rapidly, and it was also placed in Hangzhou, Quanzhou, Mingzhou in addition to Guangzhou of the Tang Dynasty.

DOC.Title: Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A special residential area for foreign merchants established in Guangzhou and Quanzhou at Tang · Song Dynasty. It was called Banbō.

DOC.Title: Zheng Wen
DOC.TEXT: The general who commanded the Nankai Expedition under the command of Emperor Yongle. Muslims in eunuchs. A part of the expedition fleet reached the east coast of Africa, and prompted a morning trip to Ming and brought about activation of Nankai trade.

DOC.Title: Ban Treaty
DOC.TEXT: From the latter half of the 14th century, clear policy on maritime trade obvious. It was laid out as a countermeasure against the shortage of currencies (silver · coin) due to the trade with Waomoo and the import of cotton cloth / spice from the Middle East and India.

DOC.Title: Ryukyu
DOC.TEXT: In the latter half of the 14th century, it became a kingdom after receiving a seal from Ming. With private sectors slumping due to the marriage's maritime penitence, trade by the tributary frequently took place, buying and selling trade goods with Ming to neighboring countries gained huge profits. After that, when the ban on arms was lifted and freedom trade revived, it declined.

DOC.Title: Naha
DOC.TEXT: The outer port of the Ryukyus. Chinese from Fujian emigrated and made tributaries and trade with China, Japan, Korea and others.

DOC.Title: Muromachi shogunate
DOC.TEXT: Mr. Ashikaga's samurai government opened. 1401 Ashikaga Yoshimitsu opened diplomatic relations with Akira, sealed in the King of Japan from the Ming, realized mating trade.

DOC.Title: Hiji Trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade with the Muromachi shogunate and Ming Dynasty, which took place under the tipping system of Mincho. Japanese shipbuilding boat is called mating trade as trading was allowed by bringing a merger (tally) delivered by Ming. Returned goods from the morning against the tributary brought great benefits to the Muromachi shogunate.

DOC.Title: Vessel ship
DOC.TEXT: A trade ship that got a vermilion letter as a permission for foreign trade from the shogunate. It became full-fledged in the early Edo period, and it was done until the ban on travel by 1635 by Tokugawa Iemitsu. Japan mainly imported raw silk and exported silver.

DOC.Title: Muslim Merchant
DOC.TEXT: Muslim merchants. I operated the Dow ship around the 8th century and also made great success in the Indian Ocean trading.

DOC.Title: Melaka Kingdom, Malaca Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The kingdom built in the southwest of the Malay Peninsula. It became the base of Zheng Wen's Nanhai Expedition, accepted Islamism in the mid-15th century, developed as a trade base connecting East Asia and the Indian Ocean.

DOC.Title: Mataram Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Islamic Kingdom built in Central Java. Prosperous in the export of rice and spices, but declined / annihilated by internal conflict.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Aceh
DOC.TEXT: Islamic Kingdom built at the northern end of Sumatra Island. Prosperous in export of spices.

DOC.Title: Indian Ocean Trade Area
DOC.TEXT: The trade zone spread from the Persian Gulf to China through the Indian Ocean. Muslim merchants used Dow ship since the 8th century and became the center of trade. When the Chinese began participating in the East Asian ocean trade since the 10th century, they conducted trade with Melaka, Palembang and others. In the 13th century, the greatly developed Mongol empire and Muslim merchants were connected, and trade in the Indian Ocean became more active. The woolen fabrics produced in Europe are taken to the hands of Karrimy merchants in Cairo and others, brought to Basra / Sealaf on the Persian Gulf coast, and raw silk from China such as Kambaya, Surat, Caribut, and Melaka on the West Coast of India etc. Silk, cotton cloth from India · spices · sugar, ivory from East Africa and so on were traded.

DOC.Title: Basra
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city located in the deepest part of the Persian Gulf.

DOC.Title: Sealaf
DOC.TEXT: Port city on the Persian Gulf.

DOC.Title: Cambaya, Canvey
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city on the west north shore of India.

DOC.Title: Surat
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city on the west north shore of India. During the Mughal Empire also became the departure port of the Mecca pilgrimage.

DOC.Title: Calicut
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city on the west coast of India. Export port of cotton cloth and spices.

DOC.Title: Quilon
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city on the west coast of India.

DOC.Title: Carlye Merchant
DOC.TEXT: A Muslim merchant group active in trade dealing with spices, silk, ceramics, etc, on the route connecting the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean, mainly in the Red Sea. From the 11th to 15th century, from the Ayyub Morning to the Mamluk dynasty in the first half of the era, he was based in Cairo and Alexandria, where he worked in various commercial districts.

DOC.Title: Cairo
DOC.TEXT: After the 11th century, it became the base of the Karrimy merchant, the Italian merchant also visited, the property in the east and the property in Europe were dealt and prospered greatly.

DOC.Title: Alexandria
DOC.TEXT: After the 11th century, along with Cairo, became the base of Karrimy merchants, sold the spices and the like obtained in Aden to Italian merchants.

DOC.Title: Aden
DOC.TEXT: Harbor City located at the entrance of the Red Sea. Perfumes produced nearby and condiments from the Indian side were traded.

DOC.Title: Dow ship
DOC.TEXT: A sailboat of a triangular sail. Originally it was a small riverbrew and was constructed with a simple structure, but since the 12th century it has grown dramatically. It was widely used in trade in the Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean using monsoon (seasonal wind).

DOC.Title: Dirham silver coin
DOC.TEXT: It was built in the Umayya era, circulated in the Islamic world, especially in Iran.

DOC.Title: Dinar gold coin
DOC.TEXT: It was built in the Umayya era and distributed in the Islamic world and the Indian Ocean trade zone.

DOC.Title: Italian merchant
DOC.TEXT: Merchant who worked in a port city such as Venice, Genoa, Pisa. Developed with the transportation of goods of the crusade that began at the end of the 11th century, it developed in the eastern trade with the Islam area and became the center of the Mediterranean trade zone.

DOC.Title: Mediterranean Trade Area
DOC.TEXT: From the end of the 11th century, the trade zone mainly carried out between the ports of northern Italy's ports, the eastern coast of the Mediterranean and the various ports of Egypt. Venice Genoa Pisa and others who developed and developed goods transportation at the start of the Crusaders, from the Constantinople of the Byzantine Empire and from the Karrimy merchants who were active in the first half of the Morning Morning and the Aiyubo Morning, spices, jewels, silk I bought fabrics etc. On the other hand, the European side sold woolen fabrics, timber, female, etc., and paid the shortage with silver.

DOC.Title: Jewish merchant
DOC.TEXT: Since the Crusade, apostolic and Byzantine emperors prohibited trading with Muslim merchants for Christians, sometimes raising profits by acting as an intermediary between them.

DOC.Title: Venice
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city in northern Italy on the north coast of the Adriatic Sea. In the beginning of the 13th century, it occupied Constantinople using the 4th Crusade and became the center of the Mediterranean trade in support of expedition of the Crusaders.

DOC.Title: Genoa
DOC.TEXT: Port city in northwest Italy. With the support of the crusade expedition, it developed, spreading the trade range from the Mediterranean to the Black Sea and prospering.

DOC.Title: Pisa
DOC.TEXT: Port city in the Midwest Italy. Although it developed with the support of crusade expedition, it declined after losing Genoa in the latter half of the 13th century.

DOC.Title: Hellenistic
DOC.TEXT: Eastern and western integration culture centered on Greek culture formed by the eastern expedition of Alexander the Great. After entering Pactolia and entering India, he gave birth to Gandhara art and influenced China and Japan through the way of the oasis.

DOC.Title: Maniacism
DOC.TEXT: Religion established in Sasan morning. In the west, Syria, Egypt to Europe, Turkistan / China to the east. It was widely appreciated by Uighurs, and it arrived in China from the western region at the end of the 7th century and the Tang dynasty.

DOC.Title: Islamism
DOC.TEXT: It spread to various places along with the activities of Muslim merchants. It was introduced to China through maritime trade in the second half of the seventh century, and then from the western region to the northwestern part of China. In China, it was called a school of Islam and Queen.

DOC.Title: Buddhism
DOC.TEXT: Mahayana Buddhism was transferred from Central Asia to China, Korea and Japan.

DOC.Title: Zoroastrianism
DOC.TEXT: Religion established in Iran around the 7th century. It was introduced to China during the North and the North, and in the Tang Dynasty it was called a religion.

DOC.Title: Nestorian faction
DOC.TEXT: Christianity that was regarded as heretical at the Council of Fesos in 431. It was introduced to China in the Tang Dynasty and was called Jingjo.

DOC.Title: Silk
DOC.TEXT: One of the most important trading goods of the oasis way which was handy in the west as a special product of China.

DOC.Title: Horses
DOC.TEXT: It is a transportation and combat tool of northern nomads, the main trade goods against China. Arabian horses were also exported to China through the Indian Ocean trade.

DOC.Title: Grape, Grape
DOC.TEXT: It is said that Zhang Zhang brought to China from the western region.

DOC.Title: Glassware
DOC.TEXT: Beginning with Mesopotamia, the recipe was inherited in Rome and Sasan morning. Glass craft goods of the Sasan dynasty also brought to Japan and became treasure of Shosoin. After that, through the Islamic world and the Byzantine Empire, Venice and Bömen (Bohemia) developed as the center of luxury glass production.

DOC.Title: copper coin
DOC.TEXT: It was exported to China, especially to Song Dynasty to India / Southeast Asia, Japan.

DOC.Title: ivory
DOC.TEXT: It was exported from East Africa, India, Southeast Asia to China and Europe by maritime trade.

DOC.Title: Spice
DOC.TEXT: Indian · Southeast Asia special products such as pepper, beef, nutmeg etc. It was regarded as the most important trade item of maritime trade.

DOC.Title: fragrance
DOC.TEXT: Goods originating in the Arabian Peninsula, India, Southeast Asia etc, which produce strong fragrance. There are various kinds according to raw materials, such as frankincense · agarwood · musk · musk · anbar (lycrae).

DOC.Title: Brown
DOC.TEXT: It originated from China, spread to the general public in the middle of Tang Dynasty, spread to the people around the Song Dynasty, and monopoly of tea was also conducted. It became the main deal of goods of Indian Ocean trading, and it is said that it was reported to Europe by the Dutch East India company around the 17th century.

DOC.Title: Sugar
DOC.TEXT: It is made by boiling down sugar cane originating from India. It was reported to China and the Islamic world through the Indian Ocean trade, and since the Crusades it is believed to have been brought to Europe by the Mediterranean trade.

DOC.Title: cotton cloth
DOC.TEXT: It was produced mainly in India since ancient times. After that it was transmitted to the Islamic world through the Indian Ocean Trade and it is believed to have been brought to Europe by the Mediterranean trade since the Crusades.

DOC.Title: Ceramics
DOC.TEXT: Production expanded with the spread of customs of dumpling in China. Through maritime trade since the 9th century, it became the most important export item of China instead of silk. Tang San Cai · Song Magnet was exported and influenced the culture of each place.

DOC.Title: Celadon
DOC.TEXT: Ceramics made with blue glaze. Although the color of the blue color varies, from the Song Dynasty to the Yuan period, a high technology celadon was created.

DOC.Title: white porcelain
DOC.TEXT: Ceramics made using transparent or white glaze. Since Song Dynasty, Jingdezhen is particularly famous as a production place.

DOC.Title: paper
DOC.TEXT: Since the later Han 's improvement by Cai Lee, it spread in China. It was thought that it was transmitted to Japan through the Korean Peninsula around the 5th-6th century, but it was reported to the Islam world in the 8th century and to Western Europe about the 12th century.

DOC.Title: Western paper of papermaking law
DOC.TEXT: It is believed to have been conveyed to the Islamic world by a Tang paper craftsman who became a captive in the battle of the Thalas river.

DOC.Title: Gunpowder
DOC.TEXT: It was put to practical use in the Song Dynasty, passed through the Islamic world to the Western Europe.

DOC.Title: Rashinban
DOC.TEXT: A compact oriented magnetic needle introduced from China to Islam was improved in Western Europe, and the compass was completed.

DOC.Title: Printing technique
DOC.TEXT: Inventions and practical application in China and Korea were transmitted to Western Europe, and it is said that it led to improvement of the printing technique of the 15th century.

DOC.Title: Ming
DOC.TEXT: The only dynasty in China history that developed from Gangnam and succeeded in unifying China. A founding national is Zhu Yuan. Then in 1421, during the era of Emperor Yongle the capital was transferred from Nanjing to Beijing. Although the traditional system of Han people was revived, the dictatorship of the emperor was established and the culture matured, but since the middle period suffered by the domineering of the North Prison South Waum and the eunuch, the financial difficulties and the court 's internal conflict also overlapped, and in 1644, It was destroyed by turbulence.

DOC.Title: Redness's Ran
DOC.TEXT: A big farmer rebellion that occurred at the end of the year and became a direct cause of the collapse of the former morning. After the execution of Hakuren Leader, Hanjiroko, the child's Hanlin children stood up as a rebellion, a large number of migrants joined this, developed into a great rebellion.

DOC.Title: Zhu Xun Meng, Hong Kong Emperor
DOC.TEXT: The first Emperor of Ming (ranking 1368-98). Originating from a poor farmer, emerging from the scourge of red wings, holding the leadership of the rebel army, he established the Ming dynasty in 1368, throneing in Nanjing (Jinling). Furthermore, I rejected the original to the Mongol plateau, completed the unification of China, strengthened the emperor dictatorship system.

DOC.Title: System of one unitary unity
DOC.TEXT: A system that makes one emperor for one emperor. It was passed down to the Qing Dynasty with a system that was established because Ming Dynasty (Zhu Yuan) did not change the original name "Hongwu". Since then, it has become a habit to call the emperor's name with the former name.

DOC.Title: Nanjing, Jinling
DOC.TEXT: Early in the morning, the capital of the Hong Kong Emperor and the Temporary Empress. It became the capital of many dynasties since ancient times and was named variously, but Emperor Hongwu set the capital, renamed Jinling of the previous generation as Nanking, Kyoto etc. In 1421, after the capital to Beijing was called Nanjing, prosperous as a sub-capital.

DOC.Title: 六 部, 明
DOC.TEXT: Six administrative organizations of the Cabinet, the House, the Rei Department, the Military Headquarters, the Prime Minister and the Engineering Division established in the Tang dynasty. Hongwu Emperor abolished the provincial department that had jurisdiction of this, put it under the emperor directly, strengthened the authoritarian regime further.

DOC.Title: Mei Law, Omakeei
DOC.TEXT: In 1368, the penal code issued by Emperor Hongwu. While being based on Tang Law, it was created by adding elements of Song · Yuan period's law.

DOC.Title: Akira, Omaki Ai
DOC.TEXT: In 1368, the law promulgated by Hongu Emperor. It was created with the Tang Dynasty as a reference, referring to the Song · Yuan period law.

DOC.Title: Military
DOC.TEXT: A house that was put into military affairs. In the light it was placed under the jurisdiction of the soldiers, belonging to the local office and subject to military service.

DOC.Title: Weathered system
DOC.TEXT: The military regiment of the military agreement that Hongwu Empress founded as a parade of Tang 's military service. One hundred of households with 112 military personnel, one thousand households at 10 hundred places, one hundred five centimeters at 5 thousand places, one city guard on the supervision, and each ministry under jurisdiction.

DOC.Title: Five Army Governor's Office
DOC.TEXT: The highest military institution in the Ming Dynasty. The military is divided by the jurisdictional area into five (Army) of the middle army, Left army, Right army, Previous army, and the rear army, and let each director (military superintendent) report to the emperor, concentration of military power to the emperor I did.

DOC.Title: Denpa House
DOC.TEXT: Central embankment and judicial agency, Emperor Hongwu abolished the historical center and established it. However, the corruption of officials was discussed, but important criminal cases were deliberated. It was the highest institution under the Emperor who is in line with the Five Government Office of the military in charge of the sixth section of the administrative office.

DOC.Title: Minoto
DOC.TEXT: The house of farmers, merchants, craftsmen and others who are stated in the supplementary yellow book. Under the management of the provincial county, it was incorporated into the village system and imposed a heavy burden including taxes and services.

DOC.Title: Okito
DOC.TEXT: A house of handicrafts manned in the engineering department.

DOC.Title: village regime
DOC.TEXT: Joint liability system for rural governance enacted by Emperor Hong. We divided 110 houses from 110 towns, of which 10 rich Futomo was a Nagato village, the remaining 100 houses were divided into 10 houses and 10 households, and each armored a carapace. Among them, 1 rio chief and 10 staple heads chosen for one year change were charged with the responsibility of preparing a work book, collecting taxes, procuring deliverables to the center, and maintaining village security.

DOC.Title: Concluded yellow book
DOC.TEXT: A family registry and tax register created for the citadel. Family composition and property situation etc of each house are stated, and it was revised every ten years. Because yellow paper was used on the cover, it was named yellow book.

DOC.Title: Scaly figure book
