DOC.TEXT: Mating in the 15th century as a trade port prospered. At once, the merchant grasped the town administration, prospered as an autonomous city.

DOC.Title: Hirado
DOC.TEXT: In the old days, the port of call of a Chinese shipping vessel. Portuguese ship arrived in 1550, after which the four merchant ships of Spain, the Netherlands and the UK entered and came as a trade port.

DOC.Title: Nanban trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade by European vessels, mainly of Portugal. We entered Kagoshima, prefecture, Hirado, Nagasaki, etc. and mediated the products in China · Southeast Asia · Europe.

DOC.Title: Nihonmachi
DOC.TEXT: A collective place of residence made by Japanese who advanced to various parts of Southeast Asia around the 17th century. Thailand · Philippines · Vietnam · Cambodia · Burma etc. It ranged from several hundred to several thousand people, and many autonomous systems were taken. After that, it faded and disappeared in the seclusion policy of the Edo shogunate.

DOC.Title: Yamada Nagasaki
DOC.TEXT: About 1612, he became the head of Ayutaya Nihonmachi over Ayutthaya era Thailand. After that, he was appointed as a defense of Rigoire in the Malay Peninsula, but was involved in political fighting and poisoned.

DOC.Title: Tokugawa Ieyasu
DOC.TEXT: We established hegemony in the battle of Sekigahara in 1600. In 1603 he became the Shogun Shogunate and opened the shogunate in Edo.

DOC.Title: Edo shogunate, Tokugawa shogunate
DOC.TEXT: The last samurai government in Japan. Ieyasu opened in Edo in 1603. After that, until the collapse of the shogunate in 1867 is called the Edo period. We reorganized feudalism system, and continued isolation in foreign countries.

DOC.Title: Mr. Shimazu, Satsuma clan
DOC.TEXT: Daimyo who owned Satsuma · Osumi 2 countries (present Kagoshima prefecture). In 1609, he dispatched to Ryukyus to control Shuri.

DOC.Title: isolation country
DOC.TEXT: Prohibition against contact with Western countries by the Edo Shogunate. Christianity ban and trade control were the main objectives. Prohibited Christianity banquet orders in 1612, 16 years' foreign trade port to 2 ports in Hirado and Nagasaki, banned the arrival of Spain vessels in 24 years, prohibition of Japanese overseas travel and return home in 1935, Portuguese ship in 39 years Continue with the prohibition of the visit of the shrine, in 41, limited to the deceased islands of Qing and the Dutch in Nagasaki, the isolation system was established.

DOC.Title: "Four mouths", four mouths
DOC.TEXT: Even under the isolation system, it means four windows that were open to the outside world. Specifically, Nagasaki mouth for the Netherlands and China, Tsushima for Korea, Matsumoto mouth for Ritsukyu (and China through Ryukyus), Matsumae for Ainu.

DOC.Title: Nagasaki
DOC.TEXT: In 1571 a Portuguese ship arrived and developed from the 17th century as a center of foreign trade on behalf of Hirado. After the isolation of 1641 it became the only destination for Dutch ships.

DOC.Title: Dejima
DOC.TEXT: Landfill in Nagasaki Port. In 1641 the Dutch made a business hall, and access to officials and authorized merchants was prohibited.

DOC.Title: Mr. Takeshi Tsushima
DOC.TEXT: Since the 13th century, Tsushima held the real power, and under the Edo shogunate was also allowed to monopolize the practice of Korean diplomacy and trade.

DOC.Title: Korean correspondent
DOC.TEXT: The mission of the Korean dynasty dispatched to Japan. I celebrated nearly every general appointment and came to Japan to negotiate. It was sent 12 times during the Edo period.

DOC.Title: The structure of the curtain clan
DOC.TEXT: Political and social system under the control of the Edo shogunate. The feudal rule was exercised by the shogunate and various clans, and the status system was strictly maintained.

DOC.Title: Ainu
DOC.TEXT: Indigenous people living mainly in Sakhalin, Chishima and Hokkaido. It resisted the invasion of the Matsumae clan and the Japanese (Japanese who emigrated from Honshu) and repeated uprising.

DOC.Title: Matsumae Clan
DOC.TEXT: In 1604, Mr. Matsumae formed a dominion in the Ezo land with the exclusive right to trade with Ainu from Ieyasu. At the end of the 18 th century, Ezo was transferred to Tohoku because it was the direct jurisdiction of the Edo shogunate for the North side security.

DOC.Title: Battle of Shaksh Shine
DOC.TEXT: In 1669, Ainu 's leader Shakshin was widely called for Ainu people to make a massive resistance movement. It was suppressed by the Matsumae clan, and the control system was strengthened.

DOC.Title: Chagatai-Han Country
DOC.TEXT: A nomadic nation built by Chagathai, the second child of Genghis-Han, in Central Asia with Al-Marrik as the capital. It became Islam in the 14th century, divided into the east and west.

DOC.Title: West Chagatai-Han Country
DOC.TEXT: It is established by division of Chagatai-Han country. It was made Islam, centering on settlements in Western Turkestan. Suffering from the internal conflict and the attack of eastern Chaga-tai, it was sacrificed by Timur.

DOC.Title: Timur
DOC.TEXT: Founder of Timur Dynasty. Embarked on the turmoil of West Chaga Thai-Han County, he emerged from the Turkish family members, founded in 1370. Expanded the majority of Central Asia and expedited to the four sides, restrained the two Rivers Region in 1393, invaded Kipchak = Han country · Northeastern India. Then in 1402 he destroyed the Ottoman army, but on the way to the Ming, he died in Otaru in Central Asia.

DOC.Title: Timur morning, Timur empire
DOC.TEXT: Islamic dynasty in Central Asia where Timur founded. The first half of the 15th century was at its heyday, cultures such as literature, astronomy, calendar law, architecture and fine painting prospered. After that, it was destroyed by the Uzbek tribes.

DOC.Title: Samarkand
DOC.TEXT: Oasis city in Central Asia, Sogdiana. Prosperity as the center of East-West trade since long ago. It flourished as a capital in the Timuru era.

DOC.Title: Il = Han Country
DOC.TEXT: A country that the flag destroyed Abbasid morning and built in West Asia. The capital is Tabriz. At the end of the 13th century, Gazan Han established Islamist as a state religion, after which Islamization advanced.

DOC.Title: Kipchak = Han country
DOC.TEXT: A nomadic country Batu built in South Russia. Sarai is the capital. It has advanced from Islam earlier, prospering in East-West trade.

DOC.Title: Battle of Ankara
DOC.TEXT: Battle where Timur was captured by Ottoman Empire Bayardess I. As a result, the Ottoman Empire was temporarily suspended.

DOC.Title: Herat
DOC.TEXT: A city in western Afghanistan. In the 15th century it became the capital of the Timur Dynasty and flourished as a center of science and art.

DOC.Title: Shar-Ruff
DOC.TEXT: Timur 's fourth child. Timur Dynasty The Third Prince (Roll 1409-47). Moved the capital to Herat, led the empire to its heyday, including maintaining goodwill relations with Ming and the Ottoman Empire, making books of books and talks.

DOC.Title: Urg-Baek
DOC.TEXT: Son of Shurafu. The fourth Timur Dynasty (ranking from 1447 to 49). I loved the arts and made construction of astronomical observatory. It was assassinated because of the civil war, and the Timurid Dynasty began to decline after that.

DOC.Title: Miniature, fine detail
DOC.TEXT: Many in books of books. It occurred in the court of Abbasid in the 9th century and spread to the Islamic culture zone mainly in Iran.

DOC.Title: Ottoman Empire
DOC.TEXT: From the end of the 13th century until the 20th century, the great empire of Islam who dominated the region that straddled Eastern Europe, West Asia and North Africa during its peak. The founder of Ottoman I. It increased steadily from the northwestern part of Anatolia (Asia Asia) to the controlled area, but it was temporarily discontinued after being defeated by Timur in 1402. In 1453 after the reconstruction, occupied Constantinople, destroyed the Byzantine Empire, after which it expanded its territory to Balkans, Eastern Europe, North Africa, Syria and Egypt. In the sixteenth century McCa Medina was under the control and secured the leading position in the Islamic world, and the Western European countries were overwhelmed and reached its peak.

DOC.Title: Room = Seljuk Morning
DOC.TEXT: Dynasty where the Seljuk tribe founded Anatolia. Although we were weakened by the invasion of the 13th century Mongolia, Ottoman who served this dynasty autonomously established the Ottoman Empire.

DOC.Title: Ottoman I, Ottoman Bay
DOC.TEXT: Room = Self-independence in the western part of Anatolia, multiplied by the confusion after the collapse of the Sergquk, became the first Ottoman monarch (ranking 1299 to 1326). It expanded the area by hitting the Byzantine Empire, laying the foundation of the Ottoman Empire.

DOC.Title: Bursa
DOC.TEXT: Built in the northwestern part of Anatolia, the capital of the early Ottoman Empire.

DOC.Title: Adrianope, Edirne
DOC.TEXT: A town in the southeastern part of the Balkans. In 1362 Murat I took away from Byzantine. In Turkish it was called Edirne, and became the capital of the Ottoman Empire between 1366 and 1453.

DOC.Title: Battle of Kosovo
DOC.TEXT: The Ottoman Empire Murat I battled Slavs forces in the Balkans such as Serbia and Bosnia with Kosovo. As a result, the Balkans peninsula south of the Danube continues to be under the control of the Ottoman Empire until Islamic until the 19th century.

DOC.Title: Bayard I.
DOC.TEXT: Ottoman Empire Fourth Sultan (ranking 1389-1402). In Nicopolis I destroyed the European Crusaders, but in the fight of Ankara in 1402 it was completely defeated by Timur and caught, he died of illness. The Ottoman Empire has since reached the age of vacancy until 1413.

DOC.Title: Battle of Nicopolis
DOC.TEXT: Battle of the Ottoman Empire Bayadill I destroyed the coalition crusaders of the Balkans, France, Germany and the UK, mainly of King Hungarian Jigismund. Nicopolis is a city on the border of Bulgaria.

DOC.Title: Jigismund
DOC.TEXT: Emperor of Holy Roman (ranking 1411-37), also King of Hungary and Bohemia. During the era of King Hungary, in the battle of Nicopolis lost to the Ottoman Empire. It is also known to convene the Council of Constance as the Holy Roman Emperor in 1414.

DOC.Title: Battle of Ankara
DOC.TEXT: The battle where the Ottoman Empire lost in the Timur rule. The defeated Bayadit I was caught and died of illness. Since then the Ottoman Empire continued its vacancy era for 11 years and was in danger of extinction.

DOC.Title: Mehmedo II
DOC.TEXT: Ottoman Empire Seventh Sultan (rank 1444-46, 51-81). In 1453 he caught Constantinople and destroyed the Byzantine Empire and went to this place. It also entered the Black Sea coast · Vulcan, strengthening the foundation of internal affairs.

DOC.Title: Destruction of Byzantine Empire
DOC.TEXT: Because the Ottoman Empire attacked and occupied Constantinople, the Byzantine Empire was destroyed.

DOC.Title: Istanbul
DOC.TEXT: A city that faces the Bosphorus Strait, which is the exit from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean Sea. Although it was called Constantinople since 330, it was occupied by the Ottoman Empire in 1453 and became the capital and the name of Istanbul spread.

DOC.Title: Klim = Han country
DOC.TEXT: It was a branch of Kipchak-Han country and later became independent. I belonged to the Ottoman Empire at the end of the 15th century.

DOC.Title: Selim I
DOC.TEXT: Ottoman Empire No. 9 Sultan (ranking from 1512 to 20). In 1514 Safavid morning, 16 years I attacked Syria. In 1517 destroyed the Egyptian Mamluku morning and acquired control of Mecca Medina.

DOC.Title: Mamluk Morning
DOC.TEXT: The dynasty which the Mamluk army of the Ayuvu military founded. It dominated Egypt · Syria, and was hit by crusades and Mongolia. It dominated the trade between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean and flourished, but it was destroyed by the Ottoman Empire.

DOC.Title: Sultan = caliphate system
DOC.TEXT: A system in which Sultan also doubles as a caliph. When Selim I of the Ottoman Sultan destroyed the Mamluk morning, it took its position from the caliph of Abbasid who exiled here and was established. [Recent research suggests that the empire uses Sultan = Caliphate as early as the latter half of the 18th century. ]

DOC.Title: Suleiman I
DOC.TEXT: Ottoman empire tenth sultan (ranking 1520-66). The central authority system was prepared, and the heyday of the Ottoman Empire was built, and it was called a legislator (Carnoy). It dominated Western Asia, North Africa and Eastern Europe, formed an alliance with Francis I of France and pressed the Western European countries.

DOC.Title: Battle of Moheach
DOC.TEXT: Battle where Suleiman I lost Hungary king Rajos II. Shortly thereafter Hungary was divided into three, and its main area was placed under the control of the Ottoman Empire until the end of the 17th century.

DOC.Title: Vienna siege, First Vienna siege
DOC.TEXT: The case where the Ottoman Empire surrounded the city of Holy Roman Empire Vienna. Vienna escaped fall from solving the siege with the Ottoman forces in over a month, so Vienna escaped fall, but since that time it became an incident that strongly impressed Western European countries "the threat of Turkey" long.

DOC.Title: Battle of the Preveza
DOC.TEXT: Preveza is the place on the west coast of Greece. Battle where the Ottoman Navy broke the Allied fleet of Spain, Pope Venezia. Since then, he held the maritime authority in all Mediterranean regions except Creta Marta.

DOC.Title: capitalization
DOC.TEXT: A kind of extraterritorial law that the Ottoman Empire guarantees conservation jurisdiction, tax exemptions, physical and property security to Western Europeans (primarily Christians). It began that Selim II (Emperor Suleiman I next) gave it as a benefit measure to deepen friendship and trade relations with France, and then it was also given to England and the Netherlands. However, after the 18th century, when the Ottoman empire faded, it was interpreted and used as a favorable inequality treaty for Western powers, and it was regarded as a foothold for invasion. [Up until now, Suleiman I was given to France, and many of the textbooks are written as such, but here we followed a novel. ]

DOC.Title: Suleiman = Mosque
DOC.TEXT: Representative of Islamic architecture in the Ottoman Empire. In 1557 Suleiman I was established in Istanbul.

DOC.Title: Mimary = Sinan
DOC.TEXT: An architect of the Ottoman Empire's heyday, Suleiman I generation. It is known for building Suleiman = Mosque.

DOC.Title: bar key
DOC.TEXT: Poets of the Ottoman heyday, Suleiman I generation era.

DOC.Title: Battle of Lepanto
DOC.TEXT: A battle where the Ottoman Navy was destroyed by Western European fleets such as Spain, Venice and the Roman Pope. Lepanto is located in the Corinth Bay in Greece. Due to this defeat, the Mediterranean domination of the Ottoman Empire temporarily retreated.

DOC.Title: Sheperfee
DOC.TEXT: In the early stages of the Ottoman Empire, the Turkish knight who became the main force of the army. Given tax collection right at Timar (donor site), under the obligation to attract and to attract a number of people according to the income there. The ownership of the distribution site belongs to the state, and Siberian is given only the tax collection right, and there is no personal control over the farmers.

DOC.Title: Timar
DOC.TEXT: The Ottoman Empire granted the knight (Shiperhi) the right to collect tax (from designated land) as compensation for military service. From the end of the 16th century the use of firearms expanded and when the importance of the knight in the battlefield began to diminish, it was abolished. It is a system similar to the Yctha system widely done in the Islamic world and the Pronoia system in the Byzantine Empire, but its origin is unknown in many respects.

DOC.Title: Jenicheli
DOC.TEXT: A regular infantry corps consisting of soldiers who are direct from Sultan. Meaning of "new soldier". We converted Christian siblings drafted by Dewsylm into Islam and made military exercises for those who are suitable for soldiers from among them to become members. It threatened the Christian countries with its powerful military power, but since then it formed a privileged group and intervened in politics, it was abolished in 1826.

DOC.Title: Dewsyline
DOC.TEXT: A system that forcibly recruits staff of Ottoman bureaucrats and corps soldiers. Prisoners or relatives of Christians forcibly recruited were converted to Islamistics, educated and trained, and appointed to key positions.

DOC.Title: Millelet
DOC.TEXT: A community of non-Muslims (Greek Orthodox, Armenian church and Jewish) made during the Ottoman Empire. Make non-Muslims communities, each with the obligation to contribute to the Ottoman empire instead of accepting traditional faith and customs. [In recent research, there was no fact that the term "Milet" was particularly used in the Ottoman era, non-Muslims are positioned as Jinmy (protected people) as before, and they can recognize their own faith and customs It was supposed to have been subjected to the duty of contribution instead. ]

DOC.Title: Sharia
DOC.TEXT: It means the law (Islamic law) set by Allah in Islam. From religious ceremonies such as worship, laws and norms with a wide range of contents such as marriage, contract, litigation, criminal law and so on.

DOC.Title: Carnoon
DOC.TEXT: One of the legal systems of Islamic society. In Islamic society, Shari'a is considered as the only law and norm, but in the Ottoman empire codified the edict and customary law of Sultan as Carnoon as a supplement to it.

DOC.Title: Cardy
DOC.TEXT: Judges of the Islamic world. People who were familiar with the Islamic law, mostly Ulamer assumed office. In the Ottoman Empire, I also took charge of local administration.

DOC.Title: Vienna siege, Second Wien siege
DOC.TEXT: Vienna siege case by the Ottoman army. The Ottoman army besieged with 150,000 large troops, but they were repelled by reinforcements such as the Polish armies. After that, the Ottoman empire in Europe began to decline.

DOC.Title: Karlovitz treaty
DOC.TEXT: The Peace Treaty between Austria, Poland, Venezia and the Ottoman Empire in Karlovitz on the banks of the Danube. The Ottoman Empire ceded major Hungarian territories under control to Austria. From this point onwards, the declining trend of the Ottoman Empire in Europe has become decisive.

DOC.Title: Ahmet 3
DOC.TEXT: Ottoman Empire 23rd Sultan (ranking 1703 to 30). Russia and Austria, but gradually the national power has declined.

DOC.Title: Tulip era
DOC.TEXT: In the early 18th century, during the reign of Ahmet 3, the era of cultural enrichment. Western European hobbies such as France have become popular centered on the court, and the literature, geography, and the private science of Western Europe were introduced. The tulip imported from Western Europe enthusiastically loved it and this name was attached because it was used for various decoration. It ended with popular riots, the introduction of Western culture (hobby) ended in half-hearted, after that the crown declined.

DOC.Title: Safavid Morning
DOC.TEXT: Ismailer I is the founding nation. The capital moves with Tabriz, Cazvin, Isfahan. The time of Abbas I is the heyday. The Shiite is regarded as the state religion, and the current Shiite school Iran was consolidated. In 1722 the Afghans were occupied the capital and eventually perished.

DOC.Title: Shear
DOC.TEXT: A word meaning "king" in Iran. It was used from the Achaemenid era and was used even in the Islamic era, but it was established in the Safavid era. It was also used in other Mughal empires.

DOC.Title: Mysticism, Safavid culture
DOC.TEXT: A cult that considers Islamic mysticism. Mysticism was ideal of coalition with God and emphasized the worship of miracles and saints, but the Safavid Council founded by Islamic mystics around the end of the 13th century spread rapidly around West Asia, centered on the people He had a strong influence.

DOC.Title: Ismail # 1
DOC.TEXT: The first prince of the Safavid dynasty (reign 1501-24). At the end of the 15th century, he became the leader of the mysticism group (Safavid Organization), flattened Iran and its surroundings and built Safavid Morning at Tabriz. The Shi'ite was national religion and adopted the title as a title.

DOC.Title: Kidil Bash
DOC.TEXT: Turkish nomads who supported the Safavid organization. After the formation of the Safavid dynasty, it formed a privilege hierarchy and repeated internal conflict, but was suppressed by Abbas I.

DOC.Title: Tabriz
DOC.TEXT: Cities in the Azerbaijan region. The capital city of Safavid early.

DOC.Title: Azerbaijan
DOC.TEXT: Region on the southwest coast of the Caspian Sea. Turkish and Shiite Muslims live a lot. In the 16th century, it was a conflict place between the Ottoman Empire and the Safavid dynasty.

DOC.Title: Shiite
DOC.TEXT: A minority in Islam and a group that claims that only the descendants of Ally are qualified as Muhammad's successor, became a denomination at the end of the 7th century. It survived mainly in Iran and Iraq, and it conflicts with the majority faction of Sunnah.

DOC.Title: Twelve Imam faction
DOC.TEXT: Moderate to form the mainstream of Shi'a. It is a group that considers only 12 direct people of Ally and his wife (daughter of Muhammad) as "true imam", dominated by Iran since the 16th century. Imam is the meaning of "leader", Shi'a is used in the meaning of "supreme leader" like the Sunni caliph, but depending on the faction, it is simply a collective worship leader, an academic scholar The interpretation is various, such as meaning.

DOC.Title: Abbas I
DOC.TEXT: King of the Safavid dynasty 5th (ranking 1587-1629). Reformed the military system, recaptured part of Azerbaijan and Iraq from the Ottoman Empire, destroyed Portuguese from Holmes Island. It took over to Isfahan and revealed the heyday of the Safavid dynasty.

DOC.Title: Isfahan
DOC.TEXT: Safavid capital of central Iran. In 1597 Abbas I transferred to here, and prosperity was hopped.

DOC.Title: Imam's Mosque
DOC.TEXT: A mosque built in Isfahan by the life of Abbas I. The beauty of geometric tiles covering the surface of the building is particularly famous.

DOC.Title: "Isfahan is half of the world"
DOC.TEXT: From the end of the 16th century to the 18th century, the expression of the great prosperity of Isfahan which was the capital of the Safavid dynasty. Beautiful buildings (mosques and corridors, royal palaces and gardens) are built around the King's Plaza (the current Imam Plaza), and many people from Europe have visited for trade and friendship, as well as from the Islamic world, the Netherlands And the commercial building of the East India company of England were also built.

DOC.Title: Holmes Island
DOC.TEXT: It is an important base in the Persian Gulf, both military and trade. It was occupied by Portugal in 1515, but the Safavid Morning was recaptured in 1622.

DOC.Title: Afshir morning
DOC.TEXT: Iranian Turkish dynasty. Although it was founded after defeating the Safavid dynasty, it was replaced by Kajar morning in 1796.

DOC.Title: Kajar morning
DOC.TEXT: Iranian Turkish dynasty. I destroyed the morning morning that took place in the morning of Afshar and built it. Since the 19th century, it became a place of conflict of expansion of the power sphere of Britain and Russia, and it became semi-colonized.

DOC.Title: Uzbek
DOC.TEXT: A Turkish ethnic group who lived in the Sill River Basin (Central Turkistan) in Central Asia. Building the Shaibani morning in 1500, destroyed the Timur morning in 1507. At the end of the 16th century, it was attacked by the Safavid dynasty and the Cossack tribe and faded.

DOC.Title: Shay bunny
DOC.TEXT: Founder of the Uzbek leader and Shaibani morning. Immediately after the construction of the dynasty, the Timur morning was destroyed, but it was lost in the fight against the Safavid dynasty.

DOC.Title: Bukhara-Han County, Bojara-Han Country
DOC.TEXT: The country that the Uzbek people built around Bukhara (initially called Shaibani morning). He played an active part in trade with Russia and East Turkestan, but in the latter part of the 19th century, like the Hiva Kokand, it was consolidated into Russia.

DOC.Title: Hiva-Han country
DOC.TEXT: A Uzbek country built in horror of the Am River Basin. The capital is Hiva. It was weakened by disputes with Bukhara-Han kingdom, and it was annexed to Russia in the second half of the 19th century.

DOC.Title: Ko Kando = Han Country
DOC.TEXT: In the beginning of the 18th century, the country of Uzbek people independent from Bukhara-Han kingdom. The capital is the capital. It flourished in agriculture in the Fergana basin and trade with Russia and Qing, but it was annexed to Russia in the second half of the 19th century.

DOC.Title: Kazafh people, Kazakh people
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic group who built a nomadic state in the grassland area north of the Shill River in the 16th century. It was made to belong to Jungal of the 17th century, was kept under the protection of 18th century Qing and Russia, was transferred to Russian territory in the first half of the 19th century.

DOC.Title: Hoja
DOC.TEXT: It is the leader of the Islamic mysticism group which advanced to East Turkestan in the 16th-17th century.

DOC.Title: Mughal Empire
DOC.TEXT: Babur's foundation, India's largest Islamic state. Although it abandoned in the middle of the 16th century, the third generation Akbar revived the empire and promoted centralization. Since then, it prospered until the age of the 6th generation Aurangsezu, but then religious conflict, rebellion of the people spread, falling into a small country with only the area around Delhi as the territory. In the middle of the nineteenth century, it was incorporated into the British territory with the Indian Rebellion (Rebellion of Shiba).

DOC.Title: Babble
DOC.TEXT: The founder of the Mughal Empire (ranked 1526 to 30). It is said that he is the descendant of Timur and inherited the strain of Genghis = Han from the maternal side. Although he aimed to restore the Timuru morning, he was lost to the Uzbek tribe, moved to Afghanistan (Kabul), and then repeatedly advanced to India. In 1526, at the battle of Pani パ ッ ト, he broke Rodi morning, occupied Delhi and built Mughal Empire.

DOC.Title: Battle of Panipat
DOC.TEXT: Babe defeated the army of Roddy morning, a fight that became a trigger for the founding of the Mughal Empire. The location is about 137 km north of Delhi.

DOC.Title: Akbar
DOC.TEXT: Mughal empire third emperor (ranking 1556 to 1605). Rebuilt the empire from the confusion after the bubble death, set Agra in the capital in 1558. We abolished Jizuya, tried to reconcile with Hindu, integrated with Large Boot kingdoms, achieved unification of North India by 1576. Establishing finance through land survey and monetary unification, and promoting centralization measures such as ruling across the country by state, prefecture, and county.

DOC.Title: Agra
DOC.TEXT: The town of Jamner River West Coast. 1558 Akbar was declared the capital, and it became the city several times until Shah-Jahan returned to Delhi. Many magnificent buildings such as Taj-Mahal are left in the vicinity.

DOC.Title: Abolition of Jizuya
DOC.TEXT: Jizuya is the head tax for non-Muslims imposed by the Muslim regime, and Akbar was abolished in 1564 to harmonize with Hindu.

DOC.Title: Mansavdar system
DOC.TEXT: Akbar's established rank system. All bureaucrats were ranked in Mansab (rank), obliged to prepare a cavalry and horse corresponding to each mansab, and gave salary.

DOC.Title: Jahan Girl
DOC.TEXT: Emperor of the 4th Mughal (ranking 1605-27). I followed the Akbar's religious tolerance policy.

DOC.Title: Shah-Jahan
DOC.TEXT: The son of the fourth generation Jahanghir and the fifth generation Mughal emperor (standing 1628-58). It calmed down the rebellion, conquered the south, and revealed the heyday of India = Islamic culture. Especially famous that Taj-Mahal was built for the queen. In the later years the baby was bruised by the real child Aurangseze.

DOC.Title: Auranguezebu
DOC.TEXT: The 6th Emperor of Mughal (ranking 1658-1707). Strict Sunni school forced the resurgence of Jizuya in 1679, crackdown on Shia and Hinduism, and destroyed the temple. Although concentrating on abroad and acquiring the greatest territory of the Empire, it caused rebellion such as the Rajput, the Sikhon, the Maratha tribe, the fiscal worsening due to the increase in war expenditure, the decline of the empire began.

DOC.Title: Resurrection of Jizuya
DOC.TEXT: Auranguezbe went in 1679. AURANG ZEBU was implementing persecution measures for non-Muslims from a standpoint as a strict Sunni Muslim Islam, but eventually it revived Jizuya.

DOC.Title: Zamingdar
DOC.TEXT: In the lord of Hindus under the Islamic dynasty of India, we undertook a tax collection contract.

DOC.Title: Nizam Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The kingdom built by the ark of the Muslim empire in 1724, independent of Ashf-Shah at the Deccan Plateau. The capital is Haidalabad. Since then, countries autonomous from the Mughal empire are rapidly increasing, and the empire goes to dismantle.

DOC.Title: Aud kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Kingdom self-sustaining in the middle Ganges river basin in 1724.

DOC.Title: Vijayagal kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Hindu kingdom dominated South India. Trade with West Asia, cultivation of commodity crops such as cotton and sugar cane, prosperous in commerce and industry, but declined due to conflict with Islamic powers.

DOC.Title: Large Pet
DOC.TEXT: The upper caste who lived in the western part of India and fixed their rulership in the 8th-12th centuries. I call himself a descendant of ancient Kushatriya. Although it was in peace relations with the Mughal Empire by Akbar's appeasement policy, it resisted intensely after the Aurangseb repression measures.

DOC.Title: Marathor
DOC.TEXT: Maharashtra Region (West Deccan Plateau) is the main residential area, mostly caste group engaged in agriculture. I devoted to Hinduism (especially Pakti faith) and became the centerpiece of the anti-Mughal movement.

DOC.Title: Shivaji
DOC.TEXT: Military leader of the marathon. Inspired by successive rebellion against Aurangsezbe, in 1674 he ranchered, and built the Kingdom of Mala.

DOC.Title: Maratha Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Kingdom of Hindu built by Shivaji. Developed while struggling with the Mughal Empire. After that, it was lost to Britain in the Maratha war and it was destroyed.

DOC.Title: Maratha alliance
DOC.TEXT: A gradual alliance that Marathi princes tied to resist the Mughal Empire. Afterwards it was destroyed by the British by the Maratha War (1775-82, 1802-05, 1817-18) one after another.

DOC.Title: Mysore Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Kingdom of Hindu built in Mysore district of South India. In the early 17th century, the Kingdom of Vijayanagar founding and developing in the midst of the decline, was pressed by the Islamic forces in the mid-18th century, was lost in the Mysore war that took place four times in the latter half of the 18th century, was placed under British rule.

DOC.Title: Kabir
DOC.TEXT: Indian religious reformers. He believed that God was the same at the root, and established a new faith to deny the fusion of Hinduism (Bakhti faith) and Islamism (Sufism), denying the caste, the formalized ritual, the authority of the scriptures, and so on.

DOC.Title: Bakhti faith
DOC.TEXT: Bakhti movement

DOC.Title: Narnack
DOC.TEXT: Indian religious leader and founder of Sikhism. I learned both Hindu and Islamic teachings and received the influence of Kabir and founded Sikhism.

DOC.Title: Sikhism
DOC.TEXT: Early in the 16th century, based on Hinduism (Bakhti faith), a new religion which was established strongly under the influence of Islamist. The founder was Nanak, spreading mainly in the Punjab region. It was monotheistic, denied idols and caste system, banned penance. With the pressure of the Mughal Empire under the militarization of the cult, advancing the militarization of the cult, built the Sikhu country in the 19th century. In the mid-nineteenth century, it was defeated by the second-order Sik war between England and was under its control.

DOC.Title: India = Islam culture
DOC.TEXT: Culture created by fusion of Indian culture and Islamic culture. After the Delhi dynasty, the fusion of both cultures progressed, especially maturing in the Mughal Empire.

DOC.Title: Hindi
DOC.TEXT: One of the main official languages ​​of the Indian Republic of today in Indo-European languages. The meaning of "Persian language of Indian people" in Persian. Those dialects in North India gradually integrated into common language. It is written in Devanagari characters.

DOC.Title: Urdu
DOC.TEXT: Today 's Pakistani language in Indo-European languages. It was established on the occasion of the northern India rule of the Islamic forces. There are a lot of borrowed words from the Arabic / Persian lord mainly in the northern Indian spoken language. It is written mainly with Arabic letters.

DOC.Title: Miniature, fine detail
DOC.TEXT: From Iran to India, it evolved into a Mughal painting and a Large Boot painting.

DOC.Title: Mughal painting
DOC.TEXT: Court paintings that were crowded in the Mughal Empire era. It developed based on Iranian painting miniature (miniature painting), but in the era of Akbar, fusion with Indian painting progressed, many of which painted flower birds, animals, portraits etc. graphically. In the age of Jahan Ghile, it was also influenced by European painting, but declined as Aurangzeb empathy was negative to paintings.

DOC.Title: Rajputo painting
DOC.TEXT: Painting that flourished in northwest India in the first half of the 16th-19th century. Many have dealt with Vishnu faith and popular subject matter related to it.

DOC.Title: Taj = Mahal
DOC.TEXT: The 5th Emperor Shah-Jahan was built in the east of Agra in 1632-53, grieving the death of babe Mumutaz-Mahal. From the beauty of the white marble dome and the garden fountain, it is regarded as the highest masterpiece of India = Islamic architecture.

DOC.Title: Mumutaz = Mahal
DOC.TEXT: Love of Shah-Jahan. Taj-Mahal was built as its temple.

DOC.Title: "Babe = Naama"
DOC.TEXT: A memorial record written by the first Emperor Babe. It is regarded as masterpiece of Turkish science literature history.

DOC.Title: "Akbar = Naama"
DOC.TEXT: A record of the history of the Mughal royal family and the rule of Emperor Akbar. Courtier Abel = Fazzle (1551-1602) wrote.

DOC.Title: Marko-Polo
DOC.TEXT: A merchant and traveler of Italy (Venice). In accordance with my father / uncle, I arrived in the big city of land route Yuan, and served also Fabylai. After returning home through Indian Ocean after staying for 16 years. Becoming a captive in the war with Genoa, he dictated the "description of the world" in prison.

DOC.Title: "Description of the world", "Oriental visit"
DOC.TEXT: Marking record of Marco Polo. He introduced the views of Central Asia, East Asia (including Yuan dynasty and Zipangu) and Indian Ocean in the 13th century, pushed Western European people into Asia.

DOC.Title: Zipangu
DOC.TEXT: Japan in the "Description of the World". In the hearing, it was regarded as an island rich in gold, silver and jewelry, and pushed the heat of Asian visits by Westerners.

DOC.Title: Prestar = John Legend
DOC.TEXT: A legend that there was a kingdom that was believed in Western Europe, a Christian priest in the east built by St. John (John). It also influenced crusaders and Carpini exploring Mongolia, and also the activities of Henrique Voyage Navy Prince.

DOC.Title: Toho Trade, Levant Trade
DOC.TEXT: After the 11th century, trade with Europe and the eastern coast of the Mediterranean (Levanto region) which became active. The European side mainly imported spices, silk fabrics, jewels, Muslim merchants imported woolen fabrics and silver. In Europe, since the 15th century when the Ottoman Empire occupied the east coast of the Mediterranean, the demand for exploration of direct routes to Asia increased.

DOC.Title: Spice
DOC.TEXT: Pepper, cinnamon, chicken, clove, etc. (Temples), such as stimulative luxury goods mainly from India and Southeast Asia. In Europe, which heavily eat meat, it was required to combine taste and anti-corruption, and it was the largest imported item in eastern trade.

DOC.Title: Pepper
DOC.TEXT: Spices from India and Sumatra. After entering the hands of many relay merchants, I entered southern Europe port from the east coast of the Mediterranean. In Venice around the 14th century, it was valuable enough to be exchanged for silver of the same weight.

DOC.Title: Enrique Navigational Prince
DOC.TEXT: Prince who built the foundation for overseas development of Portugal. The third child of Joan I (ranking 1385-1433). From the time of the campaign of Ceuta in 1415, it encouraged the exploration of the West Bank of Africa, the development of the Indian route, opened an observatory and a navigation exploration center, explored from Madira to the mouth of Gambia. It is said that he himself was seasickly and he almost did not navigate.

DOC.Title: Ceuta
DOC.TEXT: North West of Africa. Port city on the south coast of the Gibraltar Channel.

DOC.Title: Azores
DOC.TEXT: Islands on the Atlantic Ocean. In 1431, the expedition team dispatched by Enrique Navigation Prince discovered.

DOC.Title: Cape Verde
DOC.TEXT: The cape at the westernmost end of the continent of Africa. In 1445, the expedition team dispatched by Enrique Navigation Prince discovered.

DOC.Title: João II
DOC.TEXT: The Portuguese king (Indonesia 1481-95) who pioneered the development of Indian routes. The arrival at the Cape of Good Hope and the signing of the Tordesillas Treaty were events under the reign of the king.

DOC.Title: Bartolomeu-Diaz
DOC.TEXT: Portuguese voyager. Departed from 1488 (or 87) years by the life of Joan II, it was swept by the storm to the east of Africa, confirming the southern tip of Africa. As a result, the possibility of course going to India bypassing Africa was opened.

DOC.Title: Cape of Good Hope
DOC.TEXT: South of Africa. In 1498 Diaz arrived in the difficulty of navigation, named "the cape of Arashi", but King João II renamed it "Cape of Good Hope".

DOC.Title: Vasco da Gama
DOC.TEXT: Portuguese voyager. Departing Lisbon in July 1497 at the life of Manuel I (rank 1495 to 1521), turning around the Cape of Good Hope, along the Islamic sphere of the east coast of the country, northward. Directly to India by means of Ibn Marged from Marindi on the east coast of Africa, arrived at Calicut in May, 1498. By surprise attacking the group of Islam merchant ships, they took away the spices from the tribal chief and made use of the seasonal winds in September of 1499. After that she also sailed to India and was appointed to the Indian Governor (Vice-king) in 1524, but shortly afterwards he died of illness in India.

DOC.Title: Calicut
DOC.TEXT: Port city on southwest coast of India. In 1498 Vasco da Gama came and then the Netherlands and Britain dominated. Known as an export port of Indian cotton fabrics, it became the etymology of Characo.

DOC.Title: Indian route
DOC.TEXT: Direct route from Europe to India pioneered after reaching Kozhikode of Vasco da Gama. As a result, transactions that did not go through the Ottoman Empire were realized, the price of pepper in Lisbon became less than half of that in Venice, and the flow of Asian trade drastically shifted from the Mediterranean to the Indian route.

DOC.Title: Diwan Offensive Battle
DOC.TEXT: The battle that the Portuguese fleet destroyed the Egyptian Mamluk fleet off the coast of Die on the west coast of India. The sea control of the Red Sea and the Arabian Sea moved to Portugal and it was a major blow to Mamluku.

DOC.Title: Carac ship
DOC.TEXT: A ship created by the fusion of the Northern European sailing ship and the Mediterranean triangle sailing ship in the latter half of the 15th century. Ocean navigation became easier.

DOC.Title: Goa
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city on the west coast of India. Portuguese expedition forces occupied in 1510, after which it became the headquarters of Portugal 's advance to Asia. It was taken over by the Indian government in 1961.

DOC.Title: Ceylon, Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Portugal arrived in 1505 as a relay point to the fragrance islands, gradually strengthening control.

DOC.Title: Melaka Kingdom, Malaca Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The kingdom was established at the end of the 14th century, the middle of the 15th century, the king accepted Islamism and flourished as a key part of Nankai Trade. In 1511 Portugal occupied this with military force.

DOC.Title: Molucca Archipelago, Marc Islands, Perfume Islands
DOC.TEXT: An island between Celebes and New Guinea. It was the main destination of spices, especially clove / meat soybean (nutmeg), the main destinations of European Asian destinations. Since the arrival of the Portuguese in 1512 and the Spanish forces in 1521 (Magellan expedition), it became the point of contest for each country.

DOC.Title: Guangzhou
DOC.TEXT: Harbor city in the southern part of China. Portuguese arrived in 1517 and began light and trade.

DOC.Title: Macao
DOC.TEXT: Small port in the south of Guangzhou. Around 1517 Portuguese arrived and was allowed to live in 1557, and became the basis of the opposition trade. 1887 officially became Portuguese territory.

DOC.Title: Tanegashima
DOC.TEXT: 1543 An island south of Kyushu where Portuguese drifted. At this time, Portuguese is said to have reported guns to Japan.

DOC.Title: Hirado
DOC.TEXT: Port of western Kyushu. A Portuguese ship arrived in 1550, after that it became a destination for foreign ships, but prosperity ended in 1641 when the Dutch businessmen moved to Dejima.

DOC.Title: Nagasaki
DOC.TEXT: Since 1571 it has become a destination for Portuguese vessels, prosperity in the Southburgh trade. A Dutch vessel also arrived after the isolation of 1639.

DOC.Title: Maritime Empire
DOC.TEXT: A country that monopolizes trade by dominating the ocean route without dominating the area. Portugal is a good example in the first half of the 16th century.

DOC.Title: Toscanelli
DOC.TEXT: Astronomy and geographer in Florence. It asserted the theory of the Earth ball and gave the raise to Columbus to let him choose the westward route (Atlantic route).

DOC.Title: Earth ball theory
DOC.TEXT: The theory that the earth is a sphere. It was called during the Greek-Hellenistic period, passed down to the Islamic world, and was transmitted to Europe around the 13th century. Early in the 16th century, it was proved in the Magellan fleet worldwide.

DOC.Title: Columbus
DOC.TEXT: A navigator born in Genoa. I believed in the Earth ball theory and tried to reach the Asian west by westward navigation. With the aid of Queen Spain Queen Isabel, in August 1492, three vessels departed Paros from 120 people, after the 72nd voyage, arrived at the current Bahamas on October 12, exploring the vicinity and following 93 I came back to Japan in March. I sailed with the second place (1493-96), the 3 rd (1498-1500), the 4 th (1502-04), believing that the destination was part of India, but I could not find gold and silver or pepper, I also failed in local management, retired and retired.

DOC.Title: Isabel, Isabella
DOC.TEXT: Queen Castilla. In marriage with Argonese Fernando in 1469, after jointed by the two countries in 1979, we jointly governed as Spain's first queen (rank 1479-1504). In January 1492, we occupied Granada and accomplished the Reconquista, promising aid to Columbus in April.

DOC.Title: Santa Maria
DOC.TEXT: A sailing ship for the ocean navigation of three masts on which Columbus was on board during the first western navigation.

DOC.Title: Paros
DOC.TEXT: Port of Southwest coast of Spain. Columbus is the place of departure at the time of the first west navigation.

DOC.Title: West Indies
DOC.TEXT: It is a generic term for the islands scattered in the east of the Caribbean. Because it misunderstood that Columbus reached India, it was called like this.

DOC.Title: San Salvador Island
DOC.TEXT: I gave this name to the island where the Columbus group in the Bahamas lands first. The meaning of "holy savior" in Spanish.

DOC.Title: Indias
DOC.TEXT: A name that Europeans called one area of ​​Asia before the Great Voyage.

DOC.Title: colonial demarcation line, Papal meridian
DOC.TEXT: In the report of the arrival of Columbus in Asia, Portuguese-Spanish force division line set by Pope Alexander VI in 1493. It is the meridian of the western part of Cape Verde, making its west the Spain and the east the Portuguese sphere of influence.

DOC.Title: Tordesillas Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Spain · Portugal negotiated and moved the previous year's Papacy Meridian west west, the Treaty on Separation of Overseas Territories. With this, the current Brazil has become Portuguese territory.

DOC.Title: Zaragoza Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Spain sold the Molucca islands to Portugal. The scope of the power of both countries has been finalized. And on the Pacific side a meridian was drawn dividing the boundary between Spain and Portuguese territory.

DOC.Title: Cabot
DOC.TEXT: Italian voyage explorer. Father Giovanni was sponsored by King Henry VIII (ranked 1485-1509), explored the current Newfoundland and North American coast, westward from Bristol twice in 1497, 98. Child Sebastiano explored the Hudson Bay with the aid of Henry VIII.

DOC.Title: Kaburaru
DOC.TEXT: Admiral of Portugal. I flew a storm in the voyage to Asia in 1500 and drifted to the present Brazil. In the name of King Portugal, declared its possession.

DOC.Title: Brazil
DOC.TEXT: It was already accepted by the Tordesillas Treaty, but became the sole Portuguese territory in Central and South America by the arrival of Cabral.

DOC.Title: Amerigo = Vespucci
DOC.TEXT: People in Florence. It leads to astronomy and geography, exploring the New Continent four times. In the voyage report from 1501, it is said that this place is not Asia.

DOC.Title: New World
DOC.TEXT: Present naming conventions for both North and South America against the former continent. The name since Columbus arrived to be found not to be Asia.

DOC.Title: America
DOC.TEXT: After the use of the German geographer Waldsee Mueller in 1507 named after Amerigo who confirmed the New Continent, it generalized.

DOC.Title: Balboa
DOC.TEXT: Spanish explorer. In 1513, I arrived in the Pacific Ocean crossing Panama Strait and named it "Sea of ​​the South". It was sentenced to death by the name of treason by the governor of Panama who was afraid of his reputation.

DOC.Title: Panama Strait
DOC.TEXT: The narrowest part where the Americas are connected. Panama has become an important base of exploration since Columbus was discovered in the 4th voyage. After reaching the Pacific Ocean, it has become increasingly important.

DOC.Title: Magellan, Magalyanis
DOC.TEXT: Portuguese voyager. With assistance from Carlos I of Spain, 5 ships 280 people on 10 August 1519 departed Sepya and found a waterway at the southern tip of South America. After that, it crossed the Pacific Ocean over over 100 days of voyage, arriving at the current Philippine archipelago in 1521, it was killed against the chief of Mactan Island on the opposite bank of Cebu. However, in the next 22 years, a subordinate (1 ship and 18 people) completed the round.

DOC.Title: Magellan Strait
DOC.TEXT: In the strait of the south end of South America, I gave the name of the discoverer. There are many cliffs and reefs, the tidal current / ocean current is fast, the difficulty of navigation. In October 1520, the Magellan Corps passed safely on the 7th, but due to the difficulty of crossing the Pacific and passing through here, the Western Asia course has not been put to practical use for a long time.

DOC.Title: Pacific Ocean
DOC.TEXT: Magellan reached and named in October 1520. The meaning of "peaceful sea".

DOC.Title: World Traffic
DOC.TEXT: After the death of Magellan, his men passed the Molucca islands for the first time. Arriving at Paros on September 8, 1522, the Earth ball theory was demonstrated.

DOC.Title: Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Magellan reached from the east in 1521. Named after the Crown Prince Felipe, the governor of Legazpi proclaimed a territory in 1565, until the year 1898 it was Spanish territory.

DOC.Title: Laplap
DOC.TEXT: The chief of Mactan Island. Today, it is regarded as a hero in the Philippines by missing Magellan.

DOC.Title: Manila
DOC.TEXT: The main harbor city of Luzon, the main island of the Philippines. In 1571 Legazpi was built and became the base for the management of the Philippines in Spain.

DOC.Title: "Conquistador", Conquistador
DOC.TEXT: Spanish people who conquered Latin America since reaching the Americas. Columbus is the first, Cortez Pizarro is typical. I carried out aggressive activities under the name of Christianity missionary.

DOC.Title: Indio, Indian
DOC.TEXT: Generic name of Native Americans. Maya · Aztec · Inca, etc. had a high civilization, but the population decreased sharply due to severe labor and infectious diseases by "conquistors" and others.

DOC.Title: Corn
DOC.TEXT: One of the most important crops for the development of the ancient civilizations of North and South America.

DOC.Title: Mesoamerican civilization
DOC.TEXT: Generic name of ancient civilization that occurred from the Mexican plateau to the Central American belt.

DOC.Title: Teotihuacan civilization
DOC.TEXT: Ancient city civilization developed in Teotihuacan in the northeast of Mexico City in the 2nd-6th centuries ago.

DOC.Title: Maya civilization
DOC.TEXT: Civilization of the Yucatan peninsula flourished around the 4 th to 14 th century. The 10th-13th century was at its height, but it was conquered by the Spanish of the 16th century.

DOC.Title: Aztec empire, Aztec kingdom, Aztec civilization
DOC.TEXT: In the 12th and 16 th centuries, Tenochtitlan flourished in the Mexican plateau, but in 1521 Spain's Cortes was conquered.

DOC.Title: Aztec tribe
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic groups who played the Aztec civilization.

DOC.Title: Tenochtitlan
DOC.TEXT: City of Aztec kingdom. Although it was a magnificent stone city, it was occupied by Cortes in 1521.

DOC.Title: Cortes
DOC.TEXT: Spanish conquistador (Conquistador). 1519 I landed on the Yucatan Peninsula with a few soldiers and reduced the Kingdom of Aztec in 1521. In 23 years he was appointed to the governor of the area, but his later years were unfriendly.

DOC.Title: conquest of Mexico
DOC.TEXT: By Cortes. In 1521 Azteca was destroyed, civilization was destroyed.

DOC.Title: Andean civilization
DOC.TEXT: Generic name of ancient civilization that occurred in the Andean mountain range in South America.

DOC.Title: Inca Empire, Inca civilization
DOC.TEXT: An empire (civilization) built by the Incas (also known as the Quechua) in the Andean plateau. Advanced civilization flourished mainly in Cusco of the capital, but was destroyed by Spanish conquistor Pizarro in 1533.

DOC.Title: Keep, tie rope
DOC.TEXT: A way to show meaning / quantity (decimal) by rope knotting method. It was used in the record of the state in the Inca Empire.

DOC.Title: Pizarro
DOC.TEXT: Spanish conquistador (Conquistador). Attacked the Inca Empire with the help of Carlos I, executed the Emperor in 1533, and destroyed the Empire. Infamous for Indio's genocide and gold and silver looting, it was assassinated by internal conflict.

DOC.Title: Conquest of Peru
DOC.TEXT: By Pizarro. The Inca Empire was destroyed, the Inca civilization was destroyed. Acquisition of a large amount of precious metals (especially silver) has made the direction of the management of the continental continent of Spain to mining management.

DOC.Title: Potosi Silver Mine
DOC.TEXT: It was discovered in 1545, the largest silver mountain in the Americas of southern Bolivia. A large amount of silver mined here was sent to Europe, a price revolution occurred.

DOC.Title: Silver fleet
DOC.TEXT: A Spanish fleet carrying silver drawn in the Americas to Europe. After the end of the 16th century, it shrank in response to the attack by my captured ship in the Netherlands and the UK.

DOC.Title: Acapulco Trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade that Spain made on Acapulco (Mexico) on the Pacific coast as a starting point. In Manila, the Philippines, I traded Chinese silk and ceramics with silver.

DOC.Title: Acapulco
DOC.TEXT: The port city of Mexico.

DOC.Title: Galleon trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade by Galleon ship. The Spanish Acapulco trade is the main one.

DOC.Title: Galleon ship
DOC.TEXT: A sailing ship Western European countries used in overseas trade in the 15th-16th century. It was also used in Acapulco trade.

DOC.Title: Black guy
DOC.TEXT: Mainly black people brought from Africa to overwork in plantations and mines in the West · West Indies. As the Indian population drastically decreased due to forced labor and plague in the 16th century, it was required as an alternative labor force, and the number was increased from 16 to 19 century centered on people with the most working age, It is estimated to go up to people. It was one of the major causes of poverty in Africa today.

DOC.Title: Assent, Supply Contract for Supply
DOC.TEXT: The supply contract of the black guy who the Spanish government tied with a foreign merchant. Because it was a contract that can expect huge profits, each Western Europe developed a fierce competition.

DOC.Title: Encompassing system
DOC.TEXT: Land system Spain adopted in the Americas since around 1503. The King of Spain acknowledged the colonizer to serve as a labor force on condition that the indigenous people of the conquested place were to be Christianized. However, colonists overwhelmed the Indio, which caused a drastic decrease in their population and declined in the second half of the 16th century.

DOC.Title: Las = Casas
DOC.TEXT: A Spanish Dominican monk. Reported the miserable situation of Indio to the Spanish King, and worked hard to prevent Indio's slurred.

DOC.Title: "Brief report on the destruction of Indias"
DOC.TEXT: Report to the Spanish King Carlos I, written by Las Casas in 1552. Encompassing the enviroment system, thereby intensely impeaching the overuse of Indio.

DOC.Title: Hacienda system
DOC.TEXT: A land system developed in the Spanish colony of Latin America. A large farming system with debt slavery as the main labor force spreading on behalf of the encompassing system in the 17th-18th century.

DOC.Title: Plantation
DOC.TEXT: A large plantation system that mainly produces commodity crops for export, spread in colonies and semi colonies. In Latin America it became popular as an Hacienda system. In sugar cane cultivation, it appeared in the Caribbean islands at the end of the 16th century.

DOC.Title: The Great Voyage Age
DOC.TEXT: In the 15 th to the 17 th century, Western Europeans began to advance into the Indian Ocean and the Atlantic region by voyage and exploration. Portuguese and Spain opened up, the Netherlands followed it, and then triggered the spread of commercial activities on a global scale.

DOC.Title: Commercial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: With the development of the New Route and the arrival in the Americas, the origin of the product, the type and quantity of the products, etc. have expanded from the conventional European scale to the global scale including the Asia-Americas, and the unity of the world centered on Europe This means that the conversion was promoted. As a result, the center of the European economy moved from the northern Italian city to the Atlantic coastal city.

DOC.Title: Lisbon
DOC.TEXT: The capital of Portugal. Through the 16th century after the establishment of the Indian Passage, it prospered primarily through spice trading. Along with Spain's Sepya Cadis and Paros, he occupied the headquarters in world trade, but in 17th century his position was robbed in Amsterdam.

DOC.Title: Amsterdam
DOC.TEXT: River port city in the northern part of the Spanish Netherlands. After the decline of Antwerpen, it became the center of prosperity of the Netherlands, and after the independence of the Netherlands it has become the most important city not only as a capital but also economically.

DOC.Title: Antwerp, Antwerp
DOC.TEXT: A major port city in northern Belgium. It began to develop from around the 12th century, and joined the Hanseatic League early in the 14th century. It became Spain territory from the first half of the 16th century, prospering more than any port city in the home by woolen exports to the Americas. It was destroyed by the Spanish army in 1585 during the Netherlands Revolutionary War, and gave that position to Amsterdam.

DOC.Title: Price Revolution
DOC.TEXT: A large quantity of precious metal (silver) flowed in from the Americas since the middle of the 16th century, the silver price in Europe declined and the price rose. Commercial work in the western countries has come of age, while declining the downfall of the rich man and South Southern European capital that monopolized silver in southern German, declined the loser of the lord who lived in the money rent .

DOC.Title: "Modern world system"
DOC.TEXT: It is a worldwide division of labor, established from the modern era as commercial activity spreads on a global scale. In this system, the world is divided into rich countries / areas that are positioned as "core" and poor countries / areas called "surroundings", and large movements of the world can be captured from the opposing relationship between the two. In the mid-1970 's, American historian Wallerstein gave the idea of ​​spreading.

DOC.Title: "core"
DOC.TEXT: A powerful country / region with rich capital and high technology. By trade with "neighboring" under favorable conditions, we will maintain richness. It is typified by Western Europe, but in rare cases it rises to "core" from "surroundings", or conversely it falls from "core" to "surrounding".

DOC.Title: "Surrounding"
DOC.TEXT: It is a country or region where capital is scarce and technical skill. It is hard to get out of poverty because strong powerful "core" countries can be supplied with industrial raw materials and food under unfavorable conditions.

DOC.Title: Gut Hell Shaft
DOC.TEXT: A large farm where the landlord aristocrat manages mainly utilizing the farmer's labor labor to produce cereals for export. Developed in Eastern Europe (mainly Prussia) which lagged behind commercial and industrial compared to Western Europe.

DOC.Title: Reproductive serfdom regulation
DOC.TEXT: Around the 16th century, a serfdom system developed in Eastern Europe (mainly in Prussia and Poland). The Eastern European lord went through a large farm management that imparts imputation labor to farmers to respond to the expansion of grain exports to Western Europe.

DOC.Title: Renaissance
DOC.TEXT: Beginning in Italy from the 14th to the 16th century, a new movement on art and thought spread all over the Western Europe. It means "reproduction" in French, and it is translated as "literary revival". Taking the cultures of ancient Greek and Roman as an example, a shift from a medieval world view centered on God and church to a new human-centered view of the world was sought. Thus, although it is generally regarded as the starting point of modernity, it is also pointed out that there are aristocratic and conservative aspects.

DOC.Title: Italy = Renaissance
DOC.TEXT: Renaissance developed in Italy centered around the 14th-15th century. Italy was the area where the Renaissance began for the first time, but there are (1) the influx of advanced Byzantine culture and Islamic culture advanced since the Crusade, (2) Prosperity, increased civil consciousness, (3) that Italy was the place of Roman culture, and so on. In content, it was outstanding in artistic aspects such as art and architecture, and had a great influence on all parts of the Western region, but also had a conservative aspect because the nobility and the pope were asylum. In the first half of the sixteenth century, the center of trade moved from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic coast and declined rapidly due to the fact that it became the stage of Italian fight against Italian warfare by Western powers.

DOC.Title: Florence
DOC.TEXT: Urban republic of the Tuscan plains. Producing woolen fabrics · Toast trading · Finance industry and others, the millionaire as a Medici family came out and became the center of the Italian-Renaissance.

DOC.Title: Medici family
DOC.TEXT: Florence's millionaire, the family who became the Renaissance's largest asylum. Successfully accumulated in the financial industry from the end of the 14th century, 1434 Cosimo became head of the state of the Republic of Florence, its grandkids Lorenzo held the power to behave as a tyrant, also tried to protect the literature and art. As a result, Florence became the center of the Renaissance. Catherine of Roman papacy Leo X and Princess Henry II of French was also from the Medici family.

DOC.Title: Cosimo = De-Medici
DOC.TEXT: He became the head of the Medici family and pushed the Medici family to a true millionaire, and he himself took the position of head of state of the Republic of Florence. Through the opening of the Academy (Plato Gakuen) and the library, we have also made great achievements in the development of the Renaissance.

DOC.Title: Academy, Platon Academy
DOC.TEXT: It was a research institution established by Cosimo de Médici, caught the academic research of ancient Greece (especially Plato and later New Bratonism), and had a great influence on the Renaissance.

DOC.Title: Lorenzo-de-Medici
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Medici family in the most prosperous period of Florence. While acting as a tyrant in the Republic, she protected numerous artists and humanists, bringing the heyday of the Italian-Renaissance.

DOC.Title: Duke of Milano
DOC.TEXT: In particular, Rodovico Sforza, who played an active role at the end of the 15th century, became a temporary stronghold of Leonardo da Vinci and was famous as a powerful monarch in Italy during the Renaissance period.

DOC.Title: Humanism, Humanism
DOC.TEXT: Through learning the classics of the Greek-Roman era, the fundamental thought of the Renaissance period, which departs from the medieval Christian asceticism and affirms human beings as they are. Specifically, through the literature, criticisms or art works of the Renaissance period, we positively expressed various human desires and nakedness.

DOC.Title: Dante
DOC.TEXT: Born in a Republican aristocracy in Florence. Italian = pioneer of the Renaissance. Announced epic "Shinsei" around 1293. In 1302 he was exiled from the political world and wrote "imperial theory" "god song" during the wandering, and died in Ravenna.

DOC.Title: "Shinsei"
DOC.TEXT: Dante's work around 1293. The story of the experience of Dante's mysterious love for the girl Beatrice.

DOC.Title: "Shinkyou"
DOC.TEXT: A large epic of Tuscan written by Dante during the wandering period between 1304 and 21 years. The theme of the authors themselves being led by ancient Roman poet Vergilius, surrounding hell, purgatory, and heavenly world. It is penetrated with Dante's own unique values ​​by Catholic world view.

DOC.Title: Tuscan
DOC.TEXT: It is a colloquial of the Tuscan region and developed into the current Italian language. "Kamikyoku" is written in this word, it is regarded as the first work of modern citizen literature.

DOC.Title: Petrarcha
DOC.TEXT: Italian-Renaissance early poet and humanist. Praising the ancient Rome, working hard to collect and revive the classics, it became the origin of a kind of ancient boom. Major works include 'lyric poetry' and poetry 'Africa' longing for ancient Rome.

DOC.Title: Boccacio
DOC.TEXT: A child of a merchant in Florence. I tried to create as a humanist, studied the Greek classics, for the first time translated Homer's into Latin. I also had friends with Petrarch. The masterpiece is "Decameron".

DOC.Title: "Decameron"
DOC.TEXT: A representative work of Boccaccio. Work of 1348 to 53 years. A satirical short story collection of social and human depictions. It is called "human song" against Dante's "divine song", and is regarded as a prototype of modern novel.

DOC.Title: Machiavelli
DOC.TEXT: Politicians and historians of Florence who played active part in domestic affairs and diplomacy at the Republican government after Savonarola's loss. I insisted in the book "monarch theory" the need to advance realistic politics separated from religion and morality. It is regarded as a pioneer of modern political science.

DOC.Title: "Principality"
DOC.TEXT: Representative work of Machiavelli. Written around 1513 and published in 1932. In order to cope with the crisis of invasion of the centralized central powers, it is urgent task of unification of Italy, therefore, "people who are both unrelated to religion and morality, who are both lion braveness and fox's wickedness are necessary" He insisted. It is regarded as a pioneering work of modern political science.

DOC.Title: Machiavellism
DOC.TEXT: Generally speaking, it refers to the practice of pragmatism, which means a method that does not choose any means for the purpose. However, the "prince theory" is not a general statement of political science, it is a work created in the concrete consideration of how to achieve Italy's unification in order to protect Italy from the invasion of neighboring countries .

DOC.Title: Giot
DOC.TEXT: Italian-Renaissance early painter. Starting with Renaissance style paintings, it is regarded as the father of modern Italian paintings. "Lifetime of St. Francis" in his masterpiece.

DOC.Title: Renaissance architecture
DOC.TEXT: Renaissance architectural style. In the sacred architecture, it features a large crown and a column pillar, and it has a sense of stability and excitement. Many of the houses emphasized the horizontal line.

DOC.Title: Brunelleschi
DOC.TEXT: Early Renaissance architect. We completed the large fornix of Santa Maria Cathedral, which is said to be "the pride of Florence".

DOC.Title: Santa Maria Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Early Renaissance style architecture. Brunelleschi's masterpiece. It is in Florence.

DOC.Title: Ghiberti
DOC.TEXT: A sculptor. I started a free reality.

DOC.Title: Dontero
DOC.TEXT: A sculptor. I established a Renaissance style.

DOC.Title: Bramante
DOC.TEXT: Renaissance's largest architect. The first designer of Saint-Peter's new building.

DOC.Title: St. Peter's Basilica, St. Peter's Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: It is the world 's largest cathedral adjacent to the Vatican, the Catholic headquarters. Construction began in the era of Julius II at the beginning of the 16th century and Leo X emphasized the indulgent sales to raise the fund. Bamante · Raffaro · Michelangelo representing Italy · Renaissance was also involved in this design and construction.

DOC.Title: Botticelli
DOC.TEXT: Italian-Renaissance medium-term painter. Many works depicting women's beauty openly, under the protection of the Medici family.

DOC.Title: "Birth of Venus"
DOC.TEXT: A representative work by Botticelli. Famous for ladies beauty along with "spring".

DOC.Title: "Spring"
DOC.TEXT: Botticelli's work.

DOC.Title: Leonardo da Vinci
DOC.TEXT: Painter / scientist in the Renaissance period. Originating from the village of Vinci on the outskirts of Florence, in addition to leaving masterpieces of paintings such as "Mona-Lisa" "Last Supper", it is also excellent in natural sciences and various technologies, the ideal man's image of the Renaissance "genius genius" It is made to be typical. Activities at various courts, etc, and was led to Francis I and died while staying in France.

DOC.Title: "Last Supper"
DOC.TEXT: Between 1495 and 98, Da Vinci painted as a mural painting of the Cathedral of St. Mary-Della-Grazie in Milan. A piece depicting the dramatic appearance of the last dinner between Christ and the twelve apostles on the eve of passion.

DOC.Title: "Mona-Lisa"
DOC.TEXT: A famous female figure drawn by Da Vinci around 1503-06. It is known for its mysterious smile's beauty.

DOC.Title: Vatican Palace
DOC.TEXT: It is a palace with the Roman Catholic Church in the city of Rome, the center of Catholicism. Among them, St. Peter's Basilica, which underwent reconstruction in the era of Julius II, is the most important.

DOC.Title: Sistine Chapel
DOC.TEXT: The main chapel in the Vatican Palace. Constructed in 1473-81 by the life of Pope Sixtus IV, the design is Giovanni de Dee d'etci. There are many painters' mural paintings, but Michelangelo's mural paintings are most famous among them.

DOC.Title: Michelangelo
DOC.TEXT: Sculptor, painter, architect representing Renaissance. He was active mainly in Florence and Rome. A masterpiece such as marble statue 'Davide', 'Situation of the Sistine Chapel' "Creation of the heavens and the earth" "Last Judgment".

DOC.Title: "Davide"
DOC.TEXT: A marble statue of young Michelangelo work. Work of 1501-04. I expressed the spirit of freedom and independence through the youth's nude statue.

DOC.Title: "Creation of the heavens and the earth"
DOC.TEXT: A large wall painting of the Sistine Chapel ceiling that Mauritius Peter Julianus II compelled to paint in Michelangelo around 1508-12. The Old Testament consists of the story of the century.

DOC.Title: "Moses"
DOC.TEXT: Michelangelo's masterpiece. A marble statue produced as a sculpture at the center of the tombstone of Pope Julius II.

DOC.Title: "Last Judgment"
DOC.TEXT: The large altarpiece in front of the Sistine Chapel, produced by Michelangelo from 1535 to 1941.

DOC.Title: Raffaello
DOC.TEXT: Representative painter of the Renaissance. In addition to many "Virgin and Child statues", "Athens' school" is famous.

DOC.Title: Humanists, humanists
DOC.TEXT: It refers to poet, literary and critic who played an active part in the Renaissance period from the standpoint of humanism (humanism). I respect the classics of the Greek-Roman era and created a work that depicts human beings and the real society as they are, apart from the old moral views ruled by the church.

DOC.Title: Erasmus
DOC.TEXT: Originally from the Netherlands, the largest humanist in the 16th century, who is familiar with classics and theology. Initially it severely satanized the corruption of Catholicism and had a great influence on the development of religious reform, but he did not participate in the religious reform which increased intensely, and conflicted with Luther.

DOC.Title: "Praise of folly god"
DOC.TEXT: 1509 The main work of Erasmus. I satirized the bastard of the clergy and the royal prince pursuing the power of this world with a goddess of bizarre grudgingly.

DOC.Title: Flanders school
DOC.TEXT: Painters who played an active part in the Flemish region since the end of the 14th century. It deepened the realism of Gothic style. Fan-Ike brothers representative.

DOC.Title: Fan = Ike brothers
DOC.TEXT: Flemish painter and improved oil painting technique. Many religious paintings and portraits.

DOC.Title: Bruegel
DOC.TEXT: Flemish painter. While expressing the vivid figure and nature of the farmers graphically, I painted the work with the truth sharply in it in many oil paintings and copperplate prints.

DOC.Title: Dürer
DOC.TEXT: German = Renaissance pioneering painter. Featuring a heavy sunken style that makes you feel deep spirituality. I left many prints.

DOC.Title: "Four apostles"
DOC.TEXT: Durer work in 1526.

DOC.Title: Kranakha
DOC.TEXT: A German painter. I talked with Luther, especially portraits of religious reformers.

DOC.Title: Holbaine
DOC.TEXT: A German painter. After working in Germany and Italy, I went to England and became a court painter of the King Henry VIII era. It is famous for portrait of Henry VII · Erasmus · Thomas Moir.

DOC.Title: Leuhillin
DOC.TEXT: German humanist. I extended classical research to Hebrew.

DOC.Title: François I
DOC.TEXT: French Valois dynasty ninth king (ranking 1515-47). The Holy Roman Emperor Karl V fought fiercely with the Italian war and the like. He also introduced the Renaissance to France, becoming an Asylum of Leonardo da Vinci, and was called "Father of France = Renaissance".

DOC.Title: Rabelais
DOC.TEXT: A representative writer in the early French-Renaissance era, rich in humanistic culture. The core business is a doctor.

DOC.Title: "The story of Gargantua and Pan tag Ruel"
DOC.TEXT: Two part copies of Rabelais published from 1532 to 64 years. Drawn a hypothetically simple way of living hypothetical huge natural girl Gargantua and her child bread tag Ruel, satire the social classes.

DOC.Title: Montaigne
DOC.TEXT: French humanist. Observe precisely the state of human life and spirit. In the midst of religious reform, Mayor Bordeaux was inferred, and he struggled to mediate the Huguenot war. Rationalism and modern thought are characteristic.

DOC.Title: "Memorial Record"
DOC.TEXT: A collection of essays autographed by Montaigne from 1580 to 1988. Works returning to the public and private life, seeing the self, pursuing humanity, quietly speaking.

DOC.Title: Cervantes
DOC.TEXT: Representative writer of Spain = Renaissance. Injured in the Lepanto war, then became a prisoner of war, after a professional occasion, expressed a contradiction in the turbulent Spanish society in a piece full of humor and persistence.

DOC.Title: "Don Quijote"
DOC.TEXT: Work written by Cervantes in 1605-16. A funny story created by the knight era Knight Don Quijote full of justice and the real owner Sancho Pangsa. Representative of Spanish satire literature.

DOC.Title: Chaucer
DOC.TEXT: British = pioneering writer of the Renaissance. I learned from Italy and touched Boccaccio's work. My main business was a poet and experienced civil service life as well.

DOC.Title: "Canterbury Story"
DOC.TEXT: A story that Chaucer wrote in 1387-1400. Although it is a British version of "Decameron", characters and subjects are extremely popular.

DOC.Title: Thomas = More
DOC.TEXT: British politician / humanist. He worked as a lawyer and politician, and it climbed to the position of a great bureaucrat who is the highest government position at the time, but opposed to the divorce of Henry VIII, it was executed. He had deep friendship with Erasmus.

DOC.Title: "Utopia"
DOC.TEXT: Work made by Moret in 1516. Drawn a fictitious ideal social utopia, criticized the politics and society thoroughly satire, criticizing the British gift principle at the time. Especially criticism against "enclosure" is famous.

DOC.Title: Shakespeare
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth's greatest poet and playwright. Hamlet "" Othello "" Macbeth "" Leah King ", including the four great tragedies, comedy and historical theaters, left 36 pieces of work. Especially his tragedy is said to be the highest level alongside the Greek tragedy.

DOC.Title: "Merchant of Venice"
DOC.TEXT: Comedy which Shakespeare wrote in 1596-97. The struggle between Venice 's merchant Antonio and Sharok Royalty was focused on the scenes in both courts.

DOC.Title: "Hamlet"
DOC.TEXT: Character tragedy that Shakespeare wrote in 1600-01. The revenge of Danish Prince who was killed by his father is content.

DOC.Title: Three major inventions
DOC.TEXT: It refers to compass, gunpowder, letterpress printing technique. Both are originated from China, but since the 14th century, practical application advanced in Western Europe. To be precise, not an invention, but an improvement.

DOC.Title: Gunpowder, Firearm
DOC.TEXT: Gunpowder has been put to practical use in gold and former, passed through the Islamic world, and transmitted to the western Europe of the 13th century. It was used for cannons and guns and urged the fall of the knight class as the tactics changed.

DOC.Title: gun
DOC.TEXT: A firearm that appeared in South Germany in 1381. Practical application was in the latter part of the 15th century, and it was considerably popular in the 16th century. The main force of battle was transferred from knight to farmer.

DOC.Title: Rashinban
DOC.TEXT: Things that have been put into practical use at the Song Dynasty are seen to have propagated to the west via Islam. Late in the 14th century, it was improved in Italy, greatly advancing ocean navigation techniques and urged European overseas expansion.

DOC.Title: Paper making method
DOC.TEXT: China was improved to Han Dynasty. It was transmitted to the Islamic world in the 8th century, to the Western Europe around the 12th century, and the use rapidly spread instead of the old parchment.

DOC.Title: Typographical printing
DOC.TEXT: Type printing was in Song, metal type was put to practical use in Goryeo in the 13th century. In Western Europe, an alloy type of lead and tin was invented in the mid-15th century, and a technique for printing by making a letterpress was developed. Due to the spread of the papermaking method, we made books quick and inexpensive, contributing to dissemination of ideas and knowledge. It also had a major impact on religious reform.

DOC.Title: Gutenberg
DOC.TEXT: Founder of German typography. The founding age is about 1450, and prints such as "the 42nd Bible" are famous. Promoted popularization of cheap books (especially the Bible), and had a great influence on religious reform.

DOC.Title: Copernicus
DOC.TEXT: Clerics and astronomers of Poland. Giant theory based on astronomical observations brought about a revolutionary change in astronomy. However, it was just before that death that I agreed to publish "Theory of Celestial Spinning".

DOC.Title: "Theory of celestial rotation"
DOC.TEXT: Book of Copernicus. Aristotle · Ptolemy and others preaching the theory of the earth that denies the earthly center of cosmology. Published in 1543.

DOC.Title: Ground Theory
DOC.TEXT: Copernicus convinced around 1530, a view of the universe that recognizes the rotation and revolution of the earth. The church that took the theory of heavenly fiercely opposed, and it took about 100 years before Newton appeared to be recognized for its correctness.

DOC.Title: Tianyary Theory
DOC.TEXT: It is a church authorized doctrine that the earth is the immovable center of the universe and was believed throughout the Middle Ages.

DOC.Title: Giordano-Bruno
DOC.TEXT: Italian scholar. He claimed pantheism and the theory of motion and was sentenced to burning by a religious trial.

DOC.Title: Galilei, Galileo Galilei
DOC.TEXT: Astronomer / physicist who was born in Pisa, active in Florence etc. I discovered the isochronism of the pendulum, the law of object falling, and I was convinced of the theory of the theory by observing Jupiter's satellite with a telescope that I improved. However, in 1633, he was sentenced to a religious trial and was sentenced to life imprisonment for criminal sins (actually being in a state of embargo), and the theory of referee was denied.

DOC.Title: Kepler
DOC.TEXT: German astronomer. Early in the 17th century I confirmed the laws of planetary operation (Kepler's three laws) and laid the foundation for modern astronomy.

DOC.Title: Religious Reform
DOC.TEXT: Criticism and reform movement towards Catholicism, which was developed in Europe in the 16th century. Germany, Switzerland, the United Kingdom etc, denied the doctrine and institution of the old Catholic church, aimed at establishing a new Christian doctrine and institution. From this time on, reformers are referred to as New Orthodox and Catholics as Old.

DOC.Title: Leo XIII
DOC.TEXT: Pope (from 1513 to 21) from the Medici family. I liked luxury and permitted the release of a letter of appreciation in the German province because of the building cost of St. Peter's Cathedral, creating a direct cause of German religious reform.

DOC.Title: St. Peter's Basilica, St. Peter's Cathedral
