DOC.TEXT: French, Prussia joined Bayern Saxony Spain, who was dissatisfied with the succession of the Habsburg family in Maria-Theresia, and the war batted by the British standing on the Austrian side. With Aachen's sum about approval of the possession of Shreijen by Prussia and Marais Terezia's succession to the Habsburg family ended.

DOC.Title: Schlesjen, Silesia
DOC.TEXT: In the area where industries and mining are inaccurate, then Austrian territory (now Polish territory). In Austria succession war Prussia took away from Austria, and was authorized ownership by Aachen sum.

DOC.Title: diplomatic revolution
DOC.TEXT: The conflicting relationship between Austria (Habsburg Family) and France (Valois and Bourbones), which has been continuing since the Italian War, has changed significantly into cooperative relations. In order to advance the war with Prussia advantageously, Marie = Terezia called for a partnership with France.

DOC.Title: Seven Years War
DOC.TEXT: The war between isolated Prussia and the Austrian camp. Prussia isolated by the diplomatic revolution fought with a first strike with British aid, but continued to struggle with enemies such as France, Spain, Russia and others. However, in 1762 the Russian troops dropped out and overseas colonies France lost to the UK, Prussia was out of danger, and in 63 years Austria and Hubertusburg treaty alone procured, securing Shreijen.

DOC.Title: Enlightenment tyrants, enlightenment absolute monarch
DOC.TEXT: Absolute tyrant who tried to modernize (dominate) its own country under the influence of enlightenment thought. Friedrich II, Joseph II, Ecachelina II and others are representative.

DOC.Title: Voltaire
DOC.TEXT: French Enlightenment Thinker. I contacted and corresponded frequently with Friedrich II and Ecachelina II, and conveyed my own enlightenment thought.

DOC.Title: "Prince is the country's first servant", "Prince is the country's first servant"
DOC.TEXT: Enlightenment tyranny The word that Friedrich II said to have said. It is famous for mentioning the position of the enlightenment tyrant, which the monarch himself leads and advances modernization of the state (strengthening).

DOC.Title: Berlin
DOC.TEXT: The capital of the Federal Republic of Germany. It became the center city of Brandenburg since the 15th century, and since the beginning of the 18th century it prospered as the capital of the Prussian Kingdom.

DOC.Title: Junker
DOC.TEXT: A landlord aristocrat in the eastern part of the Elbe River in Germany. Through the management of Guz Hell Shaft, the exclusive bureaucracy and the monopoly of military officers, it became the main force of Prussia society.

DOC.Title: Gut Hell Shaft
DOC.TEXT: Farm lord. Farm management style where the landlord aristocrat converts free farmers into agricultural crops and produces cereals for export to Western Europe due to their labor labor. With the development of Western capitalist production, since the 16th century, developed in Prussia east of the Elbe River.

DOC.Title: Reproductive serfdom regulation
DOC.TEXT: A serf system developed around Prussia from the 16th century. Junker took charge of fertilizer on Goult Hell Shaft with imparting labor.

DOC.Title: Joseph II
DOC.TEXT: He was the eldest son of Maria-Theresia, became a co-ruler after 1765, after 80 years after his mother's parents. I developed a policy of enlightenment such as a serf liberation order and a religious tolerance age, but failed due to the rebellion of conservatives and territories inside the court.

DOC.Title: Agricultural Release Liberation Order
DOC.TEXT: In 1781 Josef II issued. Farmer's personal freedom was recognized, and freedom of movement and marriage was given. However, without paying money, the liberation from the duty to grant was not acknowledged, the conservatives' resistance was strong, and was interrupted by the death of Josef II.

DOC.Title: religious tolerance age
DOC.TEXT: In 1781 Josef II issued. Allowed non-Catholics also the freedom of religion.

DOC.Title: Stencer = Rajin
DOC.TEXT: Don Cossack leader. He instructed the farmers' rebellion from 1670 to 71 years, spreading temporary power from the Volga River downstream to the south coast of the Caspian Sea, but was defeated and died of death.

DOC.Title: Peter I, Peter the Great
DOC.TEXT: Emperor who established Russian absolute monarchy (ranking 1682-1725). He tried to make Russia Westernized and modernized, including doing its own Western tour. Defeated Sweden in the Northern War, held the hegemony of the Baltic Sea, during that time, built the new capital Petersburg.

DOC.Title: Treaty of Nerchinsk
DOC.TEXT: In the treaty of the border demarcation of Russia and Chima, the Stanovoy Mountain Range (Xinghai Anling) was border. In China 's first foreign territory treaty, contents favorable to the Qing Dynasty.

DOC.Title: Azov Sea
DOC.TEXT: Utsumi of the northeast part of the Black Sea. Until the end of the 17th century the Ottoman Empire was dominated, in 1696 Peter I occupied.

DOC.Title: Petersburg, Sankt-Petersburg
DOC.TEXT: Located in the mouth of the Neva river, facing the Baltic Sea. Peter John I started construction in 1703, became the capital in 12 years.

DOC.Title: "Window to Western Europe"
DOC.TEXT: Another name for the new capital, Petersburg. It was called from the flow of Western culture through this harbor.

DOC.Title: Baltic Sea
DOC.TEXT: Utsumi of Northeast Europe. In the Middle Ages it was important as a stage for the activities of Vikings and Hanseatic League. After the Thirty Years War, Sweden was under control, but was defeated by the Northern War and retreated, and the Russian forces newly expanded.

DOC.Title: Northern War
DOC.TEXT: Battle where Peter D I broke Denmark-Poland and beat Sweden, the powerful country of the Baltic Sea. Russia took over the hegemony of the Baltic Sea.

DOC.Title: Carl XII
DOC.TEXT: The Swedish King (ranking 1697-1718). He continued his winning streak in the Northern War, but he was defeated at Porta, after which he beat and killed the Norwegian army.

DOC.Title: Nistat treaty
DOC.TEXT: Peace treaty of the northern war, tied up in the Finnish city Nistat which touched the Baltic Sea. Russia acquired the land of the east coast of the Baltic Sea, made advance into the Baltic Sea, and began to walk to the power of Europe. The defeated Sweden lost hegemony in this area.

DOC.Title: Okhotsk Sea
DOC.TEXT: Utsumi in northwest Pacific. In the first half of the 17th century, Russian forces collided with the Qing after reaching this area, and the Neltinsk treaty was concluded between the two countries at the end of the 17th century. Later in 1713, a route to Kamchatka was also developed.

DOC.Title: Bering
DOC.TEXT: An explorer born in Denmark. He served Peter I, and later confirmed the Bering Strait in 1728. I also went exploring Kamchatka twice, but he died on the way.

DOC.Title: Alaska
DOC.TEXT: A big peninsula located in the northwest of North American continent. In 1741 Bering reached Russian territory, but it was sold to the United States in 1867.

DOC.Title: Kurishima
DOC.TEXT: An island that runs from the east end of Hokkaido to the Kamchatka peninsula. It was owned by Russia at the end of the 18th century.

DOC.Title: Laxman
DOC.TEXT: Russian soldier. He returned to Nemuro in 1792, Hakodate in 1993, repatriated Japanese drifters, requested trade, but was refused.

DOC.Title: Ecachelina II
DOC.TEXT: Empress of Russia. He was born in Germany and was the princess of Peter the 3rd, but became the emperor (ranking 1762 to 96) by the coup d'etat. Enlightenment tyrant who loved French culture, received advice through correspondence with Voltaire, and made various reforms such as protection of academic arts, educational reform, improvement of law. However, after the rebellion of Pugachev and the French Revolution, it was rebounded and the reforms were incomplete. It also played a central role in three Polish divisions.

DOC.Title: Crimea Peninsula
DOC.TEXT: Peninsula in north coast of Black Sea. In the 15th-18th century, Klim-Han country remained under the influence of the Ottoman empire, but it was annexed to Russia.

DOC.Title: Klim = Han country
DOC.TEXT: Muslim school on the north coast of the Black Sea. In 1502 Russia and destroyed Kipchak-Han country. Then prospered under the rule of the Ottoman Empire, it was annexed to Russia in the second half of the 18th century.

DOC.Title: Pugachev's rebellion
DOC.TEXT: Pocachov (from around 1742-75), a poor farmer from Cossack, faced a peasant rebellion in Southern Russia, who cheated Peter the 3rd name. I tried to eliminate the serfdom system and liberate from the Russian rule, but Pugachev was executed and the rebellion was suppressed.

DOC.Title: Yagaiwo Morning, Yagello Morning
DOC.TEXT: Medieval dynasty of Poland. It was established in the merger between Lithuania and Poland, boasting a strong prospect, such as breaking the Knights of Germany and pressing on the Grand Duchy of Moscow, and it has entered a golden era culturally.

DOC.Title: Election Official
DOC.TEXT: A system that was implemented in 1572, after the fall of Yaegao in Poland. It caused interference between major aristocracy and foreign countries, causing Poland to decline.

DOC.Title: Shruffter
DOC.TEXT: Lords of Poland · small aristocrats. He was granted various veto rights at the social status parliament at the time of the election campaign and had strong political power.

DOC.Title: Poland division
DOC.TEXT: The first was conducted by Prussia, Austria and Russia, the second was done by Prussia and Russia, using the turmoil of the French Revolution, the third was done by the three countries, the Kingdom of Poland had disappeared.

DOC.Title: Kosushiko
DOC.TEXT: Patriots and soldiers in Poland. He participated in the American Revolutionary War and became active as an assistant to Washington. From 1793 he taught the Polish anti-division struggle, and at one time he played an active part in breaking the Russian army but was injured and caught, the homeland Poland was also destroyed. After the release, we strove to restore the independence of Poland, after that death it became a symbol of Polish liberation.

DOC.Title: colony
DOC.TEXT: In areas outside the home country, colonized and conquered domestic territory. Since the end of the 15th century, the European countries advanced to the Americas and Asia-Africa, beginning with Spain, Portugal, and conquered and abused indigenous people, but from the end of the 16th century the Netherlands, France and the UK became fierce colonies I tried to expand by fighting a battle.

DOC.Title: Goa
DOC.TEXT: Harbor City on the West Bank of India Since 1510, it became the home of Portugal 's advance to Asia.

DOC.Title: Albuquerque
DOC.TEXT: Portuguese soldier, the second generation Indian Governor (Vice King). He succeeded Almeida and occupied Goa and Melaka, he was active in colonial activities in the Asian region.

DOC.Title: Spice trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade between Europe that searches for spices and India / Southeast Asia that produces it. Islamic forces such as the Mamluk dynasty and the Ottoman empire had dominated this and gained great profits, but Portugal has newly entered since the end of the 15th century.

DOC.Title: diow
DOC.TEXT: The land on the west coast of India. Portugal under command of Almeida in this offshore defeated coalition forces centered on the Mamluk dynasty, and took control of the sea control of the Arabian Sea.

DOC.Title: Ceylon, Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: An island in the south of India. In 1505, Portugal occupied Colombo and was under control, but was robbed by the 17th century Holland.

DOC.Title: Melaka, Muraka
DOC.TEXT: The port city on the southwest coast of the Malay Peninsula. It was occupied by Portugal in 1511, and then the Dutch occupied in 1641.

DOC.Title: Molucca Archipelago, Marc Islands, Perfume Islands
DOC.TEXT: Spice producing area such as Dye Oka in eastern Indonesia. A Portuguese ship arrived in the beginning of the 16th century, monopolizing perfume trading, but control came to the Netherlands in the beginning of the 17th century.

DOC.Title: East Timor
DOC.TEXT: A country in the eastern part of Timor Island, which is linked to Indonesia. Portuguese territory since the 16th century (Independence movement strengthened from 1975, referendum was supported, in 1999 the referendum was implemented in Indonesia suppressed).

DOC.Title: Guangzhou
DOC.TEXT: Harbor city in the southern part of China. Portuguese arrived in 1517 and began light and trade.

DOC.Title: Macao
DOC.TEXT: Small port in the south of Guangzhou. Around 1517 Portuguese arrived and was allowed to live in 1557, and became the basis of the opposition trade. 1887 officially became Portuguese territory.

DOC.Title: Tanegashima
DOC.TEXT: An island in the south of Kyushu. In 1543 Portuguese drifted, it is said that guns were transmitted to Japan at this time.

DOC.Title: Hirado
DOC.TEXT: Port of western Kyushu. 1550 Portuguese boat, 1609 Dutch ship arrived, prosperous in the Southwest trade, but it was replaced by Nagasaki afterwards.

DOC.Title: Nagasaki
DOC.TEXT: It flourished with the Hirado as a southern barbarian trade, but after the isolation nation (1639), it became a window for China and the Netherlands only.

DOC.Title: Manila
DOC.TEXT: The main harbor city of Luzon, the main island of the Philippines. Since 1571, it became the base for the management of the Philippines in Spain.

DOC.Title: East India Company, Dutch East India Company
DOC.TEXT: In 1602, a company established by a privileged merchant group. Monopolized the spice trade, became the center of promotion of East India management in the Netherlands including Java. It broke up in 1799.

DOC.Title: Java
DOC.TEXT: An island in the center of Indonesia. The Dutch arrived at the end of the 16th century, and in 1619 the Governor of East India was established and became the base for the entry into the East Asian Netherlands.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Banten
DOC.TEXT: Islamic school which occurred in the western part of Java in the first half of the 16th century. Prosperous in pepper trade.

DOC.Title: Batavia
DOC.TEXT: Current Jakarta. After the construction of the Dutch commercial building in 1619, the Governor General of the Netherlands was established and developed as the center of the formation of the Dutch East India.

DOC.Title: Mataram Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: An Islamic country built around the rice-producing area in the eastern part of Java.

DOC.Title: Dutch East Indies
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch colony which was formed ectopically since the beginning of the 17th century. It is almost the current Indonesian domain. Management by the East India Company mainly focused on the trade of waters from Japan to the Persian Gulf, with only Jawa and Molucca securing coastal cities. At the end of the 18th century, we turned to territorial expansion policy from before and after becoming a government controlled jurisdiction, and in Java, severe exploitation of residents such as compulsory cultivation system was done.

DOC.Title: Amboya Incident
DOC.TEXT: A case where the Netherlands slaughtered all British business associates (including employed Japanese) at Amboyaina in the Molucca islands and shut down the British forces from the Moluccas. After that Britain advanced to India direction.

DOC.Title: Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: Island located east of Mainland China. In 1624, the Netherlands occupied the first confusion of the Ming Dynasty, occupied by the Netherlands, but abandoned in 61 years, repulsed by Zheng success.

DOC.Title: East India Company, British East India Company
DOC.TEXT: Established in 1600, it is a patent company that monopolizes trade and colonial rights to the eastern Magellan Straits of the Cape of Good Hope. He focused on Indian management and promoted its colonization.

DOC.Title: Madras
DOC.TEXT: Seaport in southeastern India. Originated from the East India company building the fortress from 1639 to 40 years, it became one of the three major bases in India in the UK. It was renamed Chennai in 1996.

DOC.Title: Bombay
DOC.TEXT: The harbor city on the west coast of India. In 1661 the King of England was handed over from Portugal and transferred to East India Company in 1968. One of three major bases in India. It was renamed Mumbai in 1996.

DOC.Title: Calcutta
DOC.TEXT: Ogawa harbor city downstream of the Ganges River. It prospered since the East India Company in 1690 established a commercial hall. The main point of the fertile Bengal region. One of the three major bases.

DOC.Title: Commercial hegemony
DOC.TEXT: It is a state with overwhelming competitiveness in international trade. The Netherlands in the first half of the 17th century established this, but in the latter half of the 17th century it was rapidly progressed to Britain and France and lost.

DOC.Title: East India Company Rebuilding, France East India Company Rebuilding
DOC.TEXT: Colbert reorganized. I succeeded in entering India temporarily but lost to England and broke up in 1796.

DOC.Title: Pondicherry
DOC.TEXT: A place close to the base of England Madras. France wins from 1672 to 74 years. It returned to India in 1954.

DOC.Title: Chandelluñol
DOC.TEXT: A town in eastern India. It is close to UK base Kolkata, and in 1674 France was colonized. It returned to India in 1954.

DOC.Title: Duplex
DOC.TEXT: French Indian Governor. After overwhelming the British army in India since 1746, claimed the possibility of obtaining India, it was summoned to home country in 54 years.

DOC.Title: Carnatik War
DOC.TEXT: The third battle of England and France in the eastern coast of South India. 1744 ~ 48, 50 ~ 54, 58 ~ 61 (63) years. The British won, and the royal neighbor was also compressed.

DOC.Title: Seven Years War
DOC.TEXT: Although it was a war in Europe, England won the colonial war in Britain and France, Britain won the victory.

DOC.Title: Clive
DOC.TEXT: British East India company secretary / soldier. Victory at Placey's battle, becoming the first Bengal governor. I returned home after accumulating massive wealth, but I was accused of bribery, corruption and other charges and committed suicide.

DOC.Title: Battle of Plushy
DOC.TEXT: The British East India company army won the French · Bengal regional war coalition army by command of Clive. Britain 's Indian championship was decided, France retreated from India.

DOC.Title: West India Company, Holland West India Company
DOC.TEXT: In 1621, a company established with acquiring patent rights. I had a trade exclusive right in the Americas and Africa.

DOC.Title: New Netherlands, New Netherlands
DOC.TEXT: It was formed in the lower Hudson stream basin since 1614 and is the only Dutch colony in the Americas. In the year 64 it became British territory.

DOC.Title: New Amsterdam
DOC.TEXT: In 1625, the name of the town which the Dutchman built on the Manhattan island of the Hudson River. It became the center city of New Netherlands, and in 1653 he counted about 800 population. It flourished as a base for fur trading and colonial management, but became British territory in 1664, renamed New York.

DOC.Title: Cape colony
DOC.TEXT: After Portugal abandoned, 1652 Dutch East India Company started colonization as a base to Asia.

DOC.Title: Virginia
DOC.TEXT: Britain 's first colony in the Americas. In 1584-85 years Lori named after the virgin king Elizabeth I, founded but failed. In 1607, colonies with the same name but different in location were built.

DOC.Title: Lauri
DOC.TEXT: A British soldier who was loved by Elizabeth I and built a Virginia colony in North America. After that, he was executed with treason in the era of James I.

DOC.Title: Jamestown
DOC.TEXT: In 1607, successfully built in the era of James I, the first British colonial North America. It is also called the Virginia colony.

DOC.Title: New England
DOC.TEXT: Currently in the northeastern coast of the United States. Since Pilgrim-Father's of 1620, agricultural immigrants, mainly Puritans, were settled and formed.

DOC.Title: UK = Dutch war, British orchid war
DOC.TEXT: Contested maritime rights and colonies through the third order (1652-54, 65-67, 72-74) with the direct cause of the UK voyage law. It ended in UK dominance, and the Netherlands territory of the Americas was regarded mostly British.

DOC.Title: New York
DOC.TEXT: In 1664 England occupied New Amsterdam and renamed.

DOC.Title: West Indies
DOC.TEXT: An island running from the Gulf of Mexico to the Caribbean Sea. After reaching Columbus, it became Spain territory, plantation management of sugar and tobacco was started, but Britain and France expanded the dominated area in the 17th-18th century.

DOC.Title: Jamaica
DOC.TEXT: Caribbean island (one of the West Indies). It became British territory in 1655, sugarcane plantation management using black guys was done, bringing a great wealth to Britain. It also prospered as the biggest market for black fellows.

DOC.Title: Haiti
DOC.TEXT: Republic in the western part of the Caribbean Sea of ​​Espanola. French territory since the end of the 17th century was called Saint-Demang, sugarcane plantation management using black guys was done, bringing a great wealth to France.

DOC.Title: Louisiana
DOC.TEXT: A vast area of ​​the Mississippi River basin. Today 's state of Louisiana is only in the downstream area of ​​the Mississippi River. In 1682 the French La Sarl explored, named after the Louis XIV, and possessed it.

DOC.Title: Canada
DOC.TEXT: A nation which occupies the northern half of North American continent. French people explored from the middle of the 16th century and in 1608 built Quebec along the St. Lawrence River to form a French colony.

DOC.Title: Quebec
DOC.TEXT: In 1608, explorer Champran (1567-1635) was built. It was the center of French North American colonial management. The British army occupied in 1759, the battlefield was decided.

DOC.Title: The 2nd British and France Friendship War, British and French colonial War
DOC.TEXT: It means colonial warfare war between England and France between 1689 and 1815. King William War (1689-97) until the Napoleonic War.

DOC.Title: Farutsu War, Pulz Inheritance War
DOC.TEXT: Invasion war by Louis XIV of France.

DOC.Title: Spain succession war
DOC.TEXT: After the break of the Habsburg house in Spain, the war fought in Europe as one of the invasion war of Louis XIV. At the same time, the fight against colonies between England and France was held under the name of Queen Anne.

DOC.Title: Queen Anne
DOC.TEXT: It means the British and French war in North America during the Spanish succession war. Named after the Queen of England at the time. The British fought against the dominance, peace was established in Utrecht Treaty.

DOC.Title: Utrecht Convention
DOC.TEXT: Peace treaty of the Spanish succession war. Regarding colonies, the following Spanish territory and French colonies were transferred to the UK:

DOC.Title: Hudson Bay Region
DOC.TEXT: From France to England.

DOC.Title: Acadia
DOC.TEXT: From France to England.

DOC.Title: Newfoundland
DOC.TEXT: From France to England.

DOC.Title: Gibraltar
DOC.TEXT: From Spain to the UK.

DOC.Title: Minorca Island
DOC.TEXT: From Spain to the UK.

DOC.Title: Assent, Supply Contract for Supply
DOC.TEXT: Since the 16th century, the Spanish government has signed a slave supply contract with the governments and merchants of each country. Utrecht moved from France to England with the Utrecht Convention, after which Britain gave enormous benefits.

DOC.Title: Austria succession war
DOC.TEXT: A war in Europe where Maria Terezia was caused to succeed Austria. At the same time, the fight against colonies between England and France occurred.

DOC.Title: George King's War
DOC.TEXT: A name that the Austrian succession war spill over the North American colony. British and French colonial competition in North America.

DOC.Title: Seven Years War
DOC.TEXT: A war divided into the Prussian side and the Austrian side. At the same time, the fight against colonies between England and France occurred.

DOC.Title: French = Indian War
DOC.TEXT: British and French colonial war held in North America as part of the seven year war. The UK won the victory.

DOC.Title: Paris Convention
DOC.TEXT: It was concluded between the UK, France and Spain in the Peace Treaty of the Seven Year War and the Colonial War in North America and India.

DOC.Title: Canada
DOC.TEXT: From France to England.

DOC.Title: Louisiana east of the Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: From France to England.

DOC.Title: Louisiana west of the Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: From France to Spain.

DOC.Title: Florida
DOC.TEXT: From Spain to the UK.

DOC.Title: A part of the West Indies
DOC.TEXT: Dominica country. From France to England.

DOC.Title: Senegal
DOC.TEXT: West Africa. French occupied around 1638 as the base of the trade trade. In 1763 it was transferred to the UK, but again in 83 years it became French territory.

DOC.Title: Triangular trade, Atlantic triangle trade
DOC.TEXT: Trading that weapons and miscellaneous goods were transported from Western Europe to West Africa, exchanged for them, mainly in the 17th and 18th centuries, and replaced with sugar etc. in West India.

DOC.Title: Trading trade
DOC.TEXT: Trade mainly sold African residents on the west coast as workers to the colonies of the Americas. Since the 16th century, Portugal, France, etc. had been the main focus, Britain joined in the 18th century, became an important trade department. In Britain it was banned in 1807 by opposition movement.

DOC.Title: Black guy
DOC.TEXT: Mainly blacks brought from Africa to overwork in the Britain and the mines of the West Indies.

DOC.Title: Middle Passage
DOC.TEXT: A route that carries blacks captured as guys to the colonies of the West Indies and the Americas. Because it carries a large number of guys, since it was loaded tightly, its environment was extremely poor and the death rate on board was high.

DOC.Title: Liverpool
DOC.TEXT: A seaport city in the northwestern United Kingdom. From the end of the 17th century began to develop dramatically in the trade trade, during the Industrial Revolution the cotton and cotton products deal went prosperously.

DOC.Title: Plantation
DOC.TEXT: A large plantation system that mainly produces commodity crops for export, spread in colonies and semi colonies. Crops suitable for each climate / culture were cultivated using Indio black people and exported to Europe and the United States.

DOC.Title: Sugar Plantation
DOC.TEXT: It was started in Brazil, a colony of the 16th century Portugal, and then spread to Latin America, the Philippines, Java, and others. Especially Britain actively developed in Jamaica in the West Indies after the 17th century and gained huge profits by using slave labor. In addition, sugar cane plantation caused severe environmental destruction because a large amount of fuel wood was used to boil down the sugar solution.

DOC.Title: Tobacco Plantation
DOC.TEXT: It spread especially in the southern part of North America and was developed using labor.

DOC.Title: Cotton plantation
DOC.TEXT: Managed in India, West Indies, South America, Africa, etc. Many were developed using labor and labor.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Song King
DOC.TEXT: Islamic state built in West Africa. Although it dominated and prospered the Sahara trade route, it was hit by the development of the Atlantic routes and was lost by the expeditionary army from Morocco and it was destroyed.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Benin
DOC.TEXT: Kingdom that flourished in the 13 th-17 th century to the present land of Nigeria. Since the 16th century, Europeans, especially the Portuguese captured black people, sold them, firearms purchased, etc. to become a country of power.

DOC.Title: Daughter Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: A state built in the present land of the Republic of Benin. Throne trade flourished, extreme fear politics took place. After banning trade trade, palm oil was the largest item, but it lost to France.

DOC.Title: Kingdom of Buganda
DOC.TEXT: A kingdom built in the African inland area (currently Uganda). It flourished with the trade of ivory and fellowship with East Africa, but it was regarded as the protectorate of Britain at the end of the 19th century.

DOC.Title: Ashanti Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: A nation built in the present land of the Republic of Ghana. Flourished by trade and money trade, it lost to the UK.

DOC.Title: Science Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Research in the natural world advanced rapidly in the 17th century, the rapid development of modern natural science. From the idea of ​​the medieval church-centered center, he emphasized observation and experimentation and developed it in conjunction with philosophical methods such as induction law and deductive method.

DOC.Title: Academy of Sciences
DOC.TEXT: A research institute established in each country to apply the results of the scientific revolution that advanced in the 17th century.

DOC.Title: British Royal Society
DOC.TEXT: An academic organization in the UK. In about 1645, as the scientific revolution advanced, it was launched as a private group of intellectuals, and in 1662 he got the king's patent letter and became a quasi-public organization. Boyle and Newton join, urging the spread and development of natural science.

DOC.Title: French Academy of Sciences
DOC.TEXT: A semi-public institution established by Colbert in 1666. Purpose of promoting science and technology.

DOC.Title: Berlin Academy of Sciences
DOC.TEXT: Academic research institution of Prussia. Established in 1700, it was expanded and maintained by Friedrich II.

DOC.Title: Boyle
DOC.TEXT: British physicist / chemist. In 1662 I discovered Boyle's law and made a starting point for gas dynamics. It is called "father of modern chemistry".

DOC.Title: Huygens
DOC.TEXT: Physics and astronomer in the Netherlands. Invented the 1656 pendulum clock. I preached the wave theory of light. Discover Saturn's ring.

DOC.Title: Newton
DOC.TEXT: British mathematical physicist. Establish classical mechanics through the discovery of the law of universal gravitation and became the founder of modern physics. In 1703 he became president of the Royal Society of Britain.

DOC.Title: 'Prinquipia'
DOC.TEXT: Abbreviation for "mathematical principle of natural philosophy". Main article of Newton in 1687. A collection of research results of many years on Newtonian mechanics and cosmology, including the law of universal gravitation.

DOC.Title: Lavoisier
DOC.TEXT: French chemist. In 1774, established the combustion theory, established the law of conservation of mass. It was death sentences by the Jakovan regime on the grounds of the tax collector's previous history.

DOC.Title: Laplace
DOC.TEXT: French astronomy and mathematician. In order to explain the formation of the universe from science law, I developed Kant's theory of nebula and preached the theory of space evolution.

DOC.Title: Harvey
DOC.TEXT: British physiologist. 1628 proved blood circulation.

DOC.Title: Linnae
DOC.TEXT: Swedish botanist. Establish taxonomy of animals and plants (especially plants).

DOC.Title: Jenner
DOC.TEXT: A doctor in the UK. In 1796, the vaccination law was developed and a method called vaccination was started.

DOC.Title: Experience theory
DOC.TEXT: A philosophy that was born and developed in the 17th century England. I repeated the experience of observation and experiment, and tried to get correct recognition from it.

DOC.Title: induction method
DOC.TEXT: Thinking method as the source of empirical theory philosophy. It is intended to grasp many individual facts by repeated observation and experiment and to derive a general rule (theory) therefrom.

DOC.Title: Francis Bacon
DOC.TEXT: British scientist / philosopher. I emphasized experimentation and observation and established the foundation of empirical theory (induction law). The main work is "New Organum".

DOC.Title: "New Organum"
DOC.TEXT: Bacon 's incomplete masterpiece Part 2. Published in 1620. Induction was introduced as a new method of academic and scientific perception.

DOC.Title: Hobbes
DOC.TEXT: British philosopher / social thinker. I talked about empiricism and materialism.

DOC.Title: Lock
DOC.TEXT: A British philosopher / political scientist. It greatly influenced the enlightenment thought developed in France. He emphasized empirical theory in "human understanding theory."

DOC.Title: Hume
DOC.TEXT: A British philosopher. From empirical theory to skepticism.

DOC.Title: Rational Theory
DOC.TEXT: A philosophy developed in the continent (especially France) in the 17th century. It is intended to make human reasons the starting point of recognition and to draw a logical conclusion from there.

DOC.Title: Deductive method
DOC.TEXT: A thought method to make a proposition, to logically develop it, to derive a conclusion. Thinking way of rationalism philosophy.

DOC.Title: Descartes
DOC.TEXT: French philosopher. It was regarded as the father of modern rationalism philosophy and was also a mathematician. I conducted most of my research activities in the Netherlands.

DOC.Title: "I think, therefore I am"
DOC.TEXT: A passage in "Methodology". Descartes' words confident of their existence after doubting all the existence. It was the starting point for rationalism philosophy.

DOC.Title: "Method Explanation"
DOC.TEXT: Described in 1637 by Descartes. I explained the methodology of rationalism philosophy.

DOC.Title: Spinoza
DOC.TEXT: A Jewish Dutch philosopher. By mathematical rationalism, I claimed a kind of pantheism.

DOC.Title: Pantheism
DOC.TEXT: Both objects and minds are manifestations of the nature that God has and we think that God and all things are identical. It was heresy from the church.

DOC.Title: Leibniz
DOC.TEXT: German philosopher and mathematician. He was also active in politics and diplomacy. Initiated differential and integral theory, philosophy preached the theory of singles.

DOC.Title: Theory of Singletons, Theory of Monads
DOC.TEXT: A view of the world that all things are formed from self-contained singles and their mutual relationship is God's expected harmony. Leibniz's theory.

DOC.Title: Pascal
DOC.TEXT: French mathematician, physicist, philosopher. I left the famous "Panse" with the word "human beings think about reed."

DOC.Title: Calculus method
DOC.TEXT: Established by Newton or Pascal.

DOC.Title: "Pansé", "Meditation record"
DOC.TEXT: Papal's manuscript in 1670. Fragmentary note for Christian dialecticism.

DOC.Title: Kant
DOC.TEXT: German philosopher. Given criticism as a way of clarifying the possibilities and limitations of recognition, both the empirical theory and the rationalism are regarded as dogmatic, and the German idealism was established.

DOC.Title: "Pure Reason Criticism"
DOC.TEXT: Kant's book of 1781.

DOC.Title: "For eternal peace"
DOC.TEXT: Kant's work in 1795. Establishment of Republicans, the establishment of the International Peace Organization etc.

DOC.Title: Critique philosophy
DOC.TEXT: Kant is the Taisei philosophy. There is a big characteristic in that it has clarified the limit of cognitive ability and avoided determinism.

DOC.Title: German idealism
DOC.TEXT: A part of modern philosophy that starts with Kant and leads to Hegel.

DOC.Title: Theory of royal authority
DOC.TEXT: A theory justifying absolute monarchy. "The control of the king is what the king 's ancestor was given directly from God," and directly asked God the grounds for the absolute nature of the royalty against the people and the feudal lords, even if the king misapprehended There is no responsibility for the people as well. In addition, against the authority of the medieval times such as the emperor of the Holy Father, Holy Roman, there is also the aspect that claims independence of the royalty, and it became the theory to form a sovereign state.

DOC.Title: Filmer
DOC.TEXT: British politician. He served Charles I and declared the theory of kingship.

DOC.Title: Bourdan
DOC.TEXT: French politician / philosopher. I insisted on religious tolerance in the midst of the Huguenot war. After that, he stated the absolute national sovereignty in the main article "State theory" and settled a civil war solution through strengthening of the king.

DOC.Title: Bossche
DOC.TEXT: French bishop and theologian. He served Louis XIV and preached the theory of kingship theory. He also insisted on independence from the French church's pontificate (Galiknism).

DOC.Title: Natural law
DOC.TEXT: Law which can pass through era and region. It also evolved into the idea of ​​"a law that guarantees the rights that human beings are born in their own right." Specifically, it is a way of emphasis on living rights and fundamental human rights, and has become a weapon of criticism against the repression of absolute monarchy, coupled with the social contract theory.

DOC.Title: Groty's
DOC.TEXT: Dutch law scholar / diplomat. Although he was arrested and imprisoned for religious affairs, he jailed and exiled to France and Sweden. From its diverse activities, it is called "Father of International Law" "Father of Modern Natural Law".

DOC.Title: "Ocean freedom"
DOC.TEXT: The work of Grotius in 1609. He insisted freedom of trade and navigation and became the basis of international law concerning the ocean.

DOC.Title: "Law of war and peace"
DOC.TEXT: The main work of Grotius in 1625. Based on the idea of ​​the Natural Law, he insisted on establishing international laws that should be protected even during wartime. Written works, witnessing the disaster of the thirty year war.

DOC.Title: "Father of international law", "Father of modern natural law"
DOC.TEXT: It refers to Grotius.

DOC.Title: International Law Thought
DOC.TEXT: Legal philosophy that establishes relationships among nations. The authority of the Pope and the Holy Roman emperor, who was a mediator of the medieval conflict, was lost in the modern era, and conflicts among sovereign nations became intense, and it was created based on natural law.

DOC.Title: Social Contract theory
DOC.TEXT: It is a political doctrine that society and the state were established by mutual agreement of the people, it was established based on natural law thought. As a political claim, it is divided into the theory of absolute monarchy advocacy (Hobbes) and the theory of people's sovereignty (rock Rousseau).

DOC.Title: Hobbes
DOC.TEXT: British empirical theory philosopher / political scientist. In pursuit of the Puritan Revolution and published to France as "Leviathan" was published.

DOC.Title: "Leviathan"
DOC.TEXT: 1651 by Hobbes. Since human beings are inherently hostile to each other and delegated the full power of governance to the state (Leviathan = monster appearing in the Old Testament) in order to avoid such confusion, it is assumed that despotism of the king is natural.

DOC.Title: "Struggle against every million of people"
DOC.TEXT: The result of the exercise of individual natural rights (living rights) is the word of Hobbes who pretends that self-destruction will result in war situation of 10,000 people per million.

DOC.Title: Lock
DOC.TEXT: English philosopher, political scientist, Enlightenment thinker in the UK. He wrote "Theory of Government" and justified the honorary revolution from the standpoint of human democracy.

DOC.Title: "Theory of Governance", "Theory of citizen's government"
DOC.TEXT: By 1690 Rock. Delegation of control to the government is based on the premise of the property rights of the people and assurance of happiness. When it was hindered, the people said that they had a rebuttal against tyranny, they could demand the return of entrusted rights, the replacement of rulers.

DOC.Title: Enlightenment thought, Enlightenmentism
DOC.TEXT: Reason The idea of ​​trying to rationalistic criticism of authority, thought, institution, and custom from the standpoint of absolute, to release the people from ignorance. Beginning in the 17th century England who experienced the civil revolution, spread to Europe and North America in the 18th century. Especially in France, where the absolute monarchy after the mid-eighteenth century grew, it developed based on the citizens of the city, then rapidly evolved and became the ideological background of the French Revolution.

DOC.Title: Montesquieu
DOC.TEXT: French lawyer / Enlightenment thinker. Retired from the High Court of Bordeaux in 1725, after traveling around Europe, he devoted himself to writing.

DOC.Title: "Spirit of Law"
DOC.TEXT: By Montesquieu in 1748. I discussed the legal system of the countries, claimed the British political system as a model, argued the theory of split power, and preached the restrictions of the kingship.

DOC.Title: "Persian's letter"
DOC.TEXT: By Montesquieu in 1721. He criticized the bold French society in the form of a letter written by a Persian in Paris to his hometown.

DOC.Title: Voltaire
DOC.TEXT: A representative thinker of French Enlightenment. In particular, attacking the intolerance and religious family's intolerance and hypocrisy, accused the Catholic Church. Friedrich II gave himself up to the Sanssasian palace, and through the correspondence with Ecachelina II, it is also famous for having influenced the Enlightenment Thought.

DOC.Title: "Philosophical letter", "From the UK"
DOC.TEXT: By Voltaire in 1734. In addition to introducing and praising British cultures, it implicitly criticized the backwardness and feudalism of France.

DOC.Title: Rousseau
DOC.TEXT: French Enlightenment Thinkers and Literature. Born in Geneva, after wandering and poverty he entered the literary life in Paris. He criticized severe society and gave the deepest influence to the later French Revolution. There are "Emile" famous as a book on natural religion and education as a book.

DOC.Title: "Human inequality origin theory"
DOC.TEXT: By Rousseau in 1755. He attributed the private property system to why human beings became inequitable, and criticized the unequal French society under absolute royalty.

DOC.Title: "Social Contract Theory"
DOC.TEXT: By Rousseau in 1762. Idealized the natural state, insisted strongly on the theory of people's sovereignty, and preached the breakthrough of the French society.

DOC.Title: "encyclopedia"
DOC.TEXT: 1751-72 The monumental encyclopedia of France enlightenment thought. Didlo d'Alembert et al. Became the center of editing and tried to comprehensively introduce the enlightenment thought based on the principle of rationalism, liberalism, and individualism. Criticism of Christianity was severe and pressure from the church was added.

DOC.Title: Encyclopaque school
DOC.TEXT: French Enlightenment thinkers who wrote in "Encyclopedia".

DOC.Title: Diderot
DOC.TEXT: French philosopher and literary student. A key figure in the editing of "Encyclopedia". It was an atheist and a materialist.

DOC.Title: D'Alembert
DOC.TEXT: French mathematician and philosopher. He worked on editing "Encyclopedia" with Diderot and also wrote it.

DOC.Title: Church Merchantism
DOC.TEXT: Economic philosophy to increase national wealth, mainly adopted in the European absolute monarchy countries of the 16th-18th centuries. In particular, we believe that it is the greatest policy to increase exports, suppress imports and bring trade surplus, and therefore the nation (government) will make various interference with economic activities such as protection tariff policy and national protection and protection of domestic industry Was made correct.

DOC.Title: Malgracism
DOC.TEXT: Economic thought that from the second half of the 18th century, especially in France, "the foundation of the wealth of nation and society is in agricultural production". Criticizing interference with national economic activities based on the law of nature and admitting that individuals' freedom of economic activity (free laissez-fa, Lesse-Fèle) is a measure to accumulate wealth. Focusing on production activities rather than distribution processes such as trade, it also had a big influence on the theory of Adam Smith later.

DOC.Title: "Leave it to the eggplants", Lesse = Fail
DOC.TEXT: A slogan of a farmer who insists on eliminating national interference and control over economic activity. British classical economics took over this.

DOC.Title: Flyerism principle
DOC.TEXT: In economic activities, thought that criticizes the interference of the state and respects personal economic freedom. Classical scholars such as the psychologist and Adam Smith who inherited it became the basis of the economic thought of the period of modern capitalism establishment.

DOC.Title: Kennet
DOC.TEXT: French court physician. From about 1753 he studied economics, he wrote the "Economic Table" and became "the father of heavy agriculture". We argue that farmer's tax reduction and liberalization of grain export etc. I also wrote "Encyclopedia".

DOC.Title: "Economic table"
DOC.TEXT: 1758 by Kennet. "The source of wealth is in agricultural production," and insisted on laissez-faire for increased agricultural production. It is regarded as the first work to capture economics in the whole system of production, distribution and consumption.

DOC.Title: Turgot
DOC.TEXT: French political agricultural economist. Kenneth's disciple. Written in "Encyclopedia". Before the French Revolution, he became the Finance Superintendent and tried to rebuild the fiscal, but it was unsuccessful.

DOC.Title: Adam = Smith
DOC.TEXT: British economist / moral philosopher. Completed liberal economics by 'wealth of nations' and opened classical economics. It is called "father of economics".

DOC.Title: "Wealth of nations", "Theory of national wealth"
DOC.TEXT: The main work of Smith, published in 1776. We examined economic theory, history, policy, systematically analyzed the capitalist society for the first time, and preached that "free laissez is the policy to increase the wealth of the country". It is regarded as a masterpiece of classical economics.

DOC.Title: Liberalism economics
DOC.TEXT: Economics that emphasizes the position that national interference to economic activity should be eliminated in order to increase wealth. From the idea of ​​Modern Natural Law that human beings have freedom to pursue happiness, we promise free laisseztism and conflict with Mercantilism.

DOC.Title: Classical economics, classical economics
DOC.TEXT: It refers to the liberal economics that was founded by Adam Smith. It is named for meaning "capitalism analysis classic".

DOC.Title: Baroque art
DOC.TEXT: As a reaction of a neat Renaissance formula, it is a spectacular, brilliant, vibrant art style prevalent in Western Europe from the late 16th century until the early 18th century.

DOC.Title: Palace of Versailles
DOC.TEXT: A building representative of the Baroque style completed by Louis XIV in 1661-82. It is renowned for luxurious buildings and interior decoration, large garden.

DOC.Title: Flanders school
DOC.TEXT: A group of painters who played an active part in the Flemish region. Oil painting method was completed, perspectives were adopted, and many works with high realism. Rubens appeared following Fan = Ike brothers and bruegel, and painted Baroque style works.

DOC.Title: Rubens
DOC.TEXT: Flemish school painter. Leaving a rich and majestic Baroque style episode based on religion and history.

DOC.Title: Fan = Dyke
DOC.TEXT: Flemish school painter. Became a British court painter and left many portraits such as Charles I.

DOC.Title: Dutch painter faction
DOC.TEXT: While inheriting the Flemish faithful tradition, he painted a lot of civic life and the style rather than religious painting and portrait.

DOC.Title: Rembrandt
DOC.TEXT: Representative of the Dutch painter. Drawing the civic life of the Dutch Heian era, it is excellent in depicting light and shadow, establishing modern oil painting technique. Masterpiece work "Night watchman."

DOC.Title: Vermeer
DOC.TEXT: I drew a citizen life and a still life picture of the Netherlands. It is extremely popular, and it is also known that the rarity of the work is high.

DOC.Title: El-Greco
DOC.TEXT: A painter born in Crete, the name is a nickname for "Greeks". Learned from the Venetians, settled in Toledo, Spain since 1577. I left many religious paintings and portraits.

DOC.Title: Velázquez
DOC.TEXT: A representative painter of Spain in the 17th century. As a court house, there are many portraits and landscape paintings with ideas for expression of light rays.

DOC.Title: Murillo
DOC.TEXT: Spanish painter. Along with many pure Virgin and Child paintings, works famous for depicting poor children graphically are also famous.

DOC.Title: Rococo art
DOC.TEXT: An art style prevalent mainly in France around 1720 to 60. It is characterized by delicate and elegant decorativeness after receiving Baroque, and expressing desire for lightness and freedom.

DOC.Title: Palace of Sanssouci
DOC.TEXT: Friedrich II of Prussia, Rebuilt built in Potsdam from 1745 to 47. Representative of Rococo style.

DOC.Title: Potsdam
DOC.TEXT: Cities in the outskirts of Berlin.

DOC.Title: Schönbrunn Palace
DOC.TEXT: A palace built by Austria (Habsburgs) on the outskirts of Vienna against the Palace of Versailles. The appearance is Baroque type, but the interior is mainly decorated in Rococo style.

DOC.Title: Wato
DOC.TEXT: French painter. Many Rococo-style elegant rural court paintings.

DOC.Title: Boucher
DOC.TEXT: French court painter. I drew brilliant delicate genre paintings.

DOC.Title: Fragonard
DOC.TEXT: French painter. It is known for a genius painting with light brushstrokes.

DOC.Title: Baroque music
DOC.TEXT: Luxurious and brilliant music that popularized in the 17th-18th centuries. Bach Handel is representative.

DOC.Title: Bach
DOC.TEXT: German composer / performer. Leaving a lot of excellent work in church music / instrument music, it is called "father of music". Children Christian-Bach are also famous.

DOC.Title: Handel
DOC.TEXT: A German musician. He made Baroque music together with Bach. The late student worked as a British court musician.

DOC.Title: Classical music
DOC.TEXT: It refers to German classical music, from the latter half of the eighteenth century Vienna to Beethoven. It is characterized by work with respect to formal beauty, but since 1830 it developed into Romantic music.

DOC.Title: Haydn
DOC.TEXT: Austrian classical musician. It is called "Father of symphonies".

DOC.Title: Mozart
DOC.TEXT: Austrian composer. In a short life, he left many masterpieces over a wide range of fields such as symphonies, concertos, chamber music, opera, and the like.

DOC.Title: Beethoven
DOC.TEXT: German composer. He compiled classical music and opened the way to Romantic music. In the era of turbulent times since the French Revolution, leaving a masterpiece with freedom and love for humanity, it is called "Seiyu". Major works include Symphony "Destiny", "Countryside", "No. 9" and many piano sonatas.

DOC.Title: Puritan literature
DOC.TEXT: Literature insisting on Puritan's faith, way of life, emotion. In the latter part of the 17th century, I was occupied in the UK in disturbance.

DOC.Title: Milton
DOC.TEXT: A poet in the UK. He enthusiastically supported the Puritan revolution, but after the restoration of the royal court it was not treated, and with the body of blindness he dictated "Lost Paradise".

DOC.Title: "Paradise Paradise"
DOC.TEXT: Great epic of Milton published in 1667. It tells the paradise loss of the "Old Testament" and tries to explain the providence of God through the fight between Adam and Satan as a symbol of human beings.

DOC.Title: Banyan
DOC.TEXT: A British writer. Participated in the Puritan Revolution, imprisoned after the restoration of the royal government.

DOC.Title: "Tenpu history"
DOC.TEXT: In two copies, published in 1678, 84. The allegorical story of Banyan work. It represented plainly the religious struggle of typical Puritans, to heaven.

DOC.Title: Defoe
DOC.TEXT: A British journalist / novelist. I experienced many occupations and repeated experiences such as being imprisoned by satirizing the government. In his later years he announced "Robinson Crusoe" and became a reputation, after which he also presented the novels one after another.

DOC.Title: "Robinson Crusoe"
DOC.TEXT: 1719 Defoe's work. A novel that depicts the appearance of human beings living alone on isolated islands and faith.

DOC.Title: Swift
DOC.TEXT: A satiric writer born in Ireland. While serving as a politician's secretary and clergy, he wrote many articles on government attacks. Then released the best masterpiece of British satire literature "Gulliver travel record".

DOC.Title: "Gulliver's Travel Book"
DOC.TEXT: Swift made in 1726. Through a fictional travel grievous travel book, I sharply criticized and satirized the current state of Britain.

DOC.Title: Classicism literature, French classicism literature
DOC.TEXT: Classicism is a style modeled on Greek and Roman times, with a style that respects rationality and formality, and in France in the 17th century it was established by three major playwrights such as Corneille Racine Molière. The court play is central.

DOC.Title: Corneille
DOC.TEXT: A writer who started the French classicism tragedy.

DOC.Title: Racine
DOC.TEXT: A writer who has greatly trained the French classicism tragedy. At one point I served Louis XIV, but later he bought the incompetence of the king and died in disappointment.

DOC.Title: Moliere
DOC.TEXT: French classicalist comedy writer. He made a character comedy based on sharp human observation and reconfirmed the value of the comedy, often being performed at the court of Louis XIV.

DOC.Title: Academy = Française
DOC.TEXT: French academic research organization organized by Richelieu in 1635. It was integrated into the French degree in 1795 (French Revolutionary Period) and has played a major role in research, refinement and unification of French until today.

DOC.Title: life revolution
DOC.TEXT: Novelty items such as tea, sugar, coffee, cotton fabrics, etc. flowed from the Americas, Africa, Asia, etc. in Europe in the 17th-18th century, the lifestyle changed significantly.

DOC.Title: Cafe
DOC.TEXT: A light food restaurant that appeared in the city of France from the 17th century. Scholars, literatians, merchants, etc. gathered, talked about politics, played the role of a social gathering place to discuss art, together with salons and coffee houses in London, became one of the places for public opinion formation.

DOC.Title: Salon
DOC.TEXT: A cultural social gathering place of the upper class popular in France in the 17th-18th century. Frequently, women of the upper class became organizers, artists and writers gathered, and in the 17th century many literature, literature in the 18th century argued politics and philosophy. It became a place to spread the refinement of French culture, new thought.

DOC.Title: Izakaya
DOC.TEXT: A shop that went public around the 18th century and offered cheap sake to the people. It was a place of rest and gathering for the workers living on the bottom of the city.

DOC.Title: Shinwasuri, Chinese hobby
DOC.TEXT: Chinese hobby popular in Europe during the latter half of the 17th century-early 19th century. It incorporates Chinese style designs for ceramics, furniture and palace walls. It is the European "felt" China, not necessarily accurately depicting the landscape, animals and plants etc in China.

DOC.Title: Botanical Garden
DOC.TEXT: A garden that collects and displays plants. Europeans met innovative plants as they entered the Americas, Asia and Africa, and was established. Not only for watching but also for discovering and improving varieties useful for plantation management in colonies. Especially the latter role played a major role in cue garden founded in the suburbs of London in 1759.

DOC.Title: Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Changes in production technology from tools to machines, which began in the late 18th century in the UK and spread to other countries in the 19th century, and the accompanying major reforms of industry, economy and society. As a prerequisite for the occurrence of the industrial revolution, in general, abundance of capital, market and labor power can be mentioned. As a result of the industrial revolution, while modern capitalism based on the factory-based machine industry was established, various labor problems and social problems occurred. These are referred to as the primary industrial revolution and the stage of nuclear power utilization in the second half of the 2nd and the 20th century is called the tertiary industrial revolution in the latter half of the 19th century, the development of heavy chemical industry by the use of electricity and oil.

DOC.Title: British Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: The first industrial revolution in the world that began in the second half of the 18th century. The reasons are (1) the accumulation of capital by the development of mercantilistic policy and manufac- ture since the 16th century, (2) securing a vast market due to the victory of the colonial war, (3) low cost due to the agricultural revolution of the 18th century (4) high science and technology standards, (5) abundant resources such as iron and coal, and (6) substantial freedom of economic activities by the civil revolution, etc. . The British Industrial Revolution began with technological innovation of the cotton industry, steam engines were used as power sources, and spread to the mechanical, steel and coal industries. In the nineteenth century, inventions and improvements in the transportation sector were encouraged, and the UK established the position of "the world's factory" as an industrialized country.

DOC.Title: Agricultural Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Transformation of agricultural technology and agricultural management that occurred in England in the 18th century. In the 18 th century Britain the new circular farming method aimed at increasing grain production spread, the large enclosure (second) advances, agricultural capitalists hire agricultural workers borrowing land from landowners, capitalist agriculture Management has been established. As a result, a large number of farmers who lost land became factory workers and the industrial revolution was promoted.

DOC.Title: Norfolk Farming Method, Modern Farming Method
DOC.TEXT: A new farming law that started in Norfolk Eastern England in the 18th century. Four wheat farming method in which barley → clover → wheat → turnip in 4-year cycle. Livestock disappeared, livestock raising by grass cultivation became possible, and combined with expansion of enclosure, increased grain production.

DOC.Title: enclosure, enclosure, secondary enclosure
DOC.TEXT: Act of enclosing the cultivated land and the forest surrounded by Britain with fences, hedges and so on. The first was an illegal enclosure for sheep, while the second was carried out on a large scale as a legal movement encouraged by parliaments and governments for the purpose of increasing food production, and on agricultural capitalism Large farm management was established. The increase in food production caused by this agricultural revolution suppressed the population increase during the industrial revolution and the industrial revolution was promoted by becoming a wage worker for farmers who lost land.

DOC.Title: woolen textile industry
DOC.TEXT: Representative industry in the UK since the late Middle Ages. Since the 16th century, it became the basis of the British economic prosperity, and it had reached the manufacturing stage early.

DOC.Title: cotton industry
DOC.TEXT: Industry that became the center of the textile industry on behalf of the woolen textile industry in the late eighteenth century. When the East India Company imported Indian cotton fabrics in the 18th century, demand increased instead of woolen fabrics, and cotton imported from the United States and India developed as a crotch. With almost no guild regulation, introduction of new technology was easy, technical innovation was promoted in both spinning and woven fabric processes, and the industrial revolution began.

DOC.Title: John = Kay
DOC.TEXT: A weaver who invented the jumping lyrics. Following the persecution of the woven fabrics exposed to the danger of unemployment, after moving for several times, he ran away to France and died in poverty.

DOC.Title: Jumping Lip, Jumping 梭
DOC.TEXT: 1733 Equipment of woven fabric process invented by Kay. A device that weaves cloth by automatically moving lyrical thread wound with weft thread between warp yarns. The work of two people in the past was made possible by one person, and the efficiency was greatly improved. It became easier to make wide cloth, and spread from cotton fabric to around 1760. Because of this invention, yarn shortage became severe, and the invention was encouraged in the spinning process.

DOC.Title: Hargreaves
DOC.TEXT: A weaver / carpenter who invented Jenny spinning machine. Hated by skilled workers who are afraid of unemployment, there was a patent dispute, etc., and they died in poverty.

DOC.Title: Jenny spinning machine, multi-axis spinning machine
DOC.TEXT: Around 1764 (there is the theory of 67 years) Spinning machine invented by Hargreaves. Junee is said to be the name of his wife or daughter. Using a roller we could spin eight yarns by one person, and that improved machine was able to spin 80 yarns by one person. With this invention, the industrial revolution began in earnest.

DOC.Title: ArcLight
DOC.TEXT: Inventors of hydraulic spinning machines (also referred to as comprehensive of the advantages of others' inventions). Introduced steam power as power, it enabled factory-based mass production.

DOC.Title: Hydraulic spinning machine
DOC.TEXT: 1768 (69 years patent) Spinning machine invented by ArcLight. We improved Jenny spinning machine, made continuous work possible, and utilized hydraulic power as power. Then in 1990, we improved the one that powered by the steam engine, relaxed the location conditions of the factory, opened the way to mass production at the factory.

DOC.Title: Crompton
DOC.TEXT: Spinning work inventing mule spinning machine. Humbly saying that it was only the integration of inventions of others, named Mule (Mule (<Momentary hybrid between horses and donkeys>)) and did not apply for a patent.

DOC.Title: Mule Spinning Machine
DOC.TEXT: A spinning machine invented by 1779 Crompton. I took in the advantages of Jenny spinning machine and hydraulic spinning machine and could spin thin and strong yarn. This made it possible to produce quality cotton fabrics that will surpass the Indian produced Characo / Muslin. This principle is still in use today.

DOC.Title: Cartwright
DOC.TEXT: Pastor / inventor. Invention of hydraulic spinning machine invented a power loom in the woven cloth process as the yarn became overproduction.

DOC.Title: Power loom
DOC.TEXT: 1785 Machinery of woven fabric process invented by Cartwright. I got some hints from the hydraulic spinning machine and used a steam engine for the woven fabric process. The efficiency is 3.5 times the jumping lips, and the principle of the loom after that is on this extension.

DOC.Title: Whitney
DOC.TEXT: An American inventor. Invented the cotton-making machine and became a pioneer of the American Industrial Revolution.

DOC.Title: Cotton ginning machine
DOC.TEXT: 1793 Whitney invented, a machine to cotton fiber from seed. It has a working efficiency of 300 times that of manual work, increasing the cotton cultivation in the southern part of the United States, and enough cotton can be supplied to the UK.

DOC.Title: Steam engine
DOC.TEXT: An engine that converts thermal energy into power by using water vapor. Since Wat became practical use in the 18th century, and furthermore, Watt made an epochal improvement, it was used as a mechanical power in all sectors instead of human power, livestock, wind power, hydraulic power etc. until then, promoted the industrial revolution (The importance as a power source in the beginning of the 20th century shifts to electric power and petroleum-based power).

DOC.Title: Newcomen
DOC.TEXT: Mechanical engineer / inventor. In 1712, the steam engine was put to practical use as the power of the drain pump of the coal mine. Because the cylinder and the cooler were shared, the thermal efficiency was low, the fuel consumption increased, and it lost to the steam engine of Watt.

DOC.Title: Watt
DOC.TEXT: Mechanical engineer / inventor. By greatly improving the steam engine of Newcomen in 1769, by separating the cylinder and the cooler, we doubled the thermal efficiency and succeeded in drastically reducing coal consumption. Furthermore, in 1781, Suzuki succeeded in converting the reciprocating movement of Biston into a rotary motion, and steam engines, which was conventionally a power for a bump, opened the possibility of becoming power of every machine, and the age of machines arrived It was.

DOC.Title: Machinery Industry
DOC.TEXT: Industrial field established by utilization of steam engine power. It became the basis of factory production and dramatically improved productivity.

DOC.Title: Iron Industry
DOC.TEXT: An industrial field that has developed with increasing demand for iron as a raw material for machinery and equipment. By means of Derby's fathers' inventions, the production increased by changing the fuel from charcoal to coal / coke. From the end of the 18th century the UK became an exporter of iron materials and the iron industry promoted the development of other sectors as the core industry of various industries.

DOC.Title: Derby
DOC.TEXT: Ironmaker. My father developed the coke ironmaking law in 1709, and the child further developed it. As a result, the era of iron making using charcoal is over, mass production of iron became possible.

DOC.Title: Coal industry
DOC.TEXT: From the fuel for domestic use, iron refining, coal demand as a fuel for steam engines has increased, the energy industry has developed rapidly.

DOC.Title: Energy Revolution
DOC.TEXT: The fact that the leading role of energy has changed from charcoal to coal (coke) by the development of coke iron making method and invention of steam engine. As a result, deforestation to obtain charcoal decreased, temporarily stopping the environmental destruction.

DOC.Title: Traffic Revolution, Transportation Revolution
DOC.TEXT: A dramatic advance in traffic according to the necessity of large-volume long-distance transportation of raw materials / products which have been drastically increased by the industrial revolution. Beginning with the construction of a canal, a steamship and a steam locomotive have appeared by the invention of a steam engine. Large numbers of personnel and goods are transported more safely and faster than in the past, regions around the world have been connected in a short time, and along with the development of telegraph networks, the integration of the world has been promoted at an accelerated pace.

DOC.Title: Canal
DOC.TEXT: Artificially created waterway. It was inexpensively built in the UK in the late 18th century as a means of goods transportation in a large scenery. After the middle of the 19th century, it fainted with the development of the railway.

DOC.Title: Fulton
DOC.TEXT: An American technician. In 1807, the world's first outer ring steamship Kuramontto was built.

DOC.Title: Steamboat
DOC.TEXT: A boat powered by a steam engine. In 1807, a steamship (Clermont) was invented by Fulton, and in 1819 the Savannah was successfully crossed the Atlantic for the first time as a steamship. These were bad inefficiencies, but in the latter half of the 30 's adopted a screw propeller, a ship with excellent navigation appeared, steam ship began to be used for ocean voyage on behalf of a sailing ship.

DOC.Title: Road
DOC.TEXT: In order to transport a large amount of raw materials, products and coal, pavement and expansion of the road became necessary, and a private company to create a new toll road was also established.

DOC.Title: Trevisic
DOC.TEXT: British engineer / inventor. In 1804, steam locomotive and rail were combined to invent the first orbital steam locomotive. It has low performance and many failures, it did not come into practical use.

DOC.Title: Stevenson
DOC.TEXT: British engineer / inventor. In 1814, I developed a practical steam locomotive, and in 25 years I successfully transported customers and cargo steam locomotives in the Locomotion issue.

DOC.Title: Steam locomotive
DOC.TEXT: Rails were used for a long time in coal mines, and orbital steam locomotives also appeared in the 1790s, but in 1804 Trevic chains combined them and invented an orbital steam locomotive running on a rail. Furthermore Stevenson improved and opened the way to practical use in 25 years, and in 1930 the operating railroad of about 45 km between Manchester and Livabourg opened.

DOC.Title: Stockton · Darlington
DOC.TEXT: Steam locomotive, developed by Stevenson in 1825, was able to run a test run at about 18 km / h between Stockton and Darlington, with 35 passenger cars and freight cars.

DOC.Title: Manchester · Livabourg
DOC.TEXT: In September 1830, steam locomotive developed by Stevenson began the first commercial operation between Manchester and Liverpool.

DOC.Title: Railroad
DOC.TEXT: Since opening in earnest in the UK in 1830, it opened in 30 years in the United States, 32 years France, 35 years Germany · Belgium, 38 years Russia, 39 years in the Netherlands · Italy.

DOC.Title: Commercial capitalist
DOC.TEXT: Large merchants who became affluent through commodity circulation and wholesale system mainly based on trade since the absolute monarchy period. Tied to the royal authority, held a monopoly right, he quickly became a member of the House with the landlord and dominated the national affairs.

DOC.Title: Mechanical factory
DOC.TEXT: As a production tool, a factory used machines instead of tools. With this popularization, it became possible to produce cheap and large quantity of products, the economic activity changed from agriculture to industrial center, and a capitalist society where industrial capitalists dominated the business world was established.

DOC.Title: Industrial capitalist
DOC.TEXT: A capitalist who owns production means (factory, land, machine, etc.) and seeks profits by producing goods. After becoming an industrial revolution, he became a manager of a machinery factory from a manager company manager and acquired a dominant position in economic, social and political fields on behalf of commercial capitalists.

DOC.Title: Capitalist regime
DOC.TEXT: Economic and social systems that capitalists who own production means, hire workers to produce goods, pursue profits. It was established in the UK in the UK where the industrial revolution and factory production by machines developed.

DOC.Title: Capitalist
DOC.TEXT: People who capitalize on themselves, own production means, hire workers there to produce goods and profit. Or a person who profits by lending capital. In order to secure maximum profit, we insisted on free deal and respect for private property.

DOC.Title: Working class, proletariat
DOC.TEXT: People who are employed by capitalists and live with their wages paid because they do not have production means. With the progress of the industrial revolution, we increased the number and conflicted with the capitalist class aiming to improve our lives.

DOC.Title: Labor problems
DOC.TEXT: Problems such as poor work conditions such as low wages and long hours workers of workers, especially women and children, and problems such as an increase in unemployed, which occurred with the establishment of a capitalist society.

DOC.Title: Women's / Child's Labor
DOC.TEXT: Since the use of machines did not require skilled skills, women with low wages and children were hired as workers and became the center of early labor problems.

DOC.Title: Unity-Prohibition Law
DOC.TEXT: Act prohibiting unity of workers as civil penalties. In the UK, it was enacted in 1799 and 1800, banned the unity of workers, but was abolished in 1824.

DOC.Title: Machine striking movement
DOC.TEXT: A riot that destroyed machinery and facilities as craftworkers and workers said that the cause of their living is in the newly invented machines. It originated in the 1810's.

DOC.Title: Laddite movement
DOC.TEXT: Mechanizing strike movement occurred in the textile industrial area in the middle and north of England. A name named after the legendary character Rudd. It was suppressed by the severe repression measures of the government.

DOC.Title: "Holy Monday"
DOC.TEXT: A kind of custom made by artisans absent from work due to participation in various events on Monday. Beginning from the latter half of the Middle Ages, when the Industrial Revolution began, workers who had been subjected to severe work spent a lot of pubs on Sundays and were also exercised as "customs" without absence or late arrival on Monday.

DOC.Title: Factory Act
DOC.TEXT: A set of laws stipulating the working conditions of factory workers. Beginning with the apprentice law in 1802, the General Factory Act of 1933 stipulated banning nighttime work under the age of 18, 9 hours of work under the age of 13, 12 hours of under 18 years of age, factory oversight regime. In 1844, it took 6 and half hours of 8 to 12 years old, 12 hours of women working, 47 years of women and children 10 hours worked. Such regulation also led to improvement of working conditions of adult male workers.

DOC.Title: General Factory Act
DOC.TEXT: In 1833, the law enacted by the Shaftesbury efforts, prescribing mainly the protection of working conditions of children and young people and the adoption of factory supervisory control system.

DOC.Title: Labor Movement
DOC.TEXT: An exercise that workers who came to have a class consciousness united to seek improvement of their social and economic situation. Following the abolition of the Unity-Forbidden Law (1824), labor unions were formed and often associated with socialist movement seeking transformation of the capitalist regime, while acquiring and extending workers' political rights, improving and maintaining work conditions In terms of playing a major role.

DOC.Title: labor union
DOC.TEXT: A group of workers aimed at maintaining and improving working conditions. In the old days it had a fellowship organization and secret societal character but from the latter half of the Industrial Revolution it became popularized and became the subject of the labor movement. In the United Kingdom it was legalized in 1871 's labor union law.

DOC.Title: Social Issues
DOC.TEXT: A collective term for problems such as labor, price, women, housing, sanitation, crime, which are thought to have arisen from a defect in the capitalist society. Since the 19th century, people began to be conscious of themes as a theme.

DOC.Title: "Factory in the world"
DOC.TEXT: It means England in the mid-19th century with overwhelming industrial power. It was first used by the British economist Jevons.

DOC.Title: Pax = Britannica
DOC.TEXT: Because Britain had overwhelming power, it is a word that states the world has become stable and peaceful. Latin for "British peace".

DOC.Title: Integration of the world
DOC.TEXT: Since the middle of the 19th century, Europe (in particular the UK) has taken over the initiative and involves the Americas, Asia and Africa, and the world has become moving with a deep relationship with each other. Traffic revolution / communication revolution etc. accelerated this movement.

DOC.Title: Population city concentration
DOC.TEXT: After the Industrial Revolution, the increase in urban population became noticeable. Especially in the UK this trend is steep, and in 1851 the urban population exceeded the rural population. However, serious urban problems such as the occurrence of slums, deterioration of security, epidemic prevalence caused by environmental deterioration occurred.

DOC.Title: Manchester
DOC.TEXT: Industrial city in the Midwest England. As a result of the industrial revolution, it became the largest cotton industrial city in the Lancashire region, and the population soared. It became the ground of the 19th century British liberal movement.

DOC.Title: Birmingham
DOC.TEXT: Industrial city in the middle of England. It is close to the production area of ​​iron and coal, became the center of steel industry · machine industry, developed into a large industrial city.

DOC.Title: Liverpool
DOC.TEXT: In the 18th century it developed with trade trade, after the industrial revolution it prospered as a port of Manchester.

DOC.Title: Belgian Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: It is influenced by resources such as iron and coal, has been affected by Britain before and after independence in 1830, the industrial revolution has advanced in the textile industry, steelmaking industry, machinery industry and others.

DOC.Title: French industrial revolution
DOC.TEXT: It has made full progress since the July Queenan period of the 1830's. The decomposition of small peasants generated by the French Revolution did not proceed, the labor force and capital were insufficient, and the progress was moderate.

DOC.Title: German Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: A customs union was formed in 1834, economic unification has advanced, and industrialization has advanced since the 1840 's, especially in Rhineland. After unification in 1871, he acquired Alsace · Lorraine rich in mineral resources, the heavy-chemical industry developed under the protection policy of the state, and in late 19th century it surpassed France and came close to the UK.

DOC.Title: American Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Protection of British products The tariff policy of northern part of the country has developed industries, abundant resources and labor shortage promoted mechanization of agriculture and industry. In the 1830s, the industrial revolution centered on the cotton industry · metal machinery industry became full scale, the domestic market was unified by the Civil War of the 1960s, and the industrial revolution was completed for the time being.

DOC.Title: Russian Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Since the liberation of the agriculture in 1861, we made progress with the introduction of capital and technology such as France. In the 1890s heavy industry rapidly developed.

DOC.Title: Japan Industrial Revolution
DOC.TEXT: After the Meiji Restoration, the Government's fostering industry promotion policy triggered, the industrial revolution became full-fledged mainly by light industry before and after the Sino-Japanese War. Heavy industry developed mainly in the munitions sector before and after the Russo-Japanese War, and the mechanization of the transportation and transportation sector also progressed.

DOC.Title: American independence revolution
DOC.TEXT: The American Revolutionary War of the United States from 1775 to 1983 is not an independent war but a citizen revolution as a citizen revolution in that the civil strat have broke down the feudal custom and raised the fundamental human rights such as freedom and equality and the principle of human democracy It has a personality and is called an independent revolution. The influence spanned the French Revolution, the liberalism and nationalism of the 19th century, the independence movement of Latin America.

DOC.Title: Virginia
DOC.TEXT: State in southern USA. In 1584-85, Lori built the first British colony in the Americas and failed to name it Virginia after the virgin king Elizabeth I. After that, a new colony was built by the London company (later Virginia company) in 1607, and it developed with tobacco cultivation.

DOC.Title: New England
